content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												What I like:- It has a nice difficulty level.- Nostalgia successfully evoked for people who played classics such as Lands of Lore or Eye of the Beholder.- Fights and character builds require some strategy.- You can make notes on the ingame map. For example, you can write there "spells" next to a shop where you can do that, or "axe" at a spot where you can level up a characters axe skill.- Some replayability possible. The puzzles and enemies will be the same, but you can build a different party of different classes and thus attempt to beat the game with a different setup, using the higher of the two available difficulty modes.- Some of the puzzles and riddles are fun.What I dislike:- Ubisoft. That means you have to deal with Ubisofts Uplay nonsense, bad support, DRM and whatnot.- The game is sometimes a bit sparse in matters of telling you where to do what. Without researching sometimes on the internet where to do what, you might get frustrated.- I had one annoying bug so far.- Sometimes, every couple of hours, it crashes. Since it saves automatically ever now and then and has a quicksave option, this is bearable though.- The graphics are mixed. They're not good, but some models and parts of the dungeons look nice. Other parts, especially outdoor textures, look very bad if you get closed.Neutral:- Some of the game mechanics make sense gameplaywise but are highly illogical. For example, the buffs on your party (like one that protects you from damage) last a certain number of turns (during combat) or moves. But you can, for example, rest for 8 hours to regenerate your party, and those buffs are all still up. Sometimes you can also rest for 8 hours before a boss fight, and the boss will just wait until you're done.- In some of those old RPGs I liked that the positioning of the party mattered (melee fighters in the front, ranged fighters and spell casters in the back). In this game, the positioning is irrelevant. - The difficulty is not increasing in an entirely linear way. You will encounter enemies you can't beat at that point. On the other hand, the game saves automatically all the time, so you just reload and ignore that part for the time being.So, all in all, if you like those retro-RPGs, this one is ok. It's not great, but is entertaining enough. 25 Euro is a bit expensive in my opinion, but for 15 Euro or less, like during a Steam Sale, I can easily recommend it, as far as you don't buy it randomly but realized that you get a retro style RPG instead of a new Witcher or Elder Scrolls. Well, and you have to be aware that there are still a couple of bugs in the game.

content:
Posted: March 9
Play hours not accurate, I have 100+ hours on UplayThis game has plenty of flaws and you'll need hardware way above the listed requirements to enjoy it at decent framerates, but man, is exploring its wide, grid-based world and fighting using its turn-based combat system enjoyable!This is an old-school RPG where you create a party from scratch or using pre-made characters and go adventuring. While initially linear, the game opens up more and more to exploration as you progress. Not everything is at your level either, which is a breath of fresh air if you're used to Skyrim and the like: make sure to save often, because taking the wrong turn or entering the wrong cave can put you in a lot of trouble!Flaws:- Uplay- Sometimes bland graphics with high system requirements (some dungeons do look great though)- Long intro cutscene and a story you won't care about- If you're like me you'll find the beginning town and first combat encounters boring- Repetitive voice acting of your characters (fixable by digging in the game files)- RPG system is not the deepest or most interesting I've seenYou also need to be aware that this is not really like the old World of Xeen games, and it is not like M&M 7-8-9 either. It's pretty much its own beast, mixing elements from both and adding or modernizing others.I'm still recommending the game despite all its flaws, which goes to show how good it is. And it's pretty much the only recent game available for this particular blend of turn-based, grid-based exploration.Some players including me had trouble progressing beyond the first chapter of the game because of a leftover mechanism that was used to give players early access to a part of the game. I've put up a guide on how to work around that problem: 


Workarounds for Blocked Act 2 and Bridge 
A Guide for Might & Magic X - Legacy 
By: UncleYar

			This might fix your game if for some reason you're blocked from progressing in the game by the leftover Early Access mechanisms.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Might and Magic X doesn't try to reinvent the fantasy RPG, it sticks pretty close to the roots and the tried and true tropes of the genre.  And that's precisely why it's fun.You will create a party of heroes, and you've got a decent variety of options to choose from, enough that I wanted to play again after finishing to try out some different party makeups with different skills.The game plays out on a grid, viewed from a first person perspective, which gives it a classic dungeon crawler feel, but you've also got some convenient modern concessions such as the ability to look around freely, and an automap.  This gives you just enough of those old-school tingles to warm your aging nerd heart, without the frustration of trying to map the entire world yourself on graph paper or figure out which direction you are facing. (I know there are those who prefer that level of masochism in their gaming, I'm not among them, these are dealbreakers for me these days.)You'll get a decent level of challenge on the default setting -- you will have to think about your own party's skills and spells, and how they will work against different monsters attacks and defenses.  It's not coddling you but it's not so "hardcore" as to be unfun.   There is no level scaling here, so you will need to explore around the world a bit at times looking for encounters that are appropriate to your squad's level.  Personally i enjoy this part of the game, but if you're looking for an open-world experience where you can go anywhere you wish and always find beasties who aren't quite good enough to kill you, this isn't it.This game scratches some of my chronic itches that big budget games just won't touch anymore, much as I love them.  Namely:It's turn-basedIt's party-basedthere's no level-scalingit lets itself have fun with charming little gimmicks like riddle chests and open-ended questions.It's not driven by a cinematic narrativeIt doesn't try to reinvent the genre.  These last two points are the key to why I have enjoyed playing the game so much.  There's something mentally taxing about playing a game that tries to introduce a lot of new elements, especially when it's a heavily story driven experience.  I have to invest time and energy learning a whole new world, yes sometimes that's great.  But sometimes the story or gameplay doesn't hold up and I end up abandoning the game.  Sometimes I just want to kill monsters and loot treasure in a world that goes back to the familiar well of orcs, elves and dragons.So, give me simple, give me palatable, give me something that feels old-fashioned, but looks nice and bows reasonably to modern game conventions like automaps and quest journals.  Give me something that fits like an old shoe, without the stink.  give me more games like M&MX.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Might and Magic X I can only some up as a OK, there is enjoyment to be found in this game but there are many stretches where the game comes across as repetative and grindy. There is a nostelgic feel for old school western RPGs and if you are a fan of this niche genre then you will get your monies worth for the game. However, there is a reason why this style of RPG went out of date and I believe this game falls incredably short of reviving it. The combat system was fairly basic although not in a bad way, the depth for leveling up however was somewhat lacking and the different abilites only a few seemed playable, which hearts the replayability of the game. The positivies I found out of the game was the atmosphere, it did feel like I was inside the Might and Magic world and the lore was present in the form of the collectables in the game. The main narrative however had its high and lows but for the most part I feel like it continued on from Heroes VI well enough. In the end I really, really wanted this game to be amazing as I loved the story of Heroes VI and am a fan of this style of RPG however the game fell flat and I was simply left wanting more. I am hopeing one day the studio retries to make another RPG M&M  game but puts in as much effort as they have done with there past games.Rating: 5.5/10

												Ok, I am a big Might & Magic fan and have played MIght & Magic since the beginning back on a Commodore 64 with Might & Magic 1 & 2.  I can say that prior to this game Might & Magic VI was the best version that I had come across and when this game came out in that style and for the Mac I was absolutely estatic and had to get the game.  Pro's:  Has the same feel as the MIght & Magic VI style of play.  Pretty badass game to that extent.Con's:  This is a major con.  The game as far as I can see does not respawn.  So when you finish a map, you literally finish a map.  Yes, you can travel through the map itself to get to another part but have no way to develop a more powerful character.  You are basically limited to the level that the game is setup for.  This gives control to the gameplay to keep it complicated for the customers, but it takes out the randomness of the game, which once you realize that, the game seriously loses its appeal.  I literally went back to Might & Magic VI by downloading Crossover and the PC version on my Mac to play the game.  It plays flawlessly but Might & Magic X just does not compare to VI.  They were so close yet unless they change that part of the game, I would have to give this a thumbs down :(

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Might and Magic X is a real treat for fans of open-world exploration and dungeon crawling. The game delivers an old-school first-person RPG experience complete with cities, landscales, dungeons, side-quests, vast character/party builds, and some choices to make along the way. The turn-based combat is as fast-paced as you want it to be, and it serves to curb double-step exploits found in similar, older RPGs. Deciding how to level-up your characters is involving, and you can really make the characters you set out to. The default (lower) difficulty feels perfect, if not a tiny bit too easy for series veterans; by no means is it a pushover, nor is it as punishing to newcomes as some mainstream reviews may suggest. The game feels balanced and polished, at least for the 20+ hours I've played it. I have encountered a couple small bugs, but nothing game-breaking, and the developers have made it clear they will continue to support the game into the future.Overall, if you are a fan of old-school RPGs with modern advancements, or are to new Might and Magic, this is a game worth getting.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												FOR 64 BIT OS-Much better in 64 bit. I had to buy a new copy of Windows, since my old one was OEM and I had changed out the motherboard.Unity still sucks and it is still an insane resource hog, but the game itself is kinda fun.PS- I haven't spent that many hours playing it. If I'm alt tabbed out of it for a day or two, or even if uplay is just still running, and SOMETIMES even steam, then Steam thinks I'm playing.FOR 32 BIT OS-Unity? Really? Either it is the game engine itself, or this game has been so poorly coded that it has zero optimization and demands more memory usage than, well, any other game out there.This, despite it being a small game that has nothing close to cutting edge technology. It is a retro style game with grid movement. As a result of the poor coding or poor game engine, while 32 bit software is listed as supported, it really isn't, as the game only partially works with it.Using a 32 bit OS (even Windows 7) you only get some sounds. No player barks, no ambient sounds, no monster sounds. Just some music and button clicking sounds.Also, you only get "medium" textures, but this is a deceptive turm, since the texture quality is low- medium- high- very high- ultra. With medium level textures, this game looks like it was made by two indie game developers in a basement during their time off from work. In the year 2003. This is a shame, as a lot of love and hard work has clearly been poured into the game, and it's artwork.Pretty sad for me, too, as I've been waiting so very, very long for a new Might and Magic game! Might and Magic III was my frst game in the series. I played that little RPG to death!If you have a 64 bit OS, I'm sure it's great.If you have a 32 bit OS, and, like me, cannot afford to upgrade/lost your original CD and key, don't bother. I know it's listed in the steam store as being supported, and it's listed by ubisoft as being supported, but that's a lie. If you complain, they'll cut and paste a blurb about how it isn't recommended and you should just upgrade to a 64 bit OS. Thanks, guys.A lot of people were decived by what they heard about the early release, too, since 32 bit OS players could, pre-release, play with all the sound and max texture quality, instead of the butt-ugly silent thing they got at release.Speaking of, I bought the digital deluxe version.  Where's my soundtrack? I was supposed to get a soundtrack for paying the $5 extra for my butt-ugly game. And really? I used Steam because I hate uPlay and how flaky it is. But no. Nope! You have to go through TWO DRM software systems. You have to go through Steam, and then what loads up? uPlay! Awesome! So you have to be running Steam and uPlay to run this game. AND use an activation key. A key which Steam seems to think it needs you to copy and paste and apply EVERY TIME YOU START THE GAME. You also get to sit and watch it try to install dirextX and .net framework and something else every time you start it up. Come on now, son. Come on. Do you really think everyone's going to want to pirate this game so badly? Oh, and thanks for adding in the paper doll int he inventory that everyone wanted. Except... y'all missed the whole point of it. We liked the paper doll in 6-8 because you could put them in the armor you found, and see it. Instead, it's just an illustration of the class and gender, and one of two (way too small for some reason, in a number of cases) heads that just gets pasted on the body interchangeably, per race and gender. Zzzz. Pointless...The good? You want the good? Okay. Well, I like that they brought back the characters showing their state of health in their main portraits. Somebody gets poisoned? They turn green and look sick. That's neat. The 2D UI looks nice. I wish the game world didn't look like orc poop, but the UI looks nice.The action bar is a good thing. Having access to more than one spell at the click of a button is a great idea.That's... that's all I can think of. I keep trying to play it. I keep trying to get into it and I just can't. It's so broken in a 32 bit OS. :(Sorry. it sucks.

Posted: July 19, 2016
												World of Xeen remains one of my favorite games of all time and the Might and Magic series has been a staple of mine from M&M II to M&M VIII.  So of course I jumped on the chance to play M&M X.What it gets right:Turn-based party-based RPG mechanics.Familiar Might and Magic loot.Familiar Might and Magic skill and expertise system.Character banter.No game breaking bugs or deal breakers so far.Doesn't come on a dozen 3.5" floppy disks.What's missing:Some basic elements, the character portraits, the interface, could be tightened up a bit.The font of the in-game text doesn't seem to fit.It's subjective but the holistic package is just lacking to a small degree.What's wrong:I'm not a fan of the fixed race/class character creation.I want my old school Xeen class system with fighter, mage, cleric, thief and multi-class combinations assigned to any race/character portrait.Needs a larger party and more races/classes/skills in general.Might and Magic X - Legacy is not a perfect game.  If you are not familiar with the series and play only top tier perfect games, you will be disappointed in it.  If you are a fan of Isles of Terra or World of Xeen, you will probably find a lot to love.  My hope is this is a resurrection and the first of many Might and Magic titles.  If so, I will be playing the hell out of them.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I was concerned this wouldn't be a recommendation after participating in the Early Release, which was incredibly disappointing. However, I was pleasantly surprised when the final release came out that a large number of the issues I had with the game had been addressed. Overall, M&MX does a good job of capturing the old school vibe of earlier entries in the system, while taking advantage of some of their later design improvements first seen in their Heroes series of games. That said, the game misses the mark in several ways. First, the graphic performance is very disappointing. It looks like a game optimized for 5+ years ago. The creation and skill system does a poor job of helping new players understand pros and cons of the abilities and how they impact gameplay. The amount of running through previously cleared areas is frustrating. The limited voice acting is grating and repetitive.Despite those disappointments, this does scratch the itch for a classic, party-based, first person roleplaying experience. The exploration, discovery, hidden bits, and character classes do feel like previous entries in the system. For a truly authentic experience, and to help off-set the disappointing graphics, I strongly recommend selecting the "classic pixelated" display found in the gameplay settings menu. Other pros - once you're familiar with the game, the classes are diverse and offer a lot of variety in how you want to build your party. Combat is tactical enough to be satisfying without slowing the game down too much. Boss fights are brutal but winnable with careful play. The cool epic items that level up with your character are awesome. It's casual enough to be approachable by a wide audience. It's a fairly good value for its pricepoint. It has a strong nostalgia element. I think people familiar with other games in the series will be most likely to enjoy this version, but it shouldn't stop new players from giving it a shot!

												The game mechanics are a bit old school.  Depending on what you are into, this is either a good or bad thing.  I definitly like this game although the only thing I dislike about it (and old-school thing) is that there are a fair amount of riddles and puzzles. You go through several long levels of fighting the same enemies over and over.  It is quite tedious and boring.  I mean, if you have destroyed 10 sets of the same enemies under various "ambush" scenerios, I think you have proven your point that you can handle these guys.  Why then, make you go on and fight another 40 sets of these guys?  It is lazy game deisgn.Other than that, this game is well worth the asking price since it is so cheap.

number of helpful: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Might and Magic X - LegacyPositives:+ Successfully emulates the old-school Might and Magic series, with a party creation system which feels very familiar. There's also other classic additions, such as portraits of your characters in-game. Many of the distinct Might and Magic sounds from the games 7-9 have been re-used, which brings back memories.+ Graphically, the game looks modern and interesting, which is great.+ A fairly large game world to explore with relative freedom, quite a few quests to engage in as well, along with class promotions. + Story is intriguing and lengthy, took me about 55 hours to complete all main quests, with side quests included.+ Lots of different monsters to fight - naga samurai, air, earth, fire and water elementals, brigands, harpies, griffins, cyclopses, goblins, minotaurs...and many more.- Turn based combat which is different from Might and Magic 7-9, but actually works really well, giving you a chance to tactically assess what spells you'll cast and how you'll attack.Negatives:- Throughout the game a lot of audio is constantly repeated (such as locals talking), and for some people this might get irritating.- Decent amount of puzzles with varying difficulties, although I found some of these to be tedious, boring and annoying, resorting to simply googling the solutions.- Grid based movement, which is a step down from conventional games where you can freely turn and walk in any direction. While this isn't ideal it doesn't drastically impact on the fun of the game, it just means it's not as fluid as it could have been.Overall Score: 8/10Might and Magic X - Legacy is an excellent RPG which mirrors the old series from the 1990s. Even if you're a Might and Magic 7-9 fan, you should still grab this game because it's awesome fun.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I first should say I liked this game, but I liked it for all the wrong reasons, the gameplay is subpar at best and you can end up glitched into a situation where you have to reload from a previous save or a situation where you might have to reload from so long ago that it might as well be restarting. Additionally if you uninstall for whatever reason and re-install if you didn’t personally back up your saves they may just disappear. In the game the general forced turn-based style (which while in heroes has been optional in regular Might and magic since 1995) not only slows the game down to a crawl but makes it incredibly easy to defeat enemies, in actuality the only time you will ever have any difficulty in this game is when they force you onto a ledge before spawning the enemies or in hallways where you magically get surrounded. But the worst offense this game commits is making it impossible to fix any mistake you made. Now I know I said enemies were easy so this shouldn’t be a problem but it is since no enemy ever respawns there is a limited amount of gold and exp in the world and dead characters don’t get exp. So in those rare fights where you get surrounded and one of your party members falls it misses out on everything, and this can be especially troubling if you are under-leveled for a boss (bosses tend to be either right next to you or force you onto a ledge and then over) because you think “oh I only need a little bit more exp then I can do this” but there’s nothing left you have to reload from a save usually a few hours (minimum due to the slow pace of the game) and do everything again hoping that this time you will only to find out that you needed to load further back in your files.Personally this game I did say I liked and I’ll tell you exactly why, because Might and Magic 6 was the first great game I ever was able to play being able to play another “updated” version of the game made me excited about the future prospects, but since its release there has been no hit at another in the franchise that I am aware of so the hopes of playing another good might and magic game have been dashed.Also in the older games the voices and sound effects though primitive were clever and original, whereas here in this game everything sounds like a b-reel fantasy sound clip there The best analogy I can give to this game is imagine someone saw a beloved franchise like say Half-life, now imagine Ubisoft bought Half-life, sure we’d get a Half-life 3 and maybe more, but the game would be completely different with nearly no regard (except for names and maybe general models) for the source materials…In conclusion, Don’t waste your money go find a copy of Might and Magic 6, 7, and 8 (12$ probably total) and enjoy a good 50+ hours of classic fantasy games that are actually good.

I enjoy open world games with exploration and a variety of monsters. This game tries to appear open but is really extremely linear as any time you go the wrong way at all you die. I am sick of looking at that loading screen. Other problems include: U play account needed, extremely sub par graphics, low and inconsistant framerates, long load times, repetitve obnoxious sounds, Journal doesnt include trainer locations, default party is garbage, lack of any fast travel, no retreat from combat, poor map systemThese are all things that could be forgiven if the gameplay was great, but its not. Even if you are a fan of previous M&M titles, AVOID.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												I've played a fair amount of this now. I bought it way back in early access but I waited because I knew it would only get better and I didn't want to ruin my final experience with the game. It seems some people's experiences in early access weren't that great.I am having quite a bit of fun with it. There's a fair amount of character customization that you can do at the beginning of the game though not quite as much as  the M&M6-8 games. Mainly because you pick 1 of 4 races and each race has 3 class option. Those classes are a little bit limited in their further skill customization but there's still a fair amount of diversity to be had in terms of skill choices. You're also limited to 2 voice choices and 2 male potraits as well as 2 female portraits. At first I thought that it was a bit weak but I figured it didn't really matter what they looked or sounded like.As far as the gameplay goes I found a lot of things nostalgic. The sounds they used, the way you interact with buildings, and a few other things reminded me a lot of M&M6-8. The big difference being it's not free roam and it's on a grid but you know what, I'm fine with that. If it was free movement people would compare it to other open world games and that's not fair. It works fine that it's grid based and I didn't find it to hurt the experience at all. When you level up there's lots of customization to be had in terms of skill lines to put skill points into and stat points to distribute. There's also plenty of loot to plunder and equip even though it's kind of annoying how much +resistance gear there is. It feels like a cheap cop out way to avoid giving you a useful stat on the item. Every single green item has +resistance and you have to find a blue item to even get an item worth caring about as green items don't roll anything but +resistance which is all but pointless.Overall I would recommend this game to fans of the series and you should realize this game is a bit different than the M&M6-8 games. That doesn't mean you should avoid it though as there's a lot of fun to be had. Even people who are new to the series. If you enjoy tactical RPG type games then you should enjoy this.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												Decent Might & Magic game, nothing special, but fans of the series should enjoy it.Game is rather short & doesn't have whole lot of content, but it delivers good immersion and satisfying feeling of nostalgia :)I liked combats & skills system, and those two things are probably most important ones not to screw up in an RPG. I have low demands for graphics & music, so it's hard to dissapoint me there.All downsides for me were already summarized under "not whole lot of content". Not too many classes to select from, story plot is short, not too many cities to visit, not too many monsters to fight, not too many spells to learn, skills to train and quests to complete ... some cherished parts from earlier games are missing entirely (card game, killing traps, potion making). But what content provided, is of good quality.To summarize, game is worth playing, but probably has zero replay value, and that tells you something.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												This game pays homage to Might and Magic 1-5 and persoanlly, I like it very much. The good:* Unlike a lot of RPGs today, the combat mechanics are deep and srategic. Should you spend a turn healing and defending or should you take a chance and forgo healing this round to dish out damage with the hope of quickly ending the encounter? Decisions like these make combat satisfying. * Pretty graphics - Bright vibrant colours and nice character models. * Party based RPG that allows for a ton of customization options and increases re-play value. The bad:* Not enough content - The game is a lot of fun, but very short. The DLC addresses this nicely, but even so, the original should have been longer.* The storyline is not very memorable. I still vividly remember the story of Might and Magic 7, but despite having 244 play hours on MMX, I still can't recall the story.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												A brief summary of the below: I actually enjoy this game, and I plan to keep playing it. However, it's hard to get into, has a number of flaws, uses outdated soundbytes, and generally feels very unfinished. It doesn't feel like a betrayal to the series or anything like that, but this game is built from a lot of unrealized potential. I would not suggest this game to others unless they like the world of Ashan or want another dungeon crawler in game library. It's a solid turn-based dungeon delving game, but I wouldn't call the story I've seen impressive or the gameplay innovative.Might and Magic X is a strange beast to me. It's an enjoyable game once you get past the ghastly introduction and a fairly deadly tutorial; however, it has a rather unpolished quality about it in general. As others have mentioned, the game has more in common with the original Might and Magic games (1-5) than it does the latter end of the series (6-9), at least so far as gameplay goes. It's based on the world of Ashan, which you will know if you've played Heroes of Might and Magic 5 or 6, on a peninsula consisting of a few towns and cities in an era of rebellion and religious turmoil.First, since combat is so integral to any dungeon delving series, let's take a gander at the good side of that. Combat in Legacy is turn-based and square-based. As said above, if you're familiar with how old Might and Magic games played, or if you like Legend of Grimrock, then this will feel like familiar territory to you. The game uses this to its advantage as much as you do at times: enemies will sometimes move to flank you, doubly so if they "spawn" in a position from which it is perfect for them to do so, and opponents in dungeons typically attack from places that put your party at a severe disadvantage. This makes fights challenging, and forces you to make plans around the terrain you're fighting in if you can. Tossing enemies away from you with a gust of wind or immobilizing them before they can reach you so you can reach limit the number of melee attackers on you, or ducking around a corner so the enemy mage will have to walk into smacking distance to chuck a spell at you... This game encourages tactical thinking, and that's what turn-based gameplay is all about.Now, let's discuss the bad part of combat. First, there's the fact that a lot of enemies do seemingly appear out of thin air. Ubisoft seems to be a fan of having your opponents, even when visible, be unable to be struck until  You will encounter this problem in the very first dungeon you ever touch, in the tutorial: spiders will drop from the ceiling and initiate melee combat with you immediately, before you can react. This would not be a problem except for the fact that entering in any melee combat prevents you from moving away from your current square. Let me repeat that: melee combat stops you from going anywhere. That means if you have even a single opponent on your face, you can't pull your part back a single tile into a defensible corridor to fight your opponents a few at a time. No, you're stuck standing in the middle of a terrible position where nine enemies can surround you, listening to your idiot adventurers screaming "Sorry, I'm a little busy right now!" when you're trying to get them to move somewhere they won't die. Apparently, the heroes of Ashan were never taught the intricacies of the tactical withdrawl. It's rather aggravating, and even after you've learned to deal with this limitation, you won't learn to like it.There are a lot of other little problems I have with the combat system, such as poison lasting forever until cured (and you'll encounter a LOT of poison at level 1). They don't ruin the game, but combined these flaws make combat feel... well, flawed. A small aside: ranged combat can be fun, but in my experience you'll rarely get the chance to enjoy it due to being locked in melee combat most of the time. Your ranged damage will be negligible once your party is fighting in close quarters.As I mentioned previously, the game lacks polish. I could talk about the graphics (though I'm not really a graphics-oriented person), which are lackluster, but I'm more inclined to talk about the various, small details of the game that could use changing. For one, Ubisoft has lazily taken sound bytes from previous games in the series - very outdated soundbytes, mind you - and slapped them into Might and Magic X. Perhaps they were trying to elicit some feelings of nostalgia from those who played Might and Magic 6, 7 and 8, but all the sound bytes taken from those games just sound so very out of place and old.There are very limited voice options for your playable characters (a 'heroic' or 'cynical' voice for each race/gender combo), and several of them reuse the exact same lines. That is, the humans and dwarves say almost the exact same thing, everyone sounds like they came from the British Isles, and the characters' lines get very repetitive very quickly. (I left the first town in Act 1 as quickly as I could just to get my dwarves to stop talking about how darned boring the place was.) Non-player characters with a voice actor in the open world don't even move their mouths when speaking to you; games as old as Wizardry 8 have at least gotten THAT down.The tutorial doesn't really cover leveling up well (if at all; I can't remember if it mentions it), which is annoying because players new to the series won't know to look for the 'skills' tab and place points there, and the skills tab being a subsection of the spells tab is very obnoxious, and... Well, whoa. Like I said earlier, there's a lot of polishing up and balancing that needs to be done to the game. The user interface and the tutorial just aren't built properly.Despite this, I found the game fun; very fun. I'm going to keep playing it as I have been. However, if Ubisoft doesn't make improvements by the time the next game in the series rolls about, I'll be very disappointed, because the game could be so much better than it is right now. I like the variety in classes in the game; I like the ideas Ubisoft had in making race actually matter a little bit (as far as conversations with NPCs go at least). If you are willing to overlook this game's flaws, it will be great fun, and there's a rather rewarding experience awaiting you once you get past the nasty shell that is the game's introduction. If not, well, don't buy the game.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Might & Magic X Legacy Review 

			Views: 4,136		

			Cosmic takes a look at Might & Magic X legacy, developed by Limbic Entertainment and published by Ubisoft. Available on Steam now.		

welcome to the most recent addition to the Might & Magic series, Might & Magic X Legacy. Developed by Limbic Entertainment and published by Ubisoft, Might & Magic X legacy was released on January 23, 2014. The game is a throw back to the RPG's of old, adopting very traditional PC RPG mechanics. You start the game with the option of customizable character creation or the choice of choosing a default party of characters. Character creation is limited in terms of real personalization, you have the option of basically choosing a heroic voice or a cynical voice and that is about the depth of their personalties. My advice is to choose heroic every time as the cynical characters tend to repeat the same god damn four lines of speech every five minutes and it becomes tiresome. Other parts of character creations are good, there’s four races to choose from which span your clique elves, orcs, dwarfs and men. Each race has three unique classes to choose from, one might class, one magic class and a hybrid class.Legacy injects a lovely sense of nostalgia and really does bring you back to the series of ten plus years ago. However once that nostalgia ends what are you left with? Well a combination of good mechanics, dated mechanics and strange design choices.Lets start with movement outside of combat, I have no idea why the developers and ubisoft went for grid based movement outside of combat. Wanting a grid based combat system is one thing, out of combat grid based movement is quite another. While going for the retro feel is one thing, using dated movement that becomes boorish and frustrating is quite another. I really do feel that grid based world movement is a relic of a bygone era that does not need to resurface. The developers of the old might and magic games did not have grid based moment because they wanted too, it was a technological limitation of the time period, that limitation no longer exists so the lack of free world movement feels very contrived.The over world design itself doesn't really make sense you have a little lighthouse that nearly spans a 5 by 5 area and then a supposed huge castle that takes up the same amount of space. Places and objects in the world are not in proportion and it actually becomes immersion breaking to the point of silliness. Someone should also speak to the builders of the island as they need to be introduced to the concept of roads, how any of the citizens travel in that place is beyond me.The games graphics are confused too, you'll go from a really nice looking area, to areas riddled with poor textures, draw distance problems and outright texture load issues. I feel that Ubisoft really didn't give the game the budget it deserved and while the games graphics are in no way bad they are comparable to that of older games like elder scrolls oblivion even on its highest settings.Combat is where the game shines, the combat system is very traditional Might & Magic combat which is by no means a bad thing. I am certainly a fan of turn based combat and always have been, it is a solid mechanic that remains fun to this day. Fights are challenging and fun making you really consider each action you take to ensure your teams survival. The problem with the combat lies in smaller design choices I don't understand. Without any warning the game seems to regularly bump up the difficulty for no logical reason, for example you can clear the first two levels of a dungeon with no fuss then suddenly on the third the enemies are a lot tougher sometimes to the point of killing your entire party in one fell swoop. You can regularly run into much higher level opponents in the world that will just kill your characters in one move, which is fine in one sense but not in other. I like the fact there are enemies you cannot defeat yet, however having one of these enemies in a cave right outside of the first starting town is annoying. You cannot choose to escape from battle, so once you accidentally stumble into an area to high level for you and engage in combat, you might as well load your last save right there. Barring the few minor annoyances combat does remain fun, engaging and challenging.Levelling up again while simple suffers from strange design choices. When you level you receive attribute points to improve your base stats and skill points to improve your proficient with skills. Now any logical person would think to place tab these two menus right next too each other but no. instead you have to press the absurdly small level up button to place attribute points then close that menu to press the other small button to open the skills menu. The is a good amount of depth once in game to tailor the characters to the way you want them, there’s plenty of stats and skills to customize as is always the case in Might & Magic. The game doesn't do well in explaining skill related mechanics to players unfamiliar with the series, in fact the game has no tutorial at all and while I am a fan on games not holding your hand. It would be easy to miss that to improve skills you need to find a trainer, which by the way a spread out in an unhelpful way.The reason I love RPG's so much is due to their rich, well told characters and story. Might & Magic X Legacy's story is about as deep as a puddle in the middle of the desert, on the sun. There is no reason what so ever to care about the characters in the game, they are all as generic as any clique uninteresting fantasy characters. The back story of your characters goes as far as, your mercenaries looking for adventure, quaint. The games main story itself, is little more than a pointless excuse to visit the various dungeons with even the governor of the island basically stating that you hold no ties to the empire and thus have no reason what so ever to help them basically by saying (office space style) 'uhhh, if you could go ahead and restore all the elemental altars... that would be great.' it makes even less sense considering the empire has an army, paladins, griffon riders and a myriad of resources available to combat the threat, the reason they don't? Who knows.In all the game provides a good nostalgic feel but past that I feel disappointed. Those looking for a old school RPG will find it here. I feel that instead of trying to push the franchise forward Ubisoft have created a dated RPG experience and cashed in on the franchises name. I have to ask why this game needed to be made, yes make more Might & Magic games but don't replicate the mechanics over and over. Push forward, make better experiences, I'm not saying take out what makes Might & Magic, Might & Magic but at least bring the franchise into the modern era. Also Uplay is awful, stop putting that♥♥♥♥♥♥in your damn games Ubisoft.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												As someone who has not played any other M&M titles, I can recommend this game.I would recommend playing this on the harder difficulty. This forces you to explore everywhere in order to level up, and will greatly reward you for searching every nook and cranny.This game has one interesting niche that sets it apart from other games, everything is finite. There are no respawning monsters, no respawning loot etc. This creates a sense of meaningfulness to every choice you make, when you spend your gold or sell equipment. Because of the way the game is set up you'll often run into enemies that are far too hard for you, or bosses you can't handle yet. I consider this a positive, as it encourages you to explore the world more in order to gear up / level up.If you read other reviews pros and cons, I would agree with most of them. However , this game stands out from other turn based RPG's so much, that I can't help but recommend it. I would love to see a M&M X-2 style game, improving upon it's strengths, and adding more customizability. Pick it up on sale. I'd value it around 15-20$.

Posted: February 8, 2014
												For anyone who is a fan of the older Might and Magic games, Especially the really older ones (1-5), This game is a treat - and a blast from the past - IF you can set aside a few differences. Namely, The size/scale of the game. Don't expect a huge MM6-8 style world with hundreds of side quests - The world is much smaller and the plot is quite simple. Despite that, The loading times might annoy you and it's still a bit buggy. The skill system works a bit differently as well. But other than that..It has the spirit and feel of an MM game. I'd say it's well worth the price and Limbic should be commended for capturing NWC's spirit in this game as well. Hopefully, Next time, Ubisoft will consider a more large-scale MM game.And even if you aren't an MM fan.. This is a pretty nice RPG in today's standards, Giving well over 40-50 hours of entertaining gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												I didn't know how badly I wanted to play a game like this until I actually started playing. I realize this doesn't make much sense but it sums up my feelings on this title perfectly.. I heard some positive reviews of this game from some VG podcasters I trust (Gamers With Jobs specifically) and decided to take a chance on it. I wasn't expecting to love it but I am absolutely addicted. I am still on my first playthrough with the default party and the balance is fantastic. I always feel like I might die in any given big encounter, but I usually manage to scrape through. Lots of fun exploring, turn based combat is leisurely and exciting at the same time, and the progression is nice and smooth. The game is not afraid to kill you outright if you stumble into the wrong place, but it quietly autosaved before you took the fatal step. It's not afraid to make you trek back to town to get more supplies but you might find another cave or set of enemies while you do so.Full disclosure, I enjoyed Might and Magic 2 and 3 though I was a bit too young at the time to really grind through them all the way. I think finally, 20 years later, I am in the perfect mindset to take this on. A wonderful game, absolutely worth the price of admission, but be sure to know exactly how this game plays before diving in, and trust that instinct that says "I might like this game".

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Damn, this game gave me a headache. Should I recommend it or not? Is it, in the end, a good or a bad game?Well it is both. You're welcome. ;)In fact, MMX is a great old-school RPG, and some might hate it. If you don't like turn-based games, forget about it right away. It will appeal mostly to people who started playing computer games in the 80's and 90's. This said, this category of gamers will regret going back to another feature that was typical of the era: infinite loading times. This is, by far, the most annoying thing in this great game. You'll have to suffer long loadings every two minutes, because it makes you travel a lot, and reload saved games a lot. It is, apparently, very badly programed and suffers from huge stuttering issues on any machine. It runs "smoother" on 64-bit systems but doesn't really take advantage of huge amounts of memory as it could. Maybe it emulates floppy disks, I don't know. Let's call it a feature. Oh, and the world looks more like a maze than like an open world, making it difficult to find your way, even if you've discovered every square inch of land (or sea). If you were used to rushing from west to east in a matter of seconds in the old MM series (by tapping arrow keys madly, like Stakanov), you'll be disappointed by how long it takes to travel. It expands the world size artificially, but it works eventually.Now that's all for the bad stuff.Good things about this game? Mainly all the rest. First thing first, it is DIFFICULT. You'll spend hours trying to find the few roads/places where you're safe enough to gain some experience while avoiding dying every minute. Then you'll come back to places that were previously unaccessible to your party and kick some♥♥♥♥♥♥ Or not, and die again. And again. More often than in the old games, except maybe MM6 which was very open and very difficult too.You'll soon discover that you have to make careful choices in your skills, for every character in the party. At first, you'll also be poor as hell, which means that you'll have a hard time training your party while in the meantime healing it, buying new stuff and potions, identifying loot, etc. And then, half way from the end, you'll have not to care about money anymore since you'll have a good 100 k that will never be spent.But don't be fooled: money is one of your problems at first, but not the only one. Money will not buy you extraordinary items that can save your♥♥♥♥♥♥ It will help, but it is not the solution to all your problems. Exploration is much more rewarding than shopping, and as soon as two of your party members will be equiped with fine stuff, things will get easier. A few relics later and you'll be able to deal enough damage to cyclops. Yeeha!Then, there's magic. Remember the title, Might & Magic? Right, you'll need both. All the time. You'll need healing all the time, and above all, good warding spells. With good loot and a good spellcasting timing, you can take on almost any mob - if you're lucky. Yes, luck counts a lot. On the good side, it allows you to do critical damage. On the bad side, so it does for monsters. So you might litteraly obliterate a monster to 10% of its health, then it will do a beautiful critical strike and kill two party members in one blow. And they will not benefit from the experience gained from the fight...Now, should you reload or deal with it and visit a temple ASAP? It's all up to you. You can try again until only your party makes huge amounts of damage, or play fair. You can think hard about a specific puzzle's logic and finally understand how it works, or you can try any combination until the damn chest opens. You can take notes (real notes, on paper) or look for answers on the internet. Play fair and suffer a lot or play safe and... suffer a lot, but a bit less.This game rewards people who like exploring, and who are willing to come back to the same place they died a dozen times before just to see if now, it might be ok. And yes! It opens a new area. Now I can die again! Oh God, now I remember how loud I yelled at my computer in 1994, and why. And I also remember why I kept on playing. Damn, it's good.BUT PLEASE DO SOMETHING ABOUT THE LOADING TIMES.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												This game is a monument to shoddy, half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥game design.  It's badly programmed, horribly optimized, and it runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥on even the best computers.  The voice acting is lousy, the plot is erratic and, frankly, uninteresting.  The pacing is completely uncontrolled and the game does a terrible job of telling you where to go so you will likely frequently wander into enemies far too strong for you.  This is complemented by a battle system that makes it impossible to flee if you come into contact with an enemy you cannot defeat.  Oh, and there are a ton of annoying little bugs that Ubisoft has no solutions for, beyond "Try restarting the game."  Top it off with Uplay DRM as the cherry on the♥♥♥♥♥♥sundae.So with all of that said, why in the world am I recommending it?  Well, because despite all that garbage, I still had fun with it, and still played it to completion.  I consider myself a pretty harsh critic, so the fact that the game somehow kept me playing in spite of its innumerable faults is pretty commendable.  If you like grid-based, turn-based dungeon crawler RPGs (E.G. Legend of Grimrock, more recently, or the older Might and Magic or Eye of the Beholder games), AND you're very bored, AND the game is on sale, you may consider giving this one a try.In the absence of that perfect trifecta you may want to let this one slide, because you have to really love dungeon crawlers to stick with this one.

												Just don't... it's not worth it. The story is terrible, the ending is even worse, the game play and RPG elements are even clunkier than the old M&M games as well as less fun. The only somewhat decent thing I can say is that the game is fairly large for its price... but that really just means the pain lasts longer.If you want an old school-style grid-based dungeon crawler that was properly brought into the modern age, go play Legend of Grimrock.

number of helpful: 48 of 90 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Might & Magic X - Legacy, is a undeniable example of how a company can get a franchise wrong when rebooting it. MMX is a first person grid turn based dungeon crawler, unlike the free roaming open ended  gameplay of the previous 4 entries (that where created about a decade ago). As the 10th entry into the series, you will find the developer, and publisher Ubisoft, has decided to ignore why the games series previous and fantastic improvements (9 is the exception) by making this a turn based mess. Essentially, the game series went from what I considered the best of the FPS/RPGs (if love casting and shooting while keeping distance and strafing) to a slow paced stratedy game that is relitivly unplayable. I will state this, I can beat MM 6, 7, & 8 by using ANY team that was pre-built for me. If someone wanted to make me a team with 4 clerics, I will figure it out. The previous games where not only slightly forgiving, but the level of satisfaction when you take down massively powerful enemies with fast thinking, running and gunning, and guiding monsters made the previous games some of the greatest power trips a game has ever made me feel. Turning God mode on and cheating is boring, becoming godlike and DECIMATING MASSES OF THOSE WHO HAVE WRONGED YOU EARLIER ON IS FANTASTIC! I loved mowing down fields of enemies in the previous games while keeping a steady radius of death just steps away from me. There is nothing even close to that level of enjoyment with Might and Magic X - Legacy. Its just a slow grid grind of posturing.To put it blunt, with MMX, if you do not build a "perfect team" you won't get past the first dungeon. There feels like no character growth, because the game postures you to always be the weakling, until you hit the threshold of level/area and then it becomes stupid easy, and ultimately boring. I am fine with grid based games... for smaller devolpers. Legend of Grimrock is a great game that is cheap, about 1 gig of space, and is fast paced for a grid dungeon game. MMX is a slow paced, combat heavy, character dependent mess. With the team that Ubisoft has, I would hope for better; and rather than deliver what fans of the game series want ( I am sorry, but citing the people that only like the enteries from 1995 and back is just BS, as GOG clearly pushes 6-8 on their website because IT SELLS MORE AND HAS A BIGGER FANBASE) they just flippantly push out this game and tell us that it is how the series will be going. Someone should be fired for the decision. It takes what could have been the next entry into a fantastic series, spaghetti codes it, and makes it a boring, buggy, unplayble mess.I want to like this game, and I have tried to like this game. With the previous ones, as I said before, you do not really need a guide to do anything, you kinda just figure it out. With this entry to the series, it breaks gameplay to have to look up optimal character builds so you can beat a spider. It kills gameplay when the game is so combat driven that any choices for character creation that are whimsicle are rebuked with a re-roll. It breaks gameplay when you have to look up strategies to beat normal characters, or optimize for each dungeon. I like strategy, to a point; but there is a point where dying without learning how to overcome a scenario, unless I consult other material, takes me out of the game outright. And thats what this game feels like, is something that was overburdened with a developer who kept saying "make it more old school" well I am sorry but when they did that in the 90's we had to either figure it out or buy a guide, since then the internet has made it so that making games like this is not fun when you know that the solution is a search away. It lacks gameplay, it exhausts my graphics card for some reason (and graphically, this shouldn't be that intense of a game) and overall it just makes me want to play the previous and far supirior games. Even if you like this style of gameplay, there are better and much more satisfying games like this (Legend of Grimrock is a perfect example) that won't hurt your budget, and won't give money to a developer that obviously disregards its fanbase.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												I was set on not recommending this during my first few hours of gameplay. It didn't feel like a bad game, but also didn't feel like a good one either. After Legend of Grimrock it just felt so much more shallow and silly and ... just.. not as good.I still don't think it can compare to Legend of Grimrock, but after having put many more hours into it - it grew on me enough to give it a good review.Why is it not as good? Well, the story is not as enticing, the puzzles are less interesting, the upgrades are less exciting, too much clutter loot, and overall not as well-designed. It's designed well enough, but there are plenty of large areas that are there just to waste your time moving through them, while they actually bring no benefit to the game (no monsters to fight, no secrets to find).But despite all that the game still offers plenty of enjoyment. Combat system is turn based, so you have time to control every character without rushing.Leveling up is rewarding, it is possible to make a badass character who can take regular-enemy life bars out in 3-4 hits.There are plenty of spells to cast, weapons to use, armors to put on. There are rings, amulets, potions, buffs, debuffs.Level up system is decent, with both attribute and skill increases.Not every class/race has access to the same tiers of skills, but a lot of them have access to most skills in general, which is nice. For example a mage may not start with a dodge or crossbow skill or be able to advance to a grandmaster level of those, but he can still get to an Expert level.Towns are pretty large with many NPCs, (if you're into that. I'm not, but i appreciate the effort developers put into this.)All in all it's not an amazing game, but it still deserves a positive review because it is well made, and it is actually kind of fun (the battles anyway. i'm all about the battles.) And after you've played through Legend of Grimrock three times and unlocked all the achievements and just don't want to play it anymore but still want something like it - Might and Magic X one is an acceptable substitute.

												If you love Migth and Magic games, this is right in line for you.  What I really enjoy about Might and Magic X is that you need to really pay attention to play it well.  That might not sound good, but I was tired of games that give you a marker for every quest and tell you where exactly you ned to be.  You won't get that here.  You can shape and mold your characters into whatever you want.  The graphics are much better than the previous Might and Magic games as well, so that's a bonus.  This isn't meant to be a crazy free roam game, it's turn based for the most part with a mix of free roam.

content:
Posted: April 8
												I love it, a bit like Legend of Grimrock.While I love it however, I agree with pretty much everything said on the Zero Punctuation video about it, I suggest you watch that. Also. Look up a tutorial or something. Maybe I should make one. This game doesn't really tell you what to do... in any way shape or form... at all.Also, I've played this for near to 200 hours. But only about 30 of those was with the sound on. Music is nice, but at character creation you will notice a choice between Heroic and Cynical... Your characters make comments very bloody often."Someone forgot to take a bath." "Hope some brigands attack, crushing skulls helps orcs to sleep!" "Wait... what's that... aaaah it's nothing, hah!" I do recommend this game though. I do warn that it does however require UPlay. I have no ill will toward UPlay. But I do know that a lot of people have issues with it. You have been warned... unless you didn't read this far, then it's your own damn fault, sorry.Anyway, some starting tips.Buy a cure poison spell as soon as you save enough coins. (Shop is North West of the first town. Near the exit, past the well.)Have a designated healer. Bit of a no brainer, it does help a lot.Level high fire magic early. A dwarven Rune Priest is highly recommended, they do pretty awesome damage! There's a pretty tough earth elemental boss that's quite difficult if you aren't prepared, and Fire magic is the best way to do that.Destiny = Dexterity.When you level up, there'll be a little button next to your character portrait. Click on that to spend attributes / Skill Points. Don't be afraid to explore, but dangerous caves are what they tell you, dangerous. Come back to them later!TL:DR. I was bored, Figured I'd review a game... wait, this is too honest for a TLDR. Hope you buy it, and if you do, I hope you enjoy it!

Shopkeeper do not have enough potions to let me buff my way out with them... no fun if you need to reload all the time...

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Best CRPG released in a long time.  Has everything* I could ask for in a fantasy role playing game, namely: good character creation, party-based, interesting skills/spells to choose from, challenging combat that requires strategy, intuitive inventory system, shops that sell powerful items to save up for, a wide world to explore, lots of leveling up, and most importantly, with meaningful choices at level up regarding how to invest your skill points.  As with any good RPG, there's always more one could ask for.  There are some spells from previous M&M's that I miss (Water Walk, Fly), and I always the horseshoes.  Also, playing on Warrior mode, I'm finding my gold resources seems severely diminished since the EA.  I can't afford hardly any spells/potions/weapons.  All my gold goes towards the most crucial spells and Expert trainings.  Would rather the difficulty just relate to combat, and not less gold/higher prices (if that is the case).  And at charcter creation, I would LOVE to have a few more choices of portraits - that way you could make a party of 4 female elves that all look different, just for example. =)But all-in-all, a very fun, addictive game with great replay value.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Great old school dungeon crawler RPG. Character progression feels good, gameplay is a bit simple but I found it very satisfying. Creating a team with synergy is very satisfying. I rarely actually finnish RPGs if they take too long, but MMX had satisfying character progression up to the end.Pros:-Character progression & choices are meaningful.-Simple but satisfying combat.-Most classes feel very uinique (casters can feel samey until you get your promotion).-Good throwback to the older days.-RIDDLESCons:-Occasional bug that makes you have to load, quicksaving made that problem minor.-Building your character can be frustrating if a skill trainer is hidden or not available until late in the game.-Some encounters feel much harder than others & can be quite frustrating.Hopefully this genre of RPG will start making a comeback.

number of helpful: 87 of 168 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I was scratching my head when I was playing this. First of all, I know it is grid-based. It says it in the description and it's what the devs keep saying. But let's take a small look at the title. Might & Magic X. This is supposed to be a SEQUEL to VI, VII, VIII and IX. In other words, I expect something better that keeps innovating the genre. Why the *#$&* they went back to IV, V is beyond me. As if VI (1998) is not retro enough to duplicate. Me? I started playing the series because of VI. I loved it. I could never get myself to play I - V because it's not what I was used to. VI - IX had open worlds to explore and do quests at your own pace. Going from one side of town to the other did not take take 10 freaking minutes like it does with this game. So, the game is grid-based and I started to accept that. But even if I did, the system here is done horribly. Everything, from the controls to the animations is very ackward. You can only cast damaging spells or shoot arrows when you're enemies are in a straight line! My D&D board game allows me to shoot monsters diagonally, and that game does not even have a game engine! It's a board with some plastic figures on it and it functions better than the almighty M&MX. Graphics are terrible. Every single human being and monsters look like plastic. I can make better animations shooting Stop Motion with my Lego-sets using a iPhone 1. The levels, towns and dungeons are poorly designed. And to add insult to injury, the graphics suggest that there are things to click on. Which is impossible, because most of the objects that seem clickable are out of range. Grid-based. Great Idea. I can write an entire book about why I am disappointed with this game. It's pretty ironic that if you purchase this, you get the best Might & Magic game; Might & Magic VI: The Mandate of Heaven. I would recommend buying the older games on gog.com and leave this game alone. Wait, I forgot to say something positive about the game. The music is nice.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Pros: If you're an old-timer longing for the good old days of min-maxing stats/skills for a party (and you don't play JRPGs for various reasons), this will be the game for you. Your gameplay rewards will mostly come from seeing your carefully-planned party composition hit its stride around the mid-levels, when your bladesinger has enough stats to chunk mobs for big satisfying criticals. This game will mostly appeal to RPG fans born in the very early 80s or older, since it's a throwback to the Xeen/Terra style of gameplay. It includes all the quirks of those previous games such as tile movement, turn-based combat, random stat-increasing barrels and high-level party-oneshotting dragons in the midst of a lowly bandits and wolves. Full shameless nostalgia. Cons: It's still buggy. Your party can get stuck around teleporters, music and ambient sounds can loop forever, and some events don't trigger. Also many parts are under-developed. Armor system is underbaked (you can finish the game with your warrior wearing cloth), a couple spells are placeholders (eg liquid membrane), some classes are more fleshed out than others, tanking is near-useless, there is an overdependence on specific spells (eg Celestial Armor, Burning Determination and Whispering Secrets) which make or break your game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Old school dungeon crawler. Turn based combat. Good for a relaxing game of nostaligic party based monster bashing, leveling, and loot collecting if you are into that kind of thing. I finally made it to act 2 on my 7th try playing hardcore mode (meaning I start over on a total party kill.). It is a difficult, unforgiving game (at least on warrior mode). It won't hold your hand or give you quest arrows to follow. That is a quite refreshing change, having to explore and find things rather than mindlessly being spoon fed content.After investing several hours, I began to realize that this game is VERY hard to beat, especially if you like to play hardcore mode, and blind without knowledge of the game. It's not possible to retreat unless you use a very specific obscure party build. So to play this hardcore you almost need to be spoiled in advance. So for the record I still think it's a great game, but it can't scratch that Dead is Dead game itch without some serious tweaking for me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Ok, being a fan of the Might and Magic games, I felt completelly abandoned... MM9 was a disaster... so rushed, so bugged that sold poorly. So poorly that it was the main responsible for 3DO's demise.Then, 10 years later, they announce a new Might and Magic. Its not made by Jon Van Caneghem, and its OBVIOUSLY not made by 3DO. Still... is this the  game I've waited 10 years for? Short answer is NO. Where's our open wold? All MMs featured fully open worlds, where the only barrier iour courage to tackle stronger enemies. In MMX, you have to clear one area to be able to go to the next!Then there's my second issue with this game: where's the enemy respawn? All MMs have some form of enemy respawn, which enables you to develop your characters as much as you want! Remember the enemy lairs in Might and Magic 3-5, that if you don't destroy, the area will repopulate within a few mounths? Its GONE in here.  No respawn means that there's a cap to how much you can level in each area, and considering how linear this game is, this means that if a boss is too tough for you, you can't just go to another areas to level up some more!The developers PPROMISSED respawning enemies, and thats one of the reasons I bought the early access. Then again Ubisoft also promissed a real modular game, yet never said that we need to BUY a 1,500 dollars software to be able to create MODs for it! They also never said that 32-bit users would get a capped experience. Heck, the early access worked perfectly on 32-bit OSs. Why they changed it?On the other hand, not everything in this game is bad. The graphics (if you have a 64-bit OS) are actually decent, with some beautifull landscapes and amazingly animated enemies. The sounds are great: sound effects are realistic, the voices are actually good, and each place has some very realistic ambient sounds (birds when you are near a forest, loud people when you are in a town, etc).The gamepay is surprinsingly good. They decided to make this game very old-scool, so they opted to use tile-based movement and turn-based battles. I like this in RPGs, it gives the game a more strategic feel. Most boss battles actually requires you to THINK before acting, and if you just randomly attack, you'll die in VERY few turns. The interface, on the other hand, isn't as limited as most games of our youth. While you can still use your spellbook to select spells and abilities, now you can use a very handy numbered action bar, and activate each action with the numeric keys. Believe-me it helps. There's even the ability to set map notes, something that we would LOVE back in the day. The game isn't very long though. Its one of the shortest MMs (only MM8 feels shorter than this one), but don't expect to beat it in a few hours. We are looking at a 40+ hours journey here, more if you select the hardest mode (yeah, you have a difficulty selector in here).Anyway, this isn't as good as I was expecting. The lack of enemy respawns makes mea bit angry, and the fact that they decided to break the game into acts is ridiculous! Still, this is a 7/10 game. Really, I'm a bit disappointed at this game, and i'm a HUGE fan of World of Xeen and Isles of Terra... Still, its a worthy game to carry the Might and Magic name.Now, lets just hope the modding community can fix this game, right?The good:+Graphics are actually good, and the sounds are amazing;+The turn-based and tile-based gameplay is back, and its great!!+Gameplay is great;+The classes are varied and nice to use;+The enemy models are very detailed, and have a very smooth movement;+Great dungeons, some are actually quite big;+The enemies actually look nice.The bad:-Graphics aren't as good if you use a 32-bit OS, and the voices are GONE.-The classes are not well balanced;-The game starts out too linear, and has been divided into ACTs;-There's NO enemy respawn, not even optional like the older MMs.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												The mixed reviews put me off this game for a long while, but I finally picked it up and was pleasantly suprised. I'm a die-hard fan of Might and Magic VI, which I've gone back and played several times over the years. This installment lacks the scope of VI, but captures the spirit of it.Planning and developing your party is the main highlight, despite a few minor issues with how skills are distributed across classes. Although there are party combinations that are clearly "better" if you are optimizing, there are lots of possibilities that are doable and fun, even by just using different skill distributions amongst the same classes. You have to accept that you can't get everything you want on every character or every party, since there is an effective limit on the experience you can gain in the game. This can be frustrating, but forces you build more intelligently and make sacrifices to get the skills you want. The game itself is somewhat linear and lacking in the open-world feel of other Might and Magic games. The story isn't very deep or compelling, similar to Heroes VI. The grid movement and turn-based combat are off-putting at first, but they ultimately created interesting opportunities for tactical gameplay. Combats are often repetitive although there are some variations in tactics based on the specific enemies. After beating it on the normal difficulty, I immediately played through again with a new party on the "Warrior" difficulty, which provided a fun challenge that felt like a different game, at least in the early going. Even after beating it again, I still find myself brainstorming different party combinations I want to try.Overall, not an "amazing" game, but quite enjoyable, with good replayability. Certainly better than the average review indicates. Now I'm primed to go back and play VI again.

All MMs have some form of enemy respawn, which enables you to develop your characters as much as you want! Remember the enemy lairs in Might and Magic 3-5, that if you don't destroy, the area will repopulate within a few mounths? Its GONE in here.  No respawn means that there's a cap to how much you can level in each area, and considering how linear this game is, this means that if a boss is too tough for you, you can't just go to another areas to level up some more!The developers PPROMISSED respawning enemies, and thats one of the reasons I bought the early access. Then again Ubisoft also promissed a real modular game, yet never said that we need to BUY a 1,500 dollars software to be able to create MODs for it! They also never said that 32-bit users would get a capped experience. Heck, the early access worked perfectly on 32-bit OSs. Why they changed it?On the other hand, not everything in this game is bad. The graphics (if you have a 64-bit OS) are actually decent, with some beautifull landscapes and amazingly animated enemies. The sounds are great: sound effects are realistic, the voices are actually good, and each place has some very realistic ambient sounds (birds when you are near a forest, loud people when you are in a town, etc).The gamepay is surprinsingly good. They decided to make this game very old-scool, so they opted to use tile-based movement and turn-based battles. I like this in RPGs, it gives the game a more strategic feel. Most boss battles actually requires you to THINK before acting, and if you just randomly attack, you'll die in VERY few turns. The interface, on the other hand, isn't as limited as most games of our youth. While you can still use your spellbook to select spells and abilities, now you can use a very handy numbered action bar, and activate each action with the numeric keys. Believe-me it helps. There's even the ability to set map notes, something that we would LOVE back in the day. The game isn't very long though. Its one of the shortest MMs (only MM8 feels shorter than this one), but don't expect to beat it in a few hours. We are looking at a 40+ hours journey here, more if you select the hardest mode (yeah, you have a difficulty selector in here).Anyway, this isn't as good as I was expecting. The lack of enemy respawns makes mea bit angry, and the fact that they decided to break the game into acts is ridiculous! Still, this is a 7/10 game. Really, I'm a bit disappointed at this game, and i'm a HUGE fan of World of Xeen and Isles of Terra... Still, its a worthy game to carry the Might and Magic name.Now, lets just hope the modding community can fix this game, right?The good:+Graphics are actually good, and the sounds are amazing;+The turn-based and tile-based gameplay is back, and its great!!+Gameplay is great;+The classes are varied and nice to use;+The enemy models are very detailed, and have a very smooth movement;+Great dungeons, some are actually quite big;+The enemies actually look nice.The bad:-Graphics aren't as good if you use a 32-bit OS, and the voices are GONE.-The classes are not well balanced;-The game starts out too linear, and has been divided into ACTs;-There's NO enemy respawn, not even optional like the older MMs.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												The mixed reviews put me off this game for a long while, but I finally picked it up and was pleasantly suprised. I'm a die-hard fan of Might and Magic VI, which I've gone back and played several times over the years. This installment lacks the scope of VI, but captures the spirit of it.Planning and developing your party is the main highlight, despite a few minor issues with how skills are distributed across classes. Although there are party combinations that are clearly "better" if you are optimizing, there are lots of possibilities that are doable and fun, even by just using different skill distributions amongst the same classes. You have to accept that you can't get everything you want on every character or every party, since there is an effective limit on the experience you can gain in the game. This can be frustrating, but forces you build more intelligently and make sacrifices to get the skills you want. The game itself is somewhat linear and lacking in the open-world feel of other Might and Magic games. The story isn't very deep or compelling, similar to Heroes VI. The grid movement and turn-based combat are off-putting at first, but they ultimately created interesting opportunities for tactical gameplay. Combats are often repetitive although there are some variations in tactics based on the specific enemies. After beating it on the normal difficulty, I immediately played through again with a new party on the "Warrior" difficulty, which provided a fun challenge that felt like a different game, at least in the early going. Even after beating it again, I still find myself brainstorming different party combinations I want to try.Overall, not an "amazing" game, but quite enjoyable, with good replayability. Certainly better than the average review indicates. Now I'm primed to go back and play VI again.
