number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												I effing love turn-based RPGs. I also love any game where I can create my own party and try to make their unique skills work together into a harmonious vision. Also I love exploration. Also dungeon-crawling, especially the type that rewards searching walls and floors for traps and other dangerous things.Might and Magic X - Legacy contains all those things.Don't buy it.It's like everything I like about the genre has been taken, then subverted to make it ♥♥♥♥♥♥.There is a turn-based system, but the turn-based movement ceases to work when in combat. There is no maneuvering once enemies are in melee range. You can never take a tactical withdrawl or move to bottleneck your foes. There is no party formation, so your characters stand in a line up front. This is not Grimrock, where the people at the back of your party are mostly vulnerable to attacks from foes that have specifically flanked you. This is Might and Magic, where your unarmored mages hurl themselves in front of every stray arrow or blade they can find, as though their torso posessed by the ghost of a weapon collector.You can, however, make your own party. I meticulously used all four available races (Orc, Human, Dwarf and Elf) to make what I thought was a balanced party that would have unique skills that complemented each other. A true adventuring party, if you will. It turns out what I wanted basically didn't matter, because the level of party customization in the game is basically like paint over a piece of cardboard. There are 'classes', but they just determine how far your skills can advance, which has no bearing on the early game. They have 'advanced classes' that are unlocked at some point, but just one per class, so really it's just the inevitable progression of your class' skills. No class starts with a special ability that makes it unique. Only advanced classes get those. So your Mercenary (a might-based fighter) that's dabbling in Air Magic is -just as good at it- as the fully-specialized Freemage. Wait, you say that the Freemage is more heavily invested in the Magic attribute and is better with magic? Yeah, 8% better at the start. Hot stuff. That might increase by a whole 8% per level, too! All the while you're completely neglecting your mage's ability to stay alive by investing in Vitality or Perception, so really it's closer to 2% per level.Basically your meticulously planned party is going to be ineffective, because the game doesn't really want you to experiment with the parts of the skill system that you like. Want to invest in Warfare (a fighter's equivalent to casting spells) and have a battlefield commander? ♥♥♥♥ you. Now your fighter can't hit anything to save his life, and you need to land your Challenge attacks to draw the attention of enemies, who will then proceed to mangle your fighter that didn't invest heavily in their armor skills.Basically there are no good decisions, and that seems to be how the game likes it.Monster fighting is tiresome. The earliest quests have you dealing with spiders that poison you with their basic attacks. Poison never goes away without a (fairly expensive) antidote or specific spell that nobody can start with. So any of your characters that get poisoned by this frequent attack will inevitably go 'unconscious' without immediate medical attention. Being unconscious doesn't clear the poison. The poison is eternal. My Dwarf Defender didn't recover from poison after resting for twenty-four hours. Or ever. Not without help. So 'camping' to tend to your wounds just refills your health bars and then you watch them rapidly deteriorate from the poison that never disappeared. It takes about six 'steps' in game for people to keel over dead after getting up from their nap.What.Monsters don't get any better. Naga in the second dungeon (the first after the 'tutorial' with the spiders) dual-wield and attack twice per turn, gaining more damage if they hit with the first swing. They regularly one-hit your spellcasters and cannot be provoked into attacking anyone wearing armor without spamming 'challenge' attempts, which costs mana and rarely lands. Naga priestesses spam ice spells just as strong as the party's, but don't suffer from mana conservation. Everything crits. You guzzle mana and health potions every three rounds. I don't want to say 'unrealistic' when talking about my fantasy dungeon crawlers, but my god...I don't even...I hate to compare this game to Grimrock (which was brilliant), because it doesn't feel fair. Grimrock was a labor of love for people that love this genre. Legacy was a kick in the nuts trying to cash in on nostalgia with a low price tag and promises it doesn't deliver on. Exploring dungeons doesn't have player attentiveness rewarded by secret passages and vast loot. Instead, your characters bark out their discovery of things, waiting for you to mash your face against every nearby wall until something glows and you open a new passage with the spacebar.Riveting.Traps are mandatory. Often they just sit on a required pathway, and almost always just spawn more monsters. Usually in flanking positions. Even if you detect a trap your only choice is to mash your face into it, or, in rare circumstances, walk around the otherwise empty room.Loot is a mess of +2 to damage and +5 to some nebulous resistence stats. It's also completely random and there's no such thing as farming, so if the wrong loot drops for your party...♥♥♥♥ you. I guess you can reload, save-scumming for better loot, but is that something we really want to encourage?I've been told the game opens up, both in terms of exploration and tactics, but after my first party (which I was a fool to put on the harder of the two difficulties, which made it nearly unplayable) couldn't pass the second dungeon, I don't think I'm going to make it there. My second party has the exact same problem in the exact same dungeon, you see. On the 'much easier' difficulty.Developers and veterans will probably giggle because someone can't handle their hardcore game. Their perogative. I'm still not going to reccomend this steaming mess to anyone.Slow, unsatisfying, tiresome. Avoid it.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												I had been a massive fan of the Might & Magic franchise when I was younger, and had been disappointed by the Might & Magic 9. After hearing that they were going to try and create M&M 10 with a retro feel I was hoping that they would rekindle some of the spark that M&M 1 – M&M 8 had.Unfortunately, this had been another disappointment due to poor and confusing combat/spell systems, character development that is quite unforgiving and leaves me feeling that choice is an illusion and to get anywhere in the game you need a specific build of character.I felt the limiting of classes to race and the extremely limited choice in character appearance was unnecessary and made the options you had to build a unique character even more obvious. The story telling had been weak and had not been focused on delivering short, clear and easy to follow story line.I struggle to find any saving graces for the series, except the desire to continue the series. In conclusion I wouldn’t recommend this game to any fan of the original Might & Magic series.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												I've been a Might and Magic fan since the golden days. My personal favorite being Might and Magic 6: The Mandate of Heaven. This game is more of a take of the earlier Might and Magic games (Clouds / Darkside of Xeen). Although it pays homage to Might and Magic through gameplay, most of the familiarity ends there. That's not to say, however, that I didn't really enjoy this game.Combat is turn-based. Character customization leaves something to be desired. The classes are unbalanced and vaguely described, you won't really know what the classes are capable of until much later in the game; and by then it's too late and you'll be stuck with a couple of characters that are far less capable/effective as others, so I recommend doing some google-research on the class-combos before going all in.If you have never tried the Legend of Grimrock series, I would buy those first, as I think they offer a better tribute to the genre.It's a fun throwback to the grid-system, dungeon crawler RPG. If you can get it on sale and you're an oldschool PCRPG'er, then I would recommend this game to you.

												I didn't play the other MM games so I can't compare it to previous MM titles. Only 22 hrs in but I sat down at midnight Friday and now I HAVE to quit playing because of work tomorrow (Mon). I slept a little somewhere in there but ate my meals at the computer and only got up to pee. My point is....I was gone... totaly engrosed in this world. I guess you can say I like it. :)  To be honest, I did try it many, many moons ago, but this time I gave it a REAL fair shot and now I'm hooked.Will others like it? Dunno. I see some reviews which are bad, but all of those reviews are from peeps with little time in the game. That was me the first time. But now, ... I LOVE THIS GAME!!....and here's why:Animations         superiorTactics                great if you prepare correctly, bothersome if you try to spend valuable gold for an additional +2.....World                  interesting ... readings in lore are short ...which can be a good thing in a crpg.Fun                      it's got that "feeling" I don't know. theres a French term for it but my French is limited to Fries and toast.Atmosphere        Really fantastic...banging sounds in dungeons, many diff. birds, wind, sea.......Music                   Pretty good....its no Hans Zimmer, Thomas Bergensen, or Jeremy Soule thats for sure......Player Character Dialogs.....Sucks balls!! Irritatingly repetetive, poorly acted, and poorly scripted. I mean this part of the game is laughably bad. This part of the development team should not have gotten paid AT ALL! The good news is after somrtime in gamee you just stop listening to it.As you read these thoughts, remember despite the repetitive dialogs there is a really fun game in there.8.5/10

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												If you can get past the roughness of the visuals (texture resolutions seem to be aimed for sub 1080p monitors, gui doesn't scale so you have massive texts and buttons on big monitors, some cheap particle spell effects) you can find one enjoyable Dungeon Master -like game. Nice locations, interesting foes, pretty decent combat and character mechanics.One thing they seriously need to adjust / change is how poison works. There are way too many dungeons with poison attack enemies and getting poisoned without potions means death because resting doesn't really heal you from it and you don't have cure spells in the beginning. Antidote potions were easy to come by in the first dungeon as the enemies occasionally dropped them, but in later dungeon you have ranged poison enemies (that also cause poison with melee) and no source of anything to cure it with. A bit frustrating.edit: Apparently you can get cure poison spell with novice level earth magic, but point still stands that poison is really annoying and way too frequent effect in the beginning.I do recommend this game though! Slow first hour, but gets really nice afterwards.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I've had a good few hours with game.  No bugs so far.  Running smooth enough. I had a bit of lag at a bridge outside but no where else. Few thingts are different from the older games .  You level on the spot instead of training for exampleCombat is faster then early access from what I can tell from posts on the forum(was deemed to slow). I am playing in warrior mode; not finding it too hard so far, playing with default party..  Button mashing will just get you killed.   You have to put some thought into combat.  you can blow enemy back with one char then root it with other for example witch I found cool.You get out into open world pretty fast and no restrictions as where you can go apart from places were you need water walking etc.  Similar to earlier games.Some items have exact same name but different stats wich can be annoying slightly.Can see enemies but can't just attack em, got to get close enough to trigger battle.  I presume this is intentional.Map could be a bit better so don't have to hover over everything to see whats there; adding note didn't help still had to hover over icons.I see these as minor gripes and don't really take away from my enjoyment.I am glad I purchased game so far and would recommend if you're into the older titles and games like legend of Grimlock, Realms of Arkania remake (it is in a very playable state after many patches)I got a good feeling that I am going to enjoy this and was money well spent so far.Update:Had to strart again because enemies don't respawn and you can run out of money quite easily.In the first act I found that you can't just do quests in any order because you get wasted.  I had done all outside mobs except for w*****  and got to boss in tower.  I just can't survive long enough because I used me potions up and no way to get gold.  So I can't last it out using hp regen.  Thats the only mob left in act one plus 2 wraiths.  Can't do them either cause need something that can't afford.I still recommend game but you can quite easily make wrong choices that can basically make it game over.  Respawning enemies would give the option to grind a bit if you did not chose the skills, spells to succeed.  I get were people are coming from when they say it feels like its a bit on rails.  Hope act 2 dosen't give me same feeling.  This is in warrior mode default party.  Don't wanrt to play adventurer mode because people say too easy; can just button mash.Update: With better planning I managed to finish act 1 with no problems at all; with default party on warrior mode.  I've managed to cross the bridge.  Enjoying myself a lot more second time round.  Now I have a better idea of howto make sure I don't end up getting stuffed because I didn't get some must have spells.  I rest now instead of drinking potions during fights.

number of helpful: 21 of 40 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Review written : 28. January 2014 (5 days after release -expect some bugs to get fixed later on)will add to the review after the release of the first dlcAllrighty, first things first, for those that are curious : this game is not worth the money, it was a massive disappointment for me after spending years waiting for a new might and magic and overall it just feels like a downgraded version of legend of grimrock - the only upgrade being the price of the game - i will go into details below.Also note that you have to use Uplay to start MMX---General Stuff---Settings used : 1600x900 windowed, everything set to high- Game crashes a lot, for me it averaged around 1 crash per hour, sometimes crashing more frequently, sometimes less, depending on where you are in the game. (crashes more frequently at night)- Huge FPS drops, even bigger at nighttime or when using teleporters. MMX goes down to like 1-5 FPS and apparently tries to reload all the trees and other objects in front of you, there are tons of people with that problem in the Ubisoft forums, so it is related to the game, not computer specs (my computer can handle all new games anyways)- Annoying loading times, when loading savegames or quickloading. Can take up to 30 seconds when transitioning in and out of dungeons. (this is most fun when you are trying to navigate the optional dungeon with instant kill traps, leading to a quickload if you make a wrong move)These three points alone ruined the game for me, because it feels like trying to play skyrim on a pentium 3.But let's also take a look at some of the games "Key Features" from the store page.Open world Travel through stunning environments, choose which region you want to explore first but be careful, danger is never far off. - This is pretty misleading. Most areas are sealed off at the start and have to be opened with quest items from main quests. for example you can only access around 20% of the world before completing Act 1, around half of the areas can't be accessed before you have the swimming and teleporting abilities.Also, most of the areas accessible are "sealed off" by monsters, so if your level is too low, you can not get past them (example : cursed ruin spectres, blackguard mages before karthal), which leads to the area also being inaccessible until you made some level progress via main quest. This makes the game feel rather linear, you can only explore freely if you are nearly done with Act 3 (aka 75% of the game) but at that point you have been to most areas anyways thanks to the main quest.Various quests Discover the sinister plot happening in the Agyn Peninsula, shape its inhabitants' stories, and evolve your party thanks to fun and original quests full of Easter Eggs! - The game has a variety of quests, sure. But are they "fun and original"? Not really. About 80% of the quests are your basic stuff, "get item xy", "bring item xy to person xy", "escort person xy to location xy", "visit dungeon xy". The rest of the quests is pretty fun though, especially the more puzzle related, for example getting asked questions about various locations in the game by a guard (you have to input the answers on your own, no multiple choice) was a neat quest.20+ dungeons Experience fear and claustrophobia in the dark heart of classic dungeons, and feel vulnerable to attack from all sides while crossing open landscapes. - While this is true, they forgot to add the fact that around half of those dungeons only consist of a single room with a single monster guarding a single chest. Most of the other dungeons are pretty generic, however there are also some exceptions, like the Enigma Tower or the Tomb of Terrors that are really well made and fun.More than 60 creatures and 6 unique bosses Face cunning foes in turn-based combat and adapt your fighting skills to the mightiest creatures.- The ingame Beastiary shows that there are around 140 enemies in total in the game (i only found 130 by visiting every location in the game, so the rest is probably for the upcoming dlc) which sounds like a good amount of enemies. However, the developers counted every single variation of those enemies as a new creature. Lets take an example to make it more clear. Throughout the game you will fight a variety of Humans, of which there are also some swordsman. In the beginning you fight against Militia(1) and Elite Militia(2), afterwards against Militia Captain(3), Elite Militia Captain(4), and even later against Black Guard(5), Elite Black Guard(6), Black Guard Captain(7) and Elite Black Guard Captain(8). They all look the same and have the same abilities, only difference are the health, attack and defense stats, but the game counts them as 8 different creatures, so you can imagine how many "different" enemies you will have to face. Bosses are no exception, most of them just look like random normal enemies with a red name (Luke for example looks exactly like a Militia)MODDING KIT Create your own map and mods to express yourself, design the game you want to play and share your creative vision with the Might & Magic X – Legacy community!- Here they just forgot the most important information : to use the ModKit you have to buy Unity3D which comes at the small price of 1500$---Gameplay---The Difficulty Level of the game is extremely broken.The beginning of the game is challenging and somewhat luck based, with crits being able to oneshot mages and rangers, with you not being able to cure crowd controls reliably and with enemies dodging and blocking like there is no tomorrow.Ofcourse this also depends a lot on your party composition, but it gets easier after some level ups. In fact, if you have a healer - especially the druid - and just max out his heal (earth magic) everything becomes a piece of cake.With both of the druids healing spells healing you for absurd amounts every turn, for 4 turns, you can take on as many enemies as you want, even the final boss can't do♥♥♥♥♥♥ This is just one of the balance flaws that the game offers.Don't have a fire mage? Well ♥♥♥♥ you, this boss will paralyse you and only fire magic can cure it in the early stages of the game. Don't have a dark magician? Well ♥♥♥♥ you again, you are not gonna find secrets because only dark magic can detect those. (you can buy scrolls for that, but they only last 50 turns and are rather expensive early on) Have an archer? Well ♥♥♥♥ you as much as you want, but the bow is absolutely useless in this game, since enemies will just spawn in melee range every time. Good thing you can also skill daggers on an archer. Oh, daggers are the most broken weapon in the game, being able to dual wield them and getting 3 attacks per turn per dagger will 2 or 3 shot every boss later in the game when you have elemental daggers.tl;dr = Difficulty level and class balancing is terribleAlso Side Note : You can sometimes even accept quests a second time after doing them, yup nice bug. example : get a doctor from village a to village b, afterwards get him some reagents to fix someone up. quest done. go to his house in village a, woops suddenly he is here again, giving you the same escort mission again.---Story---The Story could not be more casual (spoiler ahead) A guy helps you when you arrive at the peninsula and later on it will go like ermahgerd, plot twist, he is a demon and the final boss of the gameThere is basically no character development, they all feel like puppets saying the same♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over again,so you will probably stop caring about the story after the first act.---Rest of the Review---Character limit has been reached, so if you want to read the rest of the review, going into detail about Atmosphere, Sound, Graphics and Gamesize follow this link to pastebin : http://pastebin.com/CL4DnM35

Posted: January 27, 2014
												Long-time fan of this series. I was skeptical of this title before it came out, but it's a satisfying continuation of M&M. Its production values aren't great and it has some problems with optimization (I hear), but the gameplay is well-thought-out and requires strategy beyond tactics like "run backward holding A" that reigned in previous titles. Definitely recommend for a fan of the genre, Might and Magic or turn based games in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Review of Might and Magic X: LegacyWhat must first be said is that this is not going to be your average run of the mill rpg, the designers of this game has made it a somewhat old-school type game, and what that means is that the game will not hold your hand and lead you through it. This can be surprising and frustrating as you sometimes wander around aimlessly, having possibly missed some small detail that means that you are now on the wrong path. Since the name of the game is indeed 'Legacy', maybe we should have come to expect this and be completely ok with it, but I think it still needs to be said that the lack of descriptions of where to go in this game can be a problem. This problem can be more or less immediately rectified however, as long as you are willing to alt tab from the game to google, which is something that I personally ended up doing multiple times, even though I would consider myself somewhat of a veteran gamer.The main plot of the game is convoluted, as it should be (follows the traditions of the older games), and there is a relatively little emphasis on story, as it should be. Most of what you do in the game is exploring, and fighting. Many npc's however have the option to spill some minor 'gossip' to the player, which is most of the time just random bits of lore of the gameworld. Scattered throughout the world is also many books, which holds a lot of lore of the world, if this is your thing.The characters your party is comprised of are created manually by the player (unless you insist on letting the computer do it for you), and they all have lots of attribute points and skills that needs to be allocated. There is a nice range of depth to the character building in this game, as the 12 classes available all have different levels of potential with different skills. The mage characters can usually level up certain magic skills to the highest level (grandmaster), but also has the potential of leveling up certain weapon skills, armor skills, and passive defense skills. This well functioning skill system works together with your attribute system to give the player quite a lot of customization options for his party. It essentially *succeeds* in making the player feel like they are the one who created this team, as opposed to having few options and feeling like you are playing a non-rpg. The games skill and attribute system is sufficient, and well expected as it follows the traditions of the older Might and Magic titles. But that doesn't mean that it is fresh, or innovative. It also isn't balanced very well. The armor skills are shown to be very lackluster once you understand the games mechanics for example.The game is entirely grid based. This is a design choice that has huge implications for gameplay, but it is an intrinsic part of the experience, and there is nothing to be done about it now. The entire game is built around this, and as such the environments of the game has the probability of looking quite odd and unrealistic, if you compare it to Skyrim for example. The world is also quite small, it would only take about 3 minutes to run through the length of the entire overworld map (once you have killed all the enemies, and opened everything). This is not because the game is small or short, but because of how compressed everything is, but this is a good thing most of the time, as otherwise there would have been an enormous amount of walking for you - that's a promise. The way the dungeons are built in this game screams 'gameplay' over 'realism', and thankfully so. Maybe it doesn't make any sense that the governor of a peninsula is living in a castle that effectively looks like a labyrinth? But it makes for fun adventuring, so I am pleased.The main focus of the game could be said to be fighting, and fighting is done in a turn based tactical manner. You get to make one action with each of your characters during your turn, such as casting spells or attacking with weapons, (but this hardly has to be said I hope). You will encounter many enemies that will give you a run for your money, and I hope you will welcome the challenge. There has been a couple of posts both on Steam and on Ubisofts forum of players complaining about not being able to progress because their party is too weak. There is the hypothetical possibility that you might gimp your characters to the point of not being able to continue. But one must understand that this is a necessity in a game if you want freedom for the player to design their own party in meaningful ways, and still pose a challenge.Finally, the game is produced by Ubisoft and requires Uplay to play, which can be a detriment, as most people don't want Uplay to clog up their computer as the millionth "gamehub service" program. Having popups that try to direct you to Youtube every time you exit the game is hardly a plus either, but that's something that Ubisoft thinks is a cool thing.Score is a whopping 85/100 for me personally. It's the perfect blend between rpg and strategy, and will probably leave you with a feeling of satisfaction if you are a min-maxing geek like myself. But you have to look past some of the things mentioned earlier in my text to get the most out of it.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												So, now that the game is in full, lets get down to the♥♥♥♥♥♥and grits of the game.  What is wrong with it? And what is right with it?  Well.. currently, I am engaging in a full playthrough.  In my first 30 minutes, I discovered that the game seems to require MUCH more system resources than it should for the type of game you are playing.  The game also seems to take several steps BACKWARDS!! in regards to the progress that has been made in the dungeon Crawler genre of games.  It makes a sort of Dated, modern take on a familiar genre that has had leaps and bounds of progress made, 10 years ago.It may get better later... but currently, it clearely shows dated mechanics that I would have expected a company like Ubisoft to invest in improving (IE full voice overs, a fully explorable world) if they actually believed in the project.Currently, SOME of the main quest givers actually speak, and the game moves in a old school (and I mean super old school) grid method which is dated even for the 90s.  The game runs poorly which is honestly unforgiveable.  And last but not least, it just seems limiting in regards to the way you make your party.  That last one is a minor gripe, but I am in a nit picky mood at the time of this review.So what does the game do right?  Well, currently it seems very balanced, and the game is full of lore if you do not mind reading.  The story ties in with a familiar world (thus far) if you have been paying attention to the previous games in the series, and even comes with several nods to those games.  It isn't a terrible game, it could have been much worse, and the game is most certainly playable.  It seems balanced (at the time of the review) and I have yet to encounter a real problem space that I simply could not finish.  I will complain though, that I have yet to discover a way to flee a combat.  Which I find to be in poor taste... there is simply no way I have found to disengage from a fight once something closes the distance etoo you.  So I would suggest to be VERY careful.  Makes you think actually, which is a good thing in a manner of speaking.  Unfortunately, some fights you will not know you can't deal with until you start the fight, so save often.is the game worth getting?  Currently, I am totally torn.  The super fan of this genre is willing to accept even a mediocre title, and invest.  The game itself is not above 30 dollars in charge, but at the same time I am torn to say that you should wait till it goes on sale before picking it up.  Why get a game from a big company, when you can get a great game from a smaller indie company... (go get legend of Grimmrock)  If you are a true blue fan of might and magic, and you want another dungeon crawl to add to your list, then by all means, the game is not unplayably bad.  But just understand, that you are supporting what seems to me, like a cash cow attempt to milk the might and magic license from your friends at Ubi-soft.If the late game is terrible, then I will add to the review, if it is good, I will also add to the review later.  Till then, I will, sort of recommend this game to folks.  Just watch my vids and see if you like what you get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Spotty textures, limited descriptions, annoying glitches... and yet something about Might and Magic X: Legacy is so very, very Awesome.Thanks to Legend of Grimrock (a game I also recommend and IMHO better than this), there has been a resurgance of grid-based dungeon crawlers. Legacy follows suit and provides hours of singleplayer entertainment that many RPG fans will likely enjoy. While anyone trying out grid-based rpgs first time should try the cheaper and more polished Grimrock first, Legacy will scratch that RPG itch whenever it comes up. If its too much for you now, save it to your wishlist for a future sale.Legacy's combat and character management is where the game really shines. Many of the toughest boss fights are challenging, unique and provide a great sense of accomplishment after bringing them down. You might find yourself reloading a save once or twice as you figure out a bosses mechanics. Even the common enemies can't be taken down with just basic attacks and rightfully punishes players who underestimate their foe. Large variety in classes and skills makes every character level up feel meaningful and potent as you mold your party into your own. You'll find yourself using nearly every skill you acquire, from minor spells like Light Orb or Fire Ward to the warfare skills of your melee classes to powerful grandmaster spells like Thunderstorm. The default party offers a great balance to different playstyles, but there are so many different class/racial combinations its worth building your own unique party, especially if you plan to only make one playthrough.Different scenery and enemies throughout the game offers much needed variety, which the Legend of Grimrock lacks. Dungeons are engaging, fun and filled with secrets; which are found with a perception check rather than the players own cunning and discovery. That said, the developers have wisely taken many of the games puzzles and placed them in "mysterious crypts" dotted around the map, rather than amongst the major quests which could serve to only slow the pacing. Even than, the crypts offer excellent items worth trying to get, but by no means necessary to complete the game. Storyline is your typical fanasty affair with an unseen villian who needs stopping, but interesting enough to provide some entertainment.Fantastic RPG specific qualities aside, you will find some pretty horrid textures within the game. Even after changing the options from the main menu (a MUST), the game was filled with some objects and characters that are something you'd expect from 2003. Most of these seem to come from the unit models brought in from Might and Magic Heroes VI, which were likely not optimized or polished for upclose inspection. On the other hand, some charecters are quite detailed. It seems that Ubisoft has tried to spend as little as possible on this title and the wide margin in texture quality shows as a result. I myself have run into a graphic glitch where most of the world area's cities and castles disappeared from view, resulting in me wasting a good 15 minutes trying to find a particular castle, until I figured out what had happened. Thankfully a simple game restart solved the problem. Judging by the forums there are other graphics glitches and some quest breaking bugs, though I haven't run into them myself.Many of the quests also lack enough description which might leave you trying to figure out what exactly your looking for. World map is also painfully simple, providing markers for only the most important cities and main dungeons, yet neglecting to identify individual sections of the map which are often given as your only clue about where to go for a certain quest. You'll also need a pen or pencil once or twice as your party seems to have none of their own for a couple critical details.Might and Magic: Legacy X is a fun addition to grid-based RPGs and I felt was worth the $25, which I luckly didn't have to spend due to the recent Ubisoft sale, though others might consider it too much at its current price. However, it is definitely worth keeping on your wishlist for an appropriate sale or price drop. Those who haven't picked up cheaper RPGs (especially Grimrock) should get those first before putting money in this new title.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												With Might & Magic 5 being the first game I ever played on an PC and with being a great fan of the series ever since, I saw the release of this title with a smile and a tear.A smile because I had hopes of a good series to be revived, a tear, because I was afraid of how it might turn out.The latest installment of the Heroes of M&M Franchise kind of depressed me, because it was "over-optimized" from my point of view. Reduction of Ressources, Conversion of towns, lack of map dwellings, obvious map patterns and the free skilltree gave me the impression of a very monotonous game, where good improvements like the bosses, an interesting story or the big maps couldn't completly save it for me.But what about Might & Magic X now?I have to admit, when I first saw the screenshots, I was scared off. Partly because of the bad impressions of HoMM mentioned earlier, partly because I saw the reused Models. It made me worry about a cheaply produced game with repitative ressources.However. I was wrong!Right now Im halfway through the game, and it really manages to bring back that positive Dungeon-Crawler-Feeling the past series excelled at. The reused models dont annoy me as much, as I like to watch the fine details on the animations up close, whereas in the far away top-down perspective of HoMM one might have missed a lot. I realize how being able to reuse so much, the developers could focus more on the other aspects of the game, like the gameworld, dungeons and such.(Besides reused ressources actualy being a very sustainable way of game development)The Difficulty "Warrior" gives me, a very well challenged game, with a precisly adjusted curve of improving enemy stacks, as well as the obligatory "come back when you feel ready" challenges on the way.The skills and abilities are well thought through, and invite you to change your tactics accordingly when fighting different constellations of enemies.Of course, it is less story/decision-driven as The Witcher or Dragon Age and more focused on battles group VS group, but thats just the good old Might&Magic Series for you. And from my point of view, it is a nice addition to the current array of RPGs.One last thing: I do not know about the stability on other systems, but it tends to crash for me. A lot. It started when I entered Act II and since then I crashed ~7 Times with one "freeze of death".Luckily a thing you can avoid if you just Quicksave often, and also many crashes seem to happen right after changing a map, after the Autosave is done. Still you gotta have the nerves for it. ;)This is a definite recommendation from me. Buy it, and experience the well done newest installment of a series, which I daresay influenced the path of many a RPG gamer.

												I really enjoyed this game.  It has improved substantially since first release.  When I tried the early access, it was very slow and almost unplayable.  But now the graphics look great and performance is very smooth.I hope there will be more of these games.  The best part is character development - there are so many ways to advance. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												As someone who only played one other game in the series, Might and Magic 8, Legacy feels to me as both a nostalgia trip and a game which tries a bit too much to be similar to previous games in the series to be its own game, but too little to be a remake.The most obvious differences between 8 and Legacy are that the former is semi-turn-based with free movement and the ability to swap out any party member except the leader, while the latter is completely turn-based with grid-based movement and your party is fixed from the start which, as far as I know, is what the series was like up to around the 6th game.The biggest disappointments in Legacy are that the game is significantly more linear than 8, and the world is significantly smaller. A large part of the enjoyment of Might and Magic, to me, was exploring new locations, seeing how quickly enemies can annihilate me, then finding ways to sneak or fly past the enemies and try to acquire the loot they are protecting. However now most enemies you encounter will be roughly as powerful as you are because new towns are unlocked only as you progress through the main quest, as opposed to them all being available from the start, the starter island notwithstanding. And if you do encounter enemies that are more powerful than you, which is either in mini-dungeons that simply have 1 very powerful monster, or, more rarely, on the world map, you may as well simply reload your most recent save, because once combat begins it is impossible to escape, save for perhaps some spell I have not yet discovered.There are also a couple of mechanics which are nearly pointless given how the game is structured, namely the fact that trainers for skills are scattered around the world and buying a ride to another city. In 8 trainers for skills could be in any of the several towns or out in the wilderness, particularly if they're the highest rank trainer, and if you looked and asked around you could generally get to the trainer no matter where he was, because even if he was in the highest-level town, you could simply get a ride there and find the trainer, despite the fact that a single step outside would spell your doom. But since you cannot move on to the next town without completing a number of quests, for balance reasons the trainers are much more cluttered. Nearly every rank 1 trainer is in the starting town, most of the rank 2 trainers are in the second town, and after exploring for about an hour I've found 3 rank 3 trainers pretty close to each other in the wilderness. As a result all that's left of a mechanic that encouraged exploration is the requirement to walk all around town until you find the right house, as well as limiting your skill progression if you haven't gotten far enough through the storyline. In a similar vein, buying a ride to another town is essentially pointless as it only takes a minute or two of walking to cover the distance on foot.I also have a few more minor complaints. There is no tavern card game, which was a great time-waster as well as an interesting way to get some artifacts, and there are barely any traps in any of the dungeons, whereas in 8 nearly half of all chests were booby-trapped and taking one wrong step could lead to ambushes, fireballs or even falling into a pit of snakes.Despite these complaints, I've enjoyed my time with the game so far. While not as much as in the game I played all those years ago, exploring is fun as is slaughtering weaker monsters and barely defeating monsters that are more powerful than you. The grid-based movement, while more restricting, also means that you can't defeat monsters that are significantly more powerful than you simply by kiting them or by flying above them while they gather underneath, vainly trying to reach you. Similarly, while the fact that your party cannot be changed after you start means you can't be as versatile with your group of adventurers, it also means you can't simply cast an invisibility spell at level 10, sneak through a cave full of high-level dragons and recruit a level 50 dragon into your party. It's a different experience to Might and Magic 8, but a fun one nonetheless.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Might and Magic Legacy goes back to the days of RPG youth putting you into a first person perspective, grid and turn based combat with puzzles, riddles, exploration, sidequests, lore and combat all aplenty.The game lasts in the ballpark of 40-50 hours and I enjoyed it the whole way through. You create your party from 4 races with 3 class options for each race, any combination is probably viable on the normal difficulty (Adventurer) however if you play on the warrior difficulty you will want to look into optimizing your party a bit. I completed the game on the warrior difficulty but started over about 10 hours in and remade the party.Combat can be difficult the whole way through the game depending on how much side quest stuff you do, I did virtually everything the game had to offer and the final fight was still a bit of a challenge. If fighting against the random number generator is not your thing this game may not be to your liking - I could have a party member go from full health and shielded to dead in 1 combat round from bad dice rolls.There are some bugs still in the game as of the time of writing this (Graphical slowdown issues at points, Had the last boss bug out during the fight on me to name a few) but they are minor and didn't detract from my opinon of the game much.All in all this is a fantastic RPG and anyone itching to explore a new world, loves turn based combat and wants to actually have to use your brain on occasion I highly recommend the game to.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Great game if you enjoy the appeal of Ye Olde' dungeon RPGs from the windows 95 era. All the fun without the hassle of floppy disks and mapping everything with a notepad and pencil. The story is great but you really have to pay attention as it can get quite confusing because there is so much to take in. Plays great and looks great, the sounds can get a bit trying at times especially the character emotes. Fairly challenging and can take quite a bit of strategy or if necessary grinding out a few levels. All in all I found it very enjoyable, but I'm a huge fan of this style of game, to the point where I still play Lands of Lore and other such titles on a DOS emulator. For me or other dungeon RPG fans I'd give it an 9/10, for the average player (especially one new to this genre) 7/10

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												A relaxing and enjoyable game.  Similar in gameplay to some of the previous Might and Magic games as well as Legend of Grimrock.  Unlike Grimrock, you may be locked to a grid, but it isn't a click-fest.  Character skills are are turn-based, and it allows more of a relaxed progression on the game.  I have a toddler and a five year old, and I appreciate a game that doesn't punish me for having to split my attention.The challenge level is good.  Some fights are easy while others are epic slug-fests you feel like you have to pull out all the stops to complete.  If you like turn-based games and/or RPGs, this one is worth a go.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Surprise, surprise, a new Might & Magic in 2014. And it's turn based. And has grid based movement. And is in first person. I had to do a double take, too, after that announcement. Although we had some Japanese games carry on the torch of such RPGs (Etrian Odyssey, Wizardry: Labyrinth of Lost Souls etc.) in recent years, they were fairly combat focused and simple.This here is the real deal. It has (light) puzzles, lore in the form of books, an expansive overworld and multiple cities with shops, NPCs and quests. Character generation and development has a lot of options and you have to make hard choices because there are a lot more skills to develop than there are skill points.The game has two difficulty modes and I played on the easier setting. I think I made the right choice as I felt the challenge was always so that I had to pay attention to enemy weaknesses and positioning but was never totally outmatched besides a few badly balanced battles. Oftentimes, in these "new old school" games, you have to go straight to a higher difficulty to get a decent challenge but this just felt right. The game loves to ambush your party from all sides with no escape possible so I think this could get frustrating in a higher difficulty quickly.The main satisfaction in these kind of games comes from getting loot, killing monsters, developing your characters and exploring new areas. I think the game absolutely delivers in these aspects, I almost never was bored in my 40 hours which it took me to beat the game with most sidequests done.The graphics are nice and adequate for the budget they probably had but the performance could be better. Loading times are fairly long, too, for 2013 mid-range game computer hardware with an SSD. I would welcome a Might & Magic XI after this successful revival of an old franchise.

Product received for free
												I have never seen the appeal in Tile Based RPG's, I tried a few of the wizardry games, but never made it passed maybe a dozen mobs in game. I got this game as part of a bundle, or promotion. I fired it up, thinking I'd get a good laugh out it, but fell completely in love.The turn based pacing is a perfect antidote to run and slash of most modern RPG's, and the difficulty of the fights had me using actual tactics. Blocking at the right time, using resistance spells, setting up crits. The story is passable enough to give you a somewhat engaging reason to complete the game outside of leveling up your party, and I had blast seeking out and finding secrets, and filling out the map.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Wow, what a game.  Haven't seen an old school RPG like this in years, and they really hit the nail on the head.  Game uses a first person grid based system similar to Legend Of Grimrock, but it is much more complex.  You choose a party of 4 adventurers, and are free to mix and match as you please.  The leveling system is well thought out and there is definitely lots of room for strategy in skill choice and combat mechanics.  Game appears to be quite long, and the difficulty on "Warrior" mode is quite challenging.  If you are a fan of classic RPG's, this game is not to be missed!  Only downside is the Ubisoft launcher, but once you are in game you will forget all about it.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Well when I did the "early access" I was thinking it was okay, but noting to get excited about. In fact I think for this game "early access" was more of a gimick then anything else. I kind of feel that the final release was going to be pretty much what they had in mind from the start, and that's not really a bad thing. It's a pretty enjoyable game over all.While it does have a vintage Might and Magic look, only updated, I wouldn't call it a faithful recreation of the old classic M&M games. I think the thing I've noticed most is that your ability to roam the game world is constricted compared to M&M games. You could pretty much go anywhere, but you'd get your @ss handed to you real quick if you strayed into too high a level area. So far with this game I've found that higher level areas are locked untill you've done the required quest/s. I think this is a developer design choice so I don't see it changing all that much as I progress.Other then that it's a pretty faithfull reproduction of the old grid and turn based combat RPG. It seems that the developers added a dash of Wizardy and AD&D to their formula and it makes for a pretty good and engrossing game. Battles can be pretty intense, but it's not a action game by any means, so If you love the more modern action RPGs you might be dissapointed. But if you've been wishing for a return to the PC RPGs of the golden age this will be right up your alley. Or if you've never played this style of RPG and wonder what the fuss about the "golden age of RPGs" is give it a spin. It's priced right for what it is and what you get, which can't always be said about a lot of the releases on the market.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												After putting 80+ hours into this game with two ongoing playthroughs I definitely recommend Might and Magic X: Legacy.  At first I was slow to succumb to its charms.  I felt the controls and immersion were a little clumsy, the voices and sound effects cheesy at best, and the visuals less than stellar.  When I got to the heart of the game, however, all of those things faded to the background and I found a lot to enjoy in the party building, monster smashing, and exploration.  I encourage newcomers to begin with an open mind and to be prepared to invest some solid time with a trial party to get acquainted with the mechanics and to learn what works well and what doesn't. Then once you have a vision and some goals it makes the challenges in front of you - and your progress - much more rewarding and motivating.I'm enjoying mysecond playthrough even more, this time using my knowledge of trainer and gear availability, what works best in combat and what doesn't, and an understanding of the pacing of the game to make a challenging party that beats the odds.  What's more, the game is deliberately set up to prevent you from trying all of the skills and classes in one go.  At first this frustrated me; now I appreciate the built-in replay.  A tip on that note: Don't try to do it all, do just a few things really well, and then try a different mix in another playthrough.

												Remember the days when RPGs didn't lead you by the nose from setpiece to setpiece? Remember when dungeons were actually dangerous and needed careful planning and tactics? And remember when skill growth actually meant something?Might & Magic X - Legacy is made in the mold of the classics. There are some modern amenities, like in-game mapping and quest notes that remind you of quest details. The graphics, while not jaw-dropping, are quite well-done. Plus there is a "retro" filter for that true 1994 experience.If you remember and loved the way CRPGs used to be, you won't be disappointed with this game.

												ConsHorribly long load times, easily 15-30 seconds for an area.  There are cases where if you want to run back to town, you will need to run through 4+ areas.  With movement and load times this can take easily five minutes.  Too make it even more annoying the loading of an area STOPS if the screen loses focus, so no alt-tabbing during a load time.This is simply too immersion breaking.   There is a good chance you will hit a point where you have to run back to town realize this could easily involve five minutes to get there and then ANOTHER five minutes to get back.  If you’re the type of person who will drop this game and forget it with the above scenario don’t buy it.ProsProbably the best combat system for a turn based RPG I’ve seen in a long time.  Melee for example you have the three styles, duel-wield, shield and two-hander each one has situations where one is better.  A monster has the ability vindictive, for every miss on him he gets one more hit, which might damages your whole party.  Duel wielding dagger wielders with 4 attacks might get you killed if they miss too often one round, while a two handers one swing mass damage won’t cause a wipe.   Conversely a monster might be able to block the first swing against him 75% of the time, making the duel wielder at worst lose one attack and the two-hander do none. The spells are just as varied and important as well with their effects frequently being more important than their damage.   Pushing a monster square away, putting a monster to sleep, reducing the number of attacks a monster gets, buffing the party, removing block attempts or armour from monsters, AoE spells, and many more effects.Although some fights do break down into a simple damage race, knowing what type of melee and spell to use and the correct order actually matters in this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												After putting 80+ hours into this game with two ongoing playthroughs I definitely recommend Might and Magic X: Legacy.  At first I was slow to succumb to its charms.  I felt the controls and immersion were a little clumsy, the voices and sound effects cheesy at best, and the visuals less than stellar.  When I got to the heart of the game, however, all of those things faded to the background and I found a lot to enjoy in the party building, monster smashing, and exploration.  I encourage newcomers to begin with an open mind and to be prepared to invest some solid time with a trial party to get acquainted with the mechanics and to learn what works well and what doesn't. Then once you have a vision and some goals it makes the challenges in front of you - and your progress - much more rewarding and motivating.I'm enjoying mysecond playthrough even more, this time using my knowledge of trainer and gear availability, what works best in combat and what doesn't, and an understanding of the pacing of the game to make a challenging party that beats the odds.  What's more, the game is deliberately set up to prevent you from trying all of the skills and classes in one go.  At first this frustrated me; now I appreciate the built-in replay.  A tip on that note: Don't try to do it all, do just a few things really well, and then try a different mix in another playthrough.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Well when I did the "early access" I was thinking it was okay, but noting to get excited about. In fact I think for this game "early access" was more of a gimick then anything else. I kind of feel that the final release was going to be pretty much what they had in mind from the start, and that's not really a bad thing. It's a pretty enjoyable game over all.While it does have a vintage Might and Magic look, only updated, I wouldn't call it a faithful recreation of the old classic M&M games. I think the thing I've noticed most is that your ability to roam the game world is constricted compared to M&M games. You could pretty much go anywhere, but you'd get your @ss handed to you real quick if you strayed into too high a level area. So far with this game I've found that higher level areas are locked untill you've done the required quest/s. I think this is a developer design choice so I don't see it changing all that much as I progress.Other then that it's a pretty faithfull reproduction of the old grid and turn based combat RPG. It seems that the developers added a dash of Wizardy and AD&D to their formula and it makes for a pretty good and engrossing game. Battles can be pretty intense, but it's not a action game by any means, so If you love the more modern action RPGs you might be dissapointed. But if you've been wishing for a return to the PC RPGs of the golden age this will be right up your alley. Or if you've never played this style of RPG and wonder what the fuss about the "golden age of RPGs" is give it a spin. It's priced right for what it is and what you get, which can't always be said about a lot of the releases on the market.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Now that it's finished I've logged in about 50 hours so far.  It's great, fully exploreable world with death around every corner.  Warrior mode is really challenging and fun.  It took a few tries to get my party right.  The world is very much like the old M&M's with a modern style. Graphics - Suprisingly good for a turn based game.  Lots of interesting terain.  Modern style with old M&M feel.  I had to do some graphics tweaking because the performance wasn't great at first.Sound - Great track and good background audio.  Lots of attention to detail.  I have a bug where sound gets weird and I have to restart the game.Gameplay - Very replayable.  Big world, lots of secrets, cool classes, tons of lore. I give it a huge thumbs up.  But I know this style game isn't for everyone, it takes patience and curiosity.  It's most fun when you take your time exploring and having late night coffee.  If you like Legend of Grimrock or old school games like M&M's, Wizardry, Anvil of Dawn, Dungeon Master you'll love this game.  They got the nastalgic feel with the modern style.  I hope this creates a rebirth of this style for the M&M series.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I've been reading some reviews on this game and they just seem silly to me, so I thought I might post one of my own.  First off, if you can't get past the Uplay don't even bother reading further.  I guess there is some issues if you have  32-bit OS as well...  I have a 64-bit OS so it isn't as issue for me.  You might want to check into that if do.  Ok, so I fell in love with Might and Magic since I played M&M II: Gates to another world on the Sega Genesis.  I've played III, IV, V and VI all through completion.  I love the series!  I've also played Heroes of M&M I-VI.  THEY ARE DIFFERENT GAMES!  I saw reviews of people complaning this is nothing like Heroes...well...yeah!  It is nothing like Duel of Champions either!  The only thing this game has in common with Heroes is story background and creatures.  Game style is completely different!  I also saw a number of people comparing this to Grimlock.  Sounds like they were expecting this to be Grimlock but with an outside world.  I wonder if this is because all the Diablo Clones out there...Anyways...  Well, this games is completely different again.  Only thing in common with Grimlock is a party of 4 and a grid movement system.  Party make up and battles are different.  There is a lot more stratagy and party balance needed here.  You can't just take for rogues and expect to shoot/kite everything.  There is no kiting.  Mobs will catch you and eat you if you're not prepared.  You will learn what kind of attacks they have and will have to plan on what you need to do to counter them to keep your team alive.   It is turn based, so you know when to expect the attack.  Your four go, then the monsters go, repeat...  You will have time to think, because you'll need it.  This game does have a lot of do and explore.  I did play the early access and am a ways into act 1 of the full release.  Things have gotten much better than early access!  So don't read too much into reviews before 01/21/2014....  The music...I don't really care about music...I play games to play them not listen to music...  The game play is fun, complex and challenging so far.    If played other M&M games (again not Heroes) then you should like this.  If you like Grimlock and are open to more strategy in fighting and with less puzzles and kiting, then you'll probably like this...    It this is a great game if you're not expecting it to be a clone of other games you've played....

content:

												A fine grid-based RPG with a reasonably open overworld, quests and even a few basic choices (spare/kill) and a lot of dungeon crawling. The turn-based combat prevents "dancing" known from realtime based blobber combat and the classes are very varied and allow many spell/skill combinations. The level progression is very satisfying, there was never a moment I felt overleveled (and a few where I had to reload and try a different path).All in all a satisfying RPG.

But at the very least, it's still the long awaited sequel to the Might and Magic series!

													So many things about Might and Magic – Legacy are just needlessly stupid. If you get poisoned  then there seems to be only two things that will cure it, the antidote potion or death. And guess what? The first portion of the game is filled with spiders that poison you repeatedly in every single fight. So, a level one spider, can poison you and do what is effectively an endless amount of damage. You can use every single health potion that you have and the poison effect never wears off. If you run out of antidote potions in the first mission then you are are just screwed as far as I can tell. 	Do you want to make a unique character? How about a tough spear wielding druid? Well, if there is no spear in the shop then you  can't attack. You can cast your one staring spell two or three times and then your mana has run out and you stand there. 	Mechanics are completely unexplained, as is leveling so are basic explanations of pretty much everything. This should be a great game that is completely ruined through sheer boneheaded decisions.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Having participated in the early-access program and completing the early stages of the game several times, and helping the developers out as they progress through the game's developerment, I can say I am so far pleased with the final product. While the game is completly tile based, it does make you think about every step you end up taking, as it uses a turn. If you have a buff, do you want to move this direction or this direction, either way it uses up a point in the spell's duration. The graphics are pretty, although it can be a little laggy even on high end machines it isn't anything to start ranting about. If you are a fan of the older type of RPG's like this, you can even set the game to "retro mode" in the options and force the older feel pixels for the game. The game is filled with all sorts of journals giving insight to the world the game is set in. I personally sat down (breaks included of going to make a sandwich or something else more important at the moment) for a little over 3 hours to find the perfect type of class combination I wanted for my party. It is very important that you choose wisely. The game encourages you to explore the areas you are in and do not strictly require you to go from point A to point B. The way I see it is, take a shot at getting it. If you get the amout of hours in gameplay that you paid for it, then its worth the purchase. Try to avoid the ones that pick at the minor flaws and give it a bad rating.

number of helpful: 14 of 27 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												For anyone who thought that MM6 and MM7 were the best games in the series, this game is a huge let down. The developers took the best part of the game series, the sandbox element, and replaced it with a linear piece of junk. There were three aspects of the game that I enjoyed, the riddles and/or puzzles, being able to gather most quest objects without having the quest active yet (it saved me a lot of running around and back-tracking), and the fallout-style epilogue for some of the completed quests, that I got after beating the game. It could have given me a little extra time to read them, but whatever.That said, those are the only three elements of the game that I enjoyed and if I had to rate the game on a scale of one to ten, I'd say it'd rate a three with their inclusion. The rest is just full of dross, I beat the game and started today on the Falcon and the Unicorn DLC. Got fed up when it just transported me to the dungeon and dumped all the stuff I had. Even if I would have gotten my things back by getting to the second level of said dungeon, the approach and how it handled the interaction does not make sense to me.Having said all of this, I can forgive a lot if there is a good story included in a game. The story given is a piece of crap. The more I think about diffent elements in it, the less it makes sense to me.It is presented in such a way as to celebrate how humans can do anything, while slandering the names of two real-life angels according to the bible, and presenting the policy of the separation of church and state as something that is needed because the angels are the corrupt element in the government. This just doesn't make sense to me in a fictional world, where as far as I know every other supernatural being is given a made up name. Why go to the trouble of offending people who believe the two named angels are real beings in the real world, and one of which is described in the book of Daniel as the Great Prince who protects the Jews? The writer could have just as easily made up another name for these mortal non-angels as they are presented in the world.There are other issues I have with the game, lots of them, but you don't need to hear general griping from me. Just suffice to say that my personal tastes find this game to be extremely lacking on several levels, despite looking forward to playing it since I heard that it was being made.Some may claim that I'm setting the bar too high, but I think it's high enough for an expectation of what to expect from a game calling itself 'Might+Magic x:Legacy' when the Wizardry series ended on an awesome note with Wizardry 8. I can play Wizardry 8 to this day and have an awesome time, but I can tell you all that I'm never touching this piece of crap again. Later! Time to play Wizardry 7, I want to see what I can do with a party starting W8 as allies of the other races...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Now that the game is in full release I feel it is appropriate to write a review for this.You probably won't like the style of game if you're impatient or expecting Might and Magic 6 or newer tyle fantasy RPG games, or a fan of when ubisoft bought out the series in 2003 and started changing it. The game is still set in a part of Ashan, iirc about 10 years after Heroes 6. That being said though, there is very little story overlap that I've seen thus far (about 30-35% in) wich was a very common thing. They do make jabs at references to the older games in the series, like when you meet the governor's daughter, she wants to see the circus (M&M 6.)The entire game is grid-based movement. Each square out of town is roughly 20-25 feet let's say. And you choose to move forward, backward, or left or right. Turning is a "Free action." After you move, any monsters in the vicinity will move. Then you move. Then they move. Combat is turn based as it was back in M&M1-5, as there's no option like there was in M&M6-9.Character development is better than in M&M1-5, worse than 6-9. You pick a race, has two benefits particular to that race. Then you pick the "might", "magic", or "hybrid" path for that race. 4 races, 12 classes. 3 classes per race. Each class has one promotion quest, i.e. crusader turns into a paladin, a blade dancer turns into a war dancer.While there is almost no relation to the previous games, as was the case with Might and Magic 9, there is a storyline in the game that I've enjoyed so far. Premise is, you're raiders. Adventurers. Call them what you will. At the end of your training, your mentor dies but tells you to bring his ashes home to Karthal. You get to the peninsula, and your adventure starts, as you free the area from all the baddies and monsters and ghosts. Pretty stereotypical of both the fantasy RPG genre as a whole, and of M&M series games. Just lacking (thus far) the sci-fi element that was throughout Might and Magic 1-8.Graphics may seem old to some people, some Pre-release folks were complaining about it. Truthfully? I'm okay with less-intensive graphics. It doesn't detract from the gameplay at all, and they were on par with the graphics present in Heroes 5 in my opinion. My rig isn't exactly new, just gave it a new video card about two years ago, (Radeon HD 6350 iirc), and everything on ultimate and the game looks wonderful. Not Crysis wonderful, but wonderful nonetheless.My recommendation? Try it out! It's a step back from the modern fantasy games out there. Something happened when 3D0 went under and this iconic series and style just about vanished overnight in 2003. This series has been going on now for 28 years and it's still good.

number of helpful: 12 of 24 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												The first major problem with this game is the U-Play requirement.  Always on DRM for the sake of DRM in addition to Steam's DRM is excessive.  Given the issues Ubisoft has had with U-Play's functionality creating points of vulnerability for Ubisofts's servers or any of thier customer's PC's, installing U-Play is the "this is secure" equivalent of downloading game DRM cracks off of random internet websites. The second major issue with this game is the complete lack of random monsters, at least in the first several hours of play.  This puts what initially looks like an open world game on rails.   The is a major issue because of the XP and leveling system.  Your heroes need to hit certain benchmarks by certain points in the game  or you will be unable to progress beyind those points.  Having a hero dead or unconcious at the end of a battle means they do not get XP and you have to reload as you do not have an opportunity to recover that lost experience.  The second major issue can be overcome with multiple playthroughs to perfect your strategies, but with the inevitable issues and crashes that U-Play will cause, this game isn't worth the extra effort necessary to deal with the DRM.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												This game is old school.  Grid based movement; turn based combat; we go/you go combat mechanics and other classic game systems like from M&M 1-5.  If your looking for top notch graphics,  a free move mode like in Skyrim, twitch based fights, and hand holding quests/fights,  you'll be sorely disapointed.But if your looking for a modernish remake of an old classic CRPG, that brings back so many memories of classic M&M/Xeen games of the past, this game will certainly give you plenty of enjoyment.But, it also has horrible, terrible optimization problems, with lag and low FPS even on the best systems, and lock-ups on 32bit systems are being reported.  So sad they released such a classic remake in such terrible shape.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I have always been a M&M loyal friend.  Even though I considered IX one of the worst of the main series, once I saw X:Legacy, I jumped on it like a kid on cake.  When I found out they went back to the original mechanics of grid-based movement, I was intrigued.  I grew up with I-V, and although I really enjoyed VI-VIII, there's something special about keeping true to the game that started it all.Now that I've covered my background story, here's my main review points for X:Legacy.  First, it's raw... as in "Early Access Beta  Test" raw.  I discovered early on that if a conversation with an NPC is a bit long in narration, it's cut off early.  I really wanted to hear more of what the Guard Captain of Sorpigal-by-the-Sea after his Quest was completed.Second, when I toured the city and found the "Training Grounds"... I expected that to be the place I would level my characters.  This has been the case for 9 games, but when I found out I can level... for FREE... on the SPOT!  I was shocked...   I really don't know if that's a good or bad thing.Third, I don't know if I am missing something, but there are certain things that seem lacking right off the bat.  The ability to ID or Repair via Skill or Spell was something I found necessary.  Yes, I do remember having to rely on a shopkeeper early on.  However, in the past, there was ONE shop. It did everything.  X:Legacy seems to bring together the worst of VI and the worst of I-V by having THREE different shops, each with their own repair and only one with the ability to ID my loot.  You mean to tell me that a Armorsmith can't ID "Armor"?  I also remember there were Robbers/Theives who ID'd traps/treasures/etc. and Sorcerers who could manage the same via spells.  Having to walk 500 blocks just for an ID isn't friendly.  Yes, this was probably my harshest of the criticisms... but as I stated before, this game is 'raw'.Next, Character Manual Creation... I liked its implementation in VI, but this new skill tree led to some ... odd circumstances.  I wound up with a 'Healer' without the ability to fight... even with his/her fists.  There used to be a standard set of things that came with a character.  Light armor/Small Weapons... A sling! of all things.  But to be completely unarmed and unable to fight except through spells? Unheard of, at least as far back as I can remember.  To top it off, for early weapons, I was not pleased to see that a simple staff REQUIRED EXPERT skill.  Since when?  No weapon in all of Cron or Terra or wherever required a minimum skill...  Class/Alignment restricted sure, but not skill.  Skills improved the basic ability of a weapon, that's how it should be.  This is my other harsh criticism thus far.Finally, everything else.  Graphically, it's ok... M&M has never been known to have particularly 'state of the art' scenery.  But what it lacked visually, it made up for in huge worlds labyrinthine worlds.  Now here's X:Legacy!  Nine sequels since the original. I'm going to use Sorpigal-by-the-Sea as my example.  It's not even a tenth of what Middlegate was (MM2) It's barely the size of Sorpigal (MM6). And it's grid based with borders that load a whole other area.  I'd almost expect the place to be Crap-My-Pants BEAUTIFUL!  Especially with the very minimal interactions with the enviroment, minimal movement options, and extraneous people/obstacles that are only there for visual goodies and serve NO purpose but to be in my way.  I haven't made it far into the so-called "Open World" but so far, it's a bit lackluster for what I'm able to see in such limited space.  Take a look at even older games as EQII or WoW or even new games like FFXIV.  Those worlds were free-roam with powerful imagery.  I'm in a grid-based static world and the imagery is just above mediocre.The Combat system is ok... a bit clunky feeling but for a turn-based set up, it's ok.  Again, graphically, it lacks quite a bit, in my opinion.  Ambushes are fun, that's for sure.  Do like them ambushes. LOL.  The auto-loot mechanic is ok.  Too subtle for my opinion though.  I miss the searching and the booby traps (MM1-2) or just the searching (MM 1-9).Sadly, I haven't fully explored the game so far... and finally earned enough gold to buy some new spells... that find traps and hidden areas.  I'm hoping those are useful.  However, since I haven't found a way to respawn monsters yet... there's a bit of a limitation in gold and thus... food/rest/mana potion options.Overall, I'd rate the game RAW out of 10!   I'll come back when the Full Game is launched and patched a few times and give an honest score. :)

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												Being an old school Might and Magic fan, I didn't know what to expect out of this game. I played through and got to the end but it took a while. Save and save often. Your party make-up in the beginning makes a BIG difference in your survivability rate. Don't make any archers, bring someone that can take a lot of dmg, bring someone that can deal lots of dmg, make sure you have a good healer and have someone that can cast pretty much all the spells. You might have to try out a few combinations before you figure out what's best. If you like the Might and Magic series, you will dig this game. The only gripe is the class customization. I was hoping for a bit more than what was offered. Pretty much have to take it or leave it kinda classes. Make a good combination of classes and you can't go wrong. This game kinda reminds me of playing the older ones with the turn-based movement. The game looks great, but be prepared for a bit of a challenge until you get some levels.
