number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2013
												IT'S MIGHT AND MAGIC ♥♥♥♥♥EEEEESS!Post-completion review:Ok so, I've been playing Might and Magic games since 1997 and finished every campaign for any and all games with M&M title that came out since then. I've completed M&M6 about 10 times and rest of the games in the series at least 3 times each.Keeping that in mind, I didn't hesitate to buy a game from the franchise, which was though to be dead, and frankly is not appealing to the younger generation of players. It is a great gamble to publish a game like this and I thank Limbic and Ubisoft (which I actually don't like very much).However, accepting the reality of this game's probability of success for modern player base and the monetary resources devoted to the game are no doubt limited, the game feels very "incomplete" in every way.As much as i can see on the internet, people ♥♥♥♥♥ about the grid based/turn based mechanics of the game. My personal problem however is not about it's mechanics but about it's setup. Game is considerably short (finished in 45 hours or so. In M&M 6 you can't even clear 3 cities and related regions/quests in that time) and game world is extremely small. Entirety of M&M X sums up to 2-3 regions in M&M 6, 7 or 8. Considering that M&M 6 had 12 regions and MASSIVE dungeons, M&M X is a huge disappointment in that regard.My second problem with the game is the linearity story. M&M games always had that freedom feeling (not like the sandbox games like TES series of course) which allowed the player to go to Dragonsand at level 1 and instantly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥by 200 dragons in range.The story itself in previous games also had a classic purpose of gathering up different factions against a common enemy, then going in solo to crash it. M&M X lacks this quest line too, as we are getting railroaded into a single minded purpose. In M&M 7 the light vs dark choice had a game changing effect, and less so in 8. M&M X doesn't have this story feature as it lacks any type of choice over the story.There are also issues with the game mechanics themselves. The class promotions are almost useless to get (which were CRITICAL to have in previous games), and the lack of honorary promotion quests breaks some of the dungeons (like if you don't have a paladin in your party, you can't complete the quest about shantiri disc). Skills are restructured and the removal of most miscelenaous skills (like lockpick, merchant, armsmaster, disarm, repair, identify item, etc.) makes the game more combat oriented than before.On the positive side of things, the setting of the game was done quite well with the "new" world of Ashan. After the failure of M&M 9 and it's poorly thought setting, M&M X used the story began with Heroes 6 quite well. Race specific classes were also a great idea and made the game replayable (for me at least)My evaluation of the game in general comes down to these:- Very short story- VERY small game world- Too linear storyline and the lack of choice- Bugs (less than I expected actually)- Poor game engine performance+ Franchise connected backstory+ Large number of classes for replayability+ 4 player party system and turn based combat+ BEING A MIGHT AND MAGIC GAME7/10PS: If the game gets a few DLCs to make it longer (like twice longer or something) and add regions like a city from Irollan, a single location from Seven Cities and a city from neighbouring Unicorn Duchy my rating would go up to 7,5-8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Might and Magic 6 and 7 were some of my favorite games when they came out. The combination of an intricate skill system and open world gameplay was addictive as hell. Fortunately this new installment in the series captures the same feeling that made those games great. In fact it even improves on many aspects. The first major difference is combat. Instead of being realtime/pausable, the combat is completely turn based. This makes battles much more about tactics then the previous might and magics. The skill system with masters and grandmasters makes a return along with class promotion quests. In fact, this game retains a lot of might and magic staples. Yes there is obelisks. Yes there are relics. Dungeons are very well done. There are secrets and hidden passages that you must find. You cant just kill all the enemies to finish the dungeons/quests. Dungeons are large and there is even one that has multiple entries and exits that span a large part of the game world. You will find yourself returning to the different dungeons just to see if you missed anything. You will solve puzzles, find clues, and even discover elemental shards. There are about 7 shards in total and each time you find one, you embark on a quest and gain a new blessing. The blessing's allow you to cross water or cut through a forest or take portals. Might and Magic X can be difficult and even frustrating at times. The magic system is such that you gain new spells when you become an expert, master, or grandmaster. You will find yourself to weak to fight certain creatures until you get these new spells. Speaking of the spell system, there are 12 different classes spanning 4 different races. Each class has its own flavor and can specialize in certain skills. Once your class gets promoted, they even get special abilities. This was a great addition to the traditional Might and Magic class system. The one downside to this game is that its not quite big enough. You can tell the developers didnt have the time or budget they needed to truly make an epic game. I believe this release was a sort of test to see how well itd do and if it does well, we can look foward to a epic Might and Magic XI. Although the game world is small, its still a fantastic game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												Over all, for the price and type of game, I'd recommend it. You just don't see a lot of games of this style being made anymore, so it's almost a matter of "beggars can't be choosers," unfortunately. That said, the game does come with a caveat emptor or two - when I played it, well after release and the first patch or two, I didn't really experience any huge problems. That said, some people do experience some game-breaking bugs, so your mileage may well vary!Tha said, it's a spot-on solid homage to the older style of party-based first-person turn-based grid-based adventury games! There's secrets, spells, NPCs and quests, puzzles aplenty, riddles to answer, quests to do, etc. etc. At this point the game seems to be pretty playable and most bugs are work-aroundable at worst, though again it may just be that I got lucky, it's hard to say!Each race has its own set of classes with their own unique promotion/promotion skill, skillsets, and so forth. The game starts out pretty smoothly and progresses nicely in terms of difficulty and character strength - I did feel my melee characters ended up a bit too strong by the end, but my magey fellow caught up right at the end-game, finally. It's really a pretty solid RPG of the style, and the only thing around since Grimrock (which isn't quite the same, anyways, though solid in its own right.)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Hello,here is my review of Might & Magic X - Legacy:first off there is no free modding kit like advertised in the shop. To use the mod kit you have to download UnityPro, after 30 days unityPro costs 1500$ once or 75$ per month to use. 32 bit users are getting screwed because they have no sound effects and are reduced to middle grafic settings. So false advertising at work in the shop. It uses Ubisoft launcher as second layer of drm, isnt it fun? Problems with your internet connection? Bad luck you will not be able to play it.The technical aspect of the game is horrible. On 32 bit system the game is incomplete, you get only middle textures, no party sounds, no monster sounds and other features are missing. The overall performance is bad. On 64 bit you get hight textures, animations and all but it does not look too good at all. That would be tolerable, roleplaying games are mostly about gameplay and not super grafic quality. But the performance is supbar compared to the grafic quality delivered. It runs really choppy and many systems. Even on the latest 780 gforce power rigs it does not run smooth so that is that. Performancewise it is a catastrophe.Gameplay: 12 classes Defender, Bladedancer, Ranger, Mecenary , Freemage, Shaman, Druid, Runepriest, Barbarian, Scout, Crusader. Unfortunately ranged classes like the ranger and scout are useless farther into the game. You have very little opportunity to fight monsters at range, in melee they do next to no damage, because the main ranged stat perception does not improve the damageoutput of melee much. The Ranger gets a point blank shot, this does not really help to improve his damage output. Magic classes are strong until the monsters get rediculous high resistance against their magic school. Most monster are resistent against a magic school or general resistent against all magic, so tough luck if your chosen magic school like fire or wind does nothing against that special pack of monsters or the boss. Magic user tend to burn your mana potion resources like mana addicts.Defender, Bladedance and Crusader perform very good, the blade dancer with daggers buffed up by crusader spells is the best damage dealer in the game by a wide margin. He is so op that it brakes the whole class system. You will struggle without a bladedancer or barbarian as damage dealer in your party. The whole class system is borked and unbalancedThe combat relies very much on luck and potion chucking, It does not feel very might and magic like in the later stages of the game. With a suboptimal(no bladedancer or two)  party you get one tough as nails fight after the other, in m&m series the game would throw many easy monsters at you to test your resource managementskills and use of aid spells, but not one hard battle after the other. The pacing is frustrating and not fun even on the easier adventurer mode. The encounterdesign is not good, it is one overly hard battle after the other, even for trash monsters. There is no respawn, the monster count is too low to succed by grinding. M&m x is the only rpg i know where i can't win through overleveling, so for me it is no rpg at all. Leveling your character through grinding, getting better equipment, farming gold, leveling skills is what makes a good rpg for me. the skill system is more might and magic like. It is very rudimental and easy. You have 4 skillpoints per level to invest in your skills, after 7 15 20 skillpoints you can upgrade to a new skilltier, expert, master, grandmaster, you will get boni for each upgrade. Some skills are more powerfull then others. So magic skills get 5% 10% 15% spell penetration and more resistance against that magic school while the infamous dagger skill gets expert 1 extra attack and plus hitrate, and on grand master 2 extra attacks and plus hitrate. Combined with dual whield skill you can get a staggering amount of 6 attacks per round, your bladedancer becomes a weapon of mass destruction. Compared to this all other skills and magic school are just a joke in terms of damageoutput. You will need some skills/spells to progress like protection against status ailments, healing spells but for raw damage dagger and dual whield is greater then none.Per levelup you get 4 attribute points you can allocate where you wish. For a seasoned rpg player it should be easy to get a deasant build. Melee 2 strength 1 perc, 1 vit, magic 1 magic, 1 vit 2 spirit in the beginning and 2 magic 1 vit 1 spirit later when you have enough manapoints (never).I think the game release was rushed, the gameplay is boring and frustrating, the encounters are onesided against the player to the extreme, you cannot grind in a rpg!, the performance is bad even for the grafics and on excellent gaming rigs, the skills, classes, monster encounters are not balanced at all. I do not recommend this game.Have a nice day

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I have always been a M&M loyal friend.  Even though I considered IX one of the worst of the main series, once I saw X:Legacy, I jumped on it like a kid on cake.  When I found out they went back to the original mechanics of grid-based movement, I was intrigued.  I grew up with I-V, and although I really enjoyed VI-VIII, there's something special about keeping true to the game that started it all.Now that I've covered my background story, here's my main review points for X:Legacy.  First, it's raw... as in "Early Access Beta  Test" raw.  I discovered early on that if a conversation with an NPC is a bit long in narration, it's cut off early.  I really wanted to hear more of what the Guard Captain of Sorpigal-by-the-Sea after his Quest was completed.Second, when I toured the city and found the "Training Grounds"... I expected that to be the place I would level my characters.  This has been the case for 9 games, but when I found out I can level... for FREE... on the SPOT!  I was shocked...   I really don't know if that's a good or bad thing.Third, I don't know if I am missing something, but there are certain things that seem lacking right off the bat.  The ability to ID or Repair via Skill or Spell was something I found necessary.  Yes, I do remember having to rely on a shopkeeper early on.  However, in the past, there was ONE shop. It did everything.  X:Legacy seems to bring together the worst of VI and the worst of I-V by having THREE different shops, each with their own repair and only one with the ability to ID my loot.  You mean to tell me that a Armorsmith can't ID "Armor"?  I also remember there were Robbers/Theives who ID'd traps/treasures/etc. and Sorcerers who could manage the same via spells.  Having to walk 500 blocks just for an ID isn't friendly.  Yes, this was probably my harshest of the criticisms... but as I stated before, this game is 'raw'.Next, Character Manual Creation... I liked its implementation in VI, but this new skill tree led to some ... odd circumstances.  I wound up with a 'Healer' without the ability to fight... even with his/her fists.  There used to be a standard set of things that came with a character.  Light armor/Small Weapons... A sling! of all things.  But to be completely unarmed and unable to fight except through spells? Unheard of, at least as far back as I can remember.  To top it off, for early weapons, I was not pleased to see that a simple staff REQUIRED EXPERT skill.  Since when?  No weapon in all of Cron or Terra or wherever required a minimum skill...  Class/Alignment restricted sure, but not skill.  Skills improved the basic ability of a weapon, that's how it should be.  This is my other harsh criticism thus far.Finally, everything else.  Graphically, it's ok... M&M has never been known to have particularly 'state of the art' scenery.  But what it lacked visually, it made up for in huge worlds labyrinthine worlds.  Now here's X:Legacy!  Nine sequels since the original. I'm going to use Sorpigal-by-the-Sea as my example.  It's not even a tenth of what Middlegate was (MM2) It's barely the size of Sorpigal (MM6). And it's grid based with borders that load a whole other area.  I'd almost expect the place to be Crap-My-Pants BEAUTIFUL!  Especially with the very minimal interactions with the enviroment, minimal movement options, and extraneous people/obstacles that are only there for visual goodies and serve NO purpose but to be in my way.  I haven't made it far into the so-called "Open World" but so far, it's a bit lackluster for what I'm able to see in such limited space.  Take a look at even older games as EQII or WoW or even new games like FFXIV.  Those worlds were free-roam with powerful imagery.  I'm in a grid-based static world and the imagery is just above mediocre.The Combat system is ok... a bit clunky feeling but for a turn-based set up, it's ok.  Again, graphically, it lacks quite a bit, in my opinion.  Ambushes are fun, that's for sure.  Do like them ambushes. LOL.  The auto-loot mechanic is ok.  Too subtle for my opinion though.  I miss the searching and the booby traps (MM1-2) or just the searching (MM 1-9).Sadly, I haven't fully explored the game so far... and finally earned enough gold to buy some new spells... that find traps and hidden areas.  I'm hoping those are useful.  However, since I haven't found a way to respawn monsters yet... there's a bit of a limitation in gold and thus... food/rest/mana potion options.Overall, I'd rate the game RAW out of 10!   I'll come back when the Full Game is launched and patched a few times and give an honest score. :)

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Hello,here is my review of Might & Magic X - Legacy:first off there is no free modding kit like advertised in the shop. To use the mod kit you have to download UnityPro, after 30 days unityPro costs 1500$ once or 75$ per month to use. 32 bit users are getting screwed because they have no sound effects and are reduced to middle grafic settings. So false advertising at work in the shop. It uses Ubisoft launcher as second layer of drm, isnt it fun? Problems with your internet connection? Bad luck you will not be able to play it.The technical aspect of the game is horrible. On 32 bit system the game is incomplete, you get only middle textures, no party sounds, no monster sounds and other features are missing. The overall performance is bad. On 64 bit you get hight textures, animations and all but it does not look too good at all. That would be tolerable, roleplaying games are mostly about gameplay and not super grafic quality. But the performance is supbar compared to the grafic quality delivered. It runs really choppy and many systems. Even on the latest 780 gforce power rigs it does not run smooth so that is that. Performancewise it is a catastrophe.Gameplay: 12 classes Defender, Bladedancer, Ranger, Mecenary , Freemage, Shaman, Druid, Runepriest, Barbarian, Scout, Crusader. Unfortunately ranged classes like the ranger and scout are useless farther into the game. You have very little opportunity to fight monsters at range, in melee they do next to no damage, because the main ranged stat perception does not improve the damageoutput of melee much. The Ranger gets a point blank shot, this does not really help to improve his damage output. Magic classes are strong until the monsters get rediculous high resistance against their magic school. Most monster are resistent against a magic school or general resistent against all magic, so tough luck if your chosen magic school like fire or wind does nothing against that special pack of monsters or the boss. Magic user tend to burn your mana potion resources like mana addicts.Defender, Bladedance and Crusader perform very good, the blade dancer with daggers buffed up by crusader spells is the best damage dealer in the game by a wide margin. He is so op that it brakes the whole class system. You will struggle without a bladedancer or barbarian as damage dealer in your party. The whole class system is borked and unbalancedThe combat relies very much on luck and potion chucking, It does not feel very might and magic like in the later stages of the game. With a suboptimal(no bladedancer or two)  party you get one tough as nails fight after the other, in m&m series the game would throw many easy monsters at you to test your resource managementskills and use of aid spells, but not one hard battle after the other. The pacing is frustrating and not fun even on the easier adventurer mode. The encounterdesign is not good, it is one overly hard battle after the other, even for trash monsters. There is no respawn, the monster count is too low to succed by grinding. M&m x is the only rpg i know where i can't win through overleveling, so for me it is no rpg at all. Leveling your character through grinding, getting better equipment, farming gold, leveling skills is what makes a good rpg for me. the skill system is more might and magic like. It is very rudimental and easy. You have 4 skillpoints per level to invest in your skills, after 7 15 20 skillpoints you can upgrade to a new skilltier, expert, master, grandmaster, you will get boni for each upgrade. Some skills are more powerfull then others. So magic skills get 5% 10% 15% spell penetration and more resistance against that magic school while the infamous dagger skill gets expert 1 extra attack and plus hitrate, and on grand master 2 extra attacks and plus hitrate. Combined with dual whield skill you can get a staggering amount of 6 attacks per round, your bladedancer becomes a weapon of mass destruction. Compared to this all other skills and magic school are just a joke in terms of damageoutput. You will need some skills/spells to progress like protection against status ailments, healing spells but for raw damage dagger and dual whield is greater then none.Per levelup you get 4 attribute points you can allocate where you wish. For a seasoned rpg player it should be easy to get a deasant build. Melee 2 strength 1 perc, 1 vit, magic 1 magic, 1 vit 2 spirit in the beginning and 2 magic 1 vit 1 spirit later when you have enough manapoints (never).I think the game release was rushed, the gameplay is boring and frustrating, the encounters are onesided against the player to the extreme, you cannot grind in a rpg!, the performance is bad even for the grafics and on excellent gaming rigs, the skills, classes, monster encounters are not balanced at all. I do not recommend this game.Have a nice day

number of helpful: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Pains me to do so but Steam's inadequate yes/no recommendation system strikes again.  I'm not entirely sure of the development of this game but I suspect Ubisoft just threw these guys permission to use the license and very little in the way of funding.  The game feels extremely low budget.  Worse than some indie games.  Even looking past superficials like the unpolished graphics and lack of voice acting (things one would assume to be better with a AAA publisher) the mechanics are overly shallow such that most people will probably burn out on the excessive content due to tedium.Melee is very basic with only one talent tree and limited attacks.  Range is pointless given the number of ambushes you face (and there's a penalty for shooting things at point blank/melee range).  The magic schools don't feel sufficiently different and mostly consist of nukes plus a couple of superfluous buff spells.  Yes, there are towns and quests and merchants and the occassional puzzle but all of it is very rudimentary.  Itemization is terrible consisting of a few hand placed relics with the rest being randomized Diablo-style crap.MMX Legacy should be more polished and deeper than Grimrock (and not merely a turn-based alternative).  It isn't.  Moreoever it is arguably worse in some aspects like level design, character progression, itemization, etc.  You're better off playing the old Bard's Tale series as the graphics are only slightly worse but the gameplay is much deeper.   But that was funded by Interplay, right?  Well... this was ostensibly funded by Ubisoft.  Apparently not.  A shame.  Had they given this the funding they put in other iteration of the M&M series this would have been a fantastic game.  In its current condition it is mediocre at best.

												Forget about the fail MM9, this is back to it's roots, back to MM6-8 goodness.With better graphics, better skill system, better artworks and very interesting classes. The turn-based movement and fights system is interesting and works very well with the game, although you might need to get used to it nowadays. The story is good and carries you over a continent, several magical places and through at least two dreams/memories.PROS:- it's Might and Magic with it's old charm and playability- classes are great, each one of them has a different skillset and you can spend hours optimising and synchronising parties to reach the best combo.- lots of items, magic and world to discover- it's funCONS:- the turn-based/step moving may not be for everyone. Also, maps tend to be quite complex and the graphics around sometimes does not really reflect where you can and can not go, which will make you look more at the minimap, than the actual screen when moving. (Yon-chall forest, looking at you!)- maps can not be scrolled. World map shows artwork without paths and local map shows only vicinity around you. What makes running to the other side of the map a bit more difficult, when trying to find things or people.- the very last level in the last dungeon, where you'll meet the Big Bad of the story and he will attack you and disappear only to come back in a while and attack you again is more annoying than difficult.TL;DR - "back to oldschool" RPG game with very well made classes, skills and character development system. The story isn't bad either and the graphics is much better than oldschool games.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Sum it up:  If you are a die-hard old school MM fan, this is something that you long for.  If you are a RPG lover, stop by and look for a decent rpg, then you need to look for other better games.I have played through the early access, and it was disappointing. I didn't make a comment because it was still beta phase. The full version has made tremendous improvments. For instance, the weapons won't break every second; you wouldn't fail to see your fingers at night due to poor lighting design. I see more barrels with more intereting content and better designed balance such as monster strength and potion pricing.However, the core problems of the early access are not addressed.First is no innovation at all. The game play and design is shockingly simplistic. You walk, see monsters, press 1144, then the monsters die. Class leveling is a straight one-way ticket. Monster fighting is the battle on who has more potions. This kind of game design maybe interesting 20 years ago. But to produce such a game at 21st century and charge people 25 dollars for it is simply not acceptable. There are some interesting puzzles, but not enough to make the game attractive.Then here comes the cheapskate strategy of reduce, recycle and reuse. Ubisoft used this strategy on heroes VI, I still bear with it. However, what is this?  The monster appearance, NPCs, music and every other thing you see basically comes from dark messiah and heroesVI. Being of the same world Ashan, I guess some repetition is fine. But this games has gone too far. The worst part is these two games are of totally different age and types. Forcing elements of these two games into one feels like a big modded rpg from some random players community like WOG. Not to mention the texture and graphic is horrible. Some people say it doesn't work with 32bit OS, but my win8 64bit seems to have the same problem as well. In one word: they shouldn't charge 25USD just for a recycled product.In conclusion, I am not against turn-based strategy games or rpg. But this game is nowhere on par with any decent modern day rpg. It is good for nostalgia. But if you are a real old school MMM fan you won't be bothered to read this review anyway. So I won't recommend to any general rpg players.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Short verdict: It is a good old school RGP improved by some of today’s standards and I would rate it 8/10Good:- Great character/skill system with many options- Highly motivating due to tough enemies and frequent level ups- Great feeling of getting stronger over time (enemies don’t level up)- Lots of different items to loot- Long playtime (at least 60 hours)- Comfortable automapMixed:- Fights can be really hard in early game (and depend on luck because of critical hit chances on crucial characters/enemies)- No group formation (but other crowd control possibilities)- No respawning enemies means no grinding possible- At a certain point (near the end) the fights get too easy and repetitive- Much backtracking- Much higher reward for quests (xp) and boss fights (loot) compared to regular fights- 2 passive companions kind of expand the party to 6 characters- Graphics are mediocre but good enough to enjoy the gameBad:- Unclear dead ends because some locations/characters/items are available but can’t be used because you don't have the needed characters in your party- Quest progress might get blocked by having no room for a needed companion- Still some bugs (huge lags while moving is the only problem that happens a lot)- You can't scroll the minimapDetails:Think of a mixture of Legend of Grimrock and Wizardry8 (there might be better comparisons but those games come to my mind).At first glance it looks like another LoG because of the tile based movement. But combat rather feels like Wizardry 8 since it is fully turn based so no moving/strafing around and wild clicking like in LoG.What is really different and could be seen as flaw is that it doesn't use any group formation. I really had to get used to this as I clearly expected to be able to place my weak characters in the back so that they won't get hit but in fact the whole group (and also a certain amount of enemies can) share 1 tile. But the game uses other features to circumvent this "flaw". Every character can easily (1 skill point) learn a skill that if he uses it for attacking lets the enemy counterattack this character the next round. So you have to use this special attack for your fighter/high defense/hitpoints characters to draw the attacks of enemies away from your mages/rangers. The problem with this is that you often face more than 1 (or 2) enemies at a time, some enemies are simply immune to that kind of taunt and strong enemies also often use group attacks that harm every member so even when using that skill the weak characters die/fall unconscious more often than your "front" warriors which really can be annoying. Falling unconscious only means losing the experience points from any enemies that are killed during that state while dead characters can only be revived with high level skills or in town. The fighting in general can be very tough. You often stumble over enemies that easily wipe your party. But this also is one of the best parts of that game - at least for me. It is highly motivating to encounter enemies you can't defeat yet but knowing that you will defeat them when you come back later. I love RPGs that handle it this way. Another thing I like is that enemies don't respawn. When you clear an area it stays cleared.Although I think that the fights are tougher than e.g. in LoG, the game is quite forgiving since you can easily quicksave/reload (not during fight though). Also it is much more convenient to play thanks to the excellent automap. The story of the game is mediocre I think and also there are no great characters that kept me engaged. But what keeps me motivated is the constant feel of reward because you level up quite often and always get attribute and skill points to distribute. Once you reach a new skill level (novice, expert, master, grand master) you need to find the correct trainer so that you can finally unlock the benefit of that skill rank. So the game always keeps you going (something e.g. Wasteland 2 lacks of). What greatly adds to the motivation is an item system comparable with diablo. So there are tons of items to find that always are a little better than the one you already own. There are green items with 1 magic attribute, blue with 2 and yellow (relics) that get up to 4 attributes but need to gain experience first. Those also don't need to be repaired - correct, items get worn over time and need to be repaired to restore their full potential. But this happens quite slowly and most of the time you found better gear already before you have to repair the old one. You can argue about if fights are rewarding enough though. You gain much more experience by completing quests and also the loot of the standard fights consists of standard (random?) items like potions or mostly useless gear. So only boss fights drop something special but most stuff can be found in chests (which are often hidden though).Secrets are also discussworthy. You don't have to search every wall for that special mark you have to click like in LoG but instead you either need to cast a spell that wears off after 50+ turns (depends on magic skill) and marks secrets or you need the correct companion to find secrets. Companions are also a neat idea. You can have up to 2 join and they give some special bonus to the party like better prices at the merchant or a healing now and then. Most of them need to be paid though and some quests let you have join one. There is one annoying problem with the companions. There are some that join for quests and you can't remove them from your party until the quest is solved. Also there is a horse as companion that doubles your inventory which is very important - at least for hoarders like me. To be honest you don't need it and will have enough gold to buy anything by the mid of the game anyway... But I ended up having the horse and a quest guy that needed to go to a special place I could not yet reach and the result was that I was blocked in the main quest until I got rid of lots of stuff and my horse to be able to continue.So back to the secrets: Once you found a secret you still have to decide which character of your group wants to try to "use" it. Different secrets make different checks for might, magic or perception (I think). You can either learn the different signs or just reload if it didn't work (the char will fall unconscious if he fails). The same can be sad about the barrels that can be found everywhere. They contain a liquid with different colors and every colour stands for a stat that increases permanently when drinking the liquid. So it is the basic functionality of permanent +1 to some stat that you know from other modern RPGs where you have to collect flowers or similar stuff and this also adds some motivation.I didn't mention the biggest flaw in my eyes yet: You will stumble across certain quest items/characters/locations that won't do anything because they are only available for certain characters and you can't have all of them in your party. That is some really bad design here because you end up confused and don't know if you are missing something or if it is just not possible to do something. I ended up checking forums whenever I was uncertain if I am blind...Also I should mention that large parts of the map are blocked as long as you didn't get certain "skills" that let you pass through. I think that mechanic is ok, it only causes much backtracking to locations you couldn't visit earlier. It is only really annoying when such a block is deep within a dungeon. You can mark such spots on the worldmap so at least they are easy to find later (the map can become clustered with notes though).So in the end I had a mixed experience. Most hours were great fun and I couldn't stop. Some were quite annoying and in the end I didn't finish the game because it was too easy and I already got most of the rewards/unlocks/max skills I was playing for.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I think M&M X was somewhat entertaining. A decent game, I guess, but then again I'm super easily entertained. I also wouldn't buy this for 25 dollars. Here's why:A big portion of the game time is spent walking around, searching for the right trainers to unlock your skills or running around in repetitive mazes and teleport puzzles. Or trying to find some quest location on the game map. It feels like an unnecessary method for increasing play time.My game crashed every now and then. The graphics glitched and sometimes even the battle music got stuck in a loop, so I had to listen to it even though there were no monsters around. Apparently some of the quests have been buggy. I had to go and fetch a particular quest item twice, because the game wants you to do certain things in a certain order.The combat system was a bit unbalanced. There's a set number of monsters in the game, so you can't just kill monsters to grind XP and to learn new tricks. First half of the game I kept getting instakilled and the second half I was always several levels ahead of the monsters I encountered. Even the boss fights posed no threat, which was pretty boring.The story is just an excuse for a bunch of fetch quests. It failed to make me feel even a least bit involved.Overall the game is okay, but it's nothing to write home about. There just isn't anything special about it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												I'm going to slog through this game anyway out of dedication to the series, but honestly... it's pretty bad. If you've ever played any of the original Might & Magic games and were excited to play the much-hyped revamp... well, that's too bad, because there isn't really anything they have in common with them aside from some loose superficiality.Character creation:There really isn't any. This may seem surprising at the outset -- after all, hasn't this kind of always been a hallmark of the entire series? Tweak your character and your party (because, hey, who wants the default party, right?) and test your theories to see if it's survivable. Sometimes you may not even find out until halfway through the game. Balance your party with early, mid, and late-game classes, and grind your way up to success, right?Well.. no. There are four races, and each race has three classes (a 'might' class, a 'magic' class, and a hybrid class). Each one gets one or two special abilities once they're promoted (like MM6), and also like MM6, you have to receive 'training' to go from novice to expert to master to grandmaster in your skills. Like MM6, these trainers are also spread all throughout the world, and you have to learn where they are (or read a spoiler). Your class choice feels almost entirely flavourless, and pretty much only determines what skills you can raise to what caps (and at times, what skills you can even learn at all). Also, you only get four party members.Control and feel:The game is on a grid, like Xeen-style era of Might & Magic, and things only move when you do. Monsters don't patrol, however, and unless they 'see' you, they won't go anywhere. When they do see you, the 'danger' light turns hostile, and they will proceed to chase you... forever. You cannot outrun monsters or get them to some kind of 'tether' range, so if you step into the wrong area, your only option is to reload the game. There is no fleeing.NPCs are also like the Xeen era of M&M, in the sense that they appear to only be found in towns (or in map objects on the main map), and do not move. They CAN be found standing around in the game world in towns, but do not actually move. The ones that you can't talk to (which is most of them) do, however, tend to say one of possibly four or five quipped lines, which will replay, endlessly, every time you are standing near them. This is also true of 'environment' sound effects like mumbling, people shuffling things, hammers on anvils, etc. It is generally one sound that loops forever until you step away.UI:The UI is pretty minimal, which is OK. There is an 'action bar', akin to the one on most MMOs, with 10 slots that you can set for each of your 4 party members. Frequently, however (particularly on a mage), you will have to go to your skill book and manually cast from there, as it's simply not feasable to have everything you need on the bar. Not a big deal; it's split up intelligently.There is a minimap, which autorecords your progress on a gridded map. Unfortunately, however, you can not scroll this map even when you make it larger, so if you're looking for somewhere that's off the side of the enlarged map, too bad.Gameplay:There aren't terribly many spells per spell 'level' per school, but there are a lot of schools, which means there's still a hefty amount of spells. Unlike previous games in the series, there are not 'master' or 'grandmaster' schools of each element, there are simply libraries in each town that have all the spells and you pick from there.Weapons and armour can break (this appears to be random chance -- I had a new item I just picked up break in a second combat, and a weapon I used the entire game until then -- 17 hours in -- never break), which degrades their stats until you go to town to repair it. There is no 'mobile repair' that I've encountered yet, though perhaps there is a spell for it that I'm unaware of.Like previous Might and Magic games, you can have two 'hirelings' (sometimes one or both may be a mandatory 'quest' hireling), but these hirelings do not participate in combat as they did in the later versions -- they are back to simply providing an auxiliary benefit for a small percentage cut of your gold and a hiring fee.There is no grinding, not because grinding is not necessary, but because monsters do not respawn. Ever. If you have killed a monster, it is permanently gone. This means that there is a *fixed* finite level of gold and loot in the game, and even things like the "well, it'll respawn in a few months" option in previous iterations of the series is gone.There is no party formation -- each spot in the party lineup is equal, and it doesn't matter if you get flanked or attacked from behind. Everything does the same damage with the same random odds of it hitting someone as anything else.Like some later M&M games, you get food (called 'supplies' in this one) to camp, and can only camp so many times before having to resupply. Camping cannot be interrupted.Areas are 'gated' by progress -- did you put points into 'shield' to get it to expert level (the first tier past the starting one) so you can have that extra edge on the boss you're fighting in the beginning? Well, too bad, because that's in the second town, and you can't get there no matter what because some NPC is standing around saying the bridge is off limits, or the gates are shut, or what-have-you. Everything is limited in this fashion -- you may be given a region to explore in that's open (and consequently, may have monsters too hard for you -- which, again, you can't run from, you simply have to reload), but anything outside of that region is always gated. Don't know what trainers are available in the area and don't want to read spoilers? Sucks to be you, because if you opted to put things into your skills and got to a skill tier that's in the next 'zone', you don't get to use it.You have one single inventory, and it's on a grid that does not get larger. Later you will find yourself needing to stop your dungeon delve to go back to town to sell everything, which is mildly obnoxious. I don't yet know if the Lloyd's Beacon spells have made it into this game, however, because...Faithfulness to source material:None. This isn't Might & Magic, this is Heroes of Might and Magic: the RPG, which is a *distinctly different game*. The original Might & Magic games were a kind of silly but fun hybrid of extreme sci-fi with high fantasy. There were spaceships and computers and people and races from other planets, and later your samurai would be dodging ray guns from robots. There is and will be none of that here (one early NPC, in fact, says he was exiled because he thought that stars might be other planets), because this is all set in Ashan, the world from the Heroes of Might and Magic games. This is actually *incredibly irritating*, much moreso than I thought it would be or than it sounds on the surface, but I think it has something to do with the fact that this was touted as a long-awaited return of a game for the fans, and then (presumably Ubisoft) proceeded to crap all over everything that would've actually done that.Conclusion:The game basically feels like Grimrock, except there aren't any secrets you can spy (you just cast the detect secrets spell, and if you don't have it up, the secrets don't show up, period) and the plot is less interesting. Yes, the plot is *less interesting* than "yo we put you doods in a hole gl hf." I've dutifully been reading everything that I've come across, including all the lore books, and I really just don't care at all about it. It's extremely low-tier regional politics (that will, I'm sure, eventually involve demons or angels or both), and I'm 20 hours in (the amount of time sunk being telling, given that everything is gated and linear). I'm really not happy with it. The entire game plays like a demo game that's a lead-in for user content. Sad.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Final verdict: Great game, but not a Might and Magic game at all.PROSYes they had some M&M lore and a really nice NWC type dungeon in the DLC.The music was good but not M&M greatThe graphic were spectacular for a grid based RPGThe voice acting was great and your avatars side comments were often excellent although they needed more (in particular, the male orc voice actor was spectacular)The city sounds were also great but there were far too few and  and you had the same ones in all the cites and it was totally ridiculous to have Georgian chants coming out of a Orc healing center (chapel)And finally the game story was surprisingly coherent and had far deeper elements than a typical Might and Magic game.And there were bunch of puzzles. Most were fair, but they did have a couple really bad ones. There are riddle chests and puzzle dungeons ( fortunatly no monsters to battle in there)Hireable NPC was handled better in this verionsCONSCharacter upgrades are pre defined A battle simulator (just like Lords of Xulima)I think the developers wanted a cap on levels (prior M&M didnt give a lick about this)Some battle last well over 20 minutesNo retreating from battles (either win it or reload)No honorary promotions (although you can do the missions)No experience points for avatars disabled at battles end Many times the battle music would not stop after battles end (long time unfixed bug-you have to save and reload)Audio did not work on my rig until i plugged in some headphoneSpell book sucked. Good spells but too many of the mage schools had little or no offensive capabilities spells.Still, it was a good game to play and I would recommend it. But only as a good game, not as a Might and Magic sequel.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												I'm going to slog through this game anyway out of dedication to the series, but honestly... it's pretty bad. If you've ever played any of the original Might & Magic games and were excited to play the much-hyped revamp... well, that's too bad, because there isn't really anything they have in common with them aside from some loose superficiality.Character creation:There really isn't any. This may seem surprising at the outset -- after all, hasn't this kind of always been a hallmark of the entire series? Tweak your character and your party (because, hey, who wants the default party, right?) and test your theories to see if it's survivable. Sometimes you may not even find out until halfway through the game. Balance your party with early, mid, and late-game classes, and grind your way up to success, right?Well.. no. There are four races, and each race has three classes (a 'might' class, a 'magic' class, and a hybrid class). Each one gets one or two special abilities once they're promoted (like MM6), and also like MM6, you have to receive 'training' to go from novice to expert to master to grandmaster in your skills. Like MM6, these trainers are also spread all throughout the world, and you have to learn where they are (or read a spoiler). Your class choice feels almost entirely flavourless, and pretty much only determines what skills you can raise to what caps (and at times, what skills you can even learn at all). Also, you only get four party members.Control and feel:The game is on a grid, like Xeen-style era of Might & Magic, and things only move when you do. Monsters don't patrol, however, and unless they 'see' you, they won't go anywhere. When they do see you, the 'danger' light turns hostile, and they will proceed to chase you... forever. You cannot outrun monsters or get them to some kind of 'tether' range, so if you step into the wrong area, your only option is to reload the game. There is no fleeing.NPCs are also like the Xeen era of M&M, in the sense that they appear to only be found in towns (or in map objects on the main map), and do not move. They CAN be found standing around in the game world in towns, but do not actually move. The ones that you can't talk to (which is most of them) do, however, tend to say one of possibly four or five quipped lines, which will replay, endlessly, every time you are standing near them. This is also true of 'environment' sound effects like mumbling, people shuffling things, hammers on anvils, etc. It is generally one sound that loops forever until you step away.UI:The UI is pretty minimal, which is OK. There is an 'action bar', akin to the one on most MMOs, with 10 slots that you can set for each of your 4 party members. Frequently, however (particularly on a mage), you will have to go to your skill book and manually cast from there, as it's simply not feasable to have everything you need on the bar. Not a big deal; it's split up intelligently.There is a minimap, which autorecords your progress on a gridded map. Unfortunately, however, you can not scroll this map even when you make it larger, so if you're looking for somewhere that's off the side of the enlarged map, too bad.Gameplay:There aren't terribly many spells per spell 'level' per school, but there are a lot of schools, which means there's still a hefty amount of spells. Unlike previous games in the series, there are not 'master' or 'grandmaster' schools of each element, there are simply libraries in each town that have all the spells and you pick from there.Weapons and armour can break (this appears to be random chance -- I had a new item I just picked up break in a second combat, and a weapon I used the entire game until then -- 17 hours in -- never break), which degrades their stats until you go to town to repair it. There is no 'mobile repair' that I've encountered yet, though perhaps there is a spell for it that I'm unaware of.Like previous Might and Magic games, you can have two 'hirelings' (sometimes one or both may be a mandatory 'quest' hireling), but these hirelings do not participate in combat as they did in the later versions -- they are back to simply providing an auxiliary benefit for a small percentage cut of your gold and a hiring fee.There is no grinding, not because grinding is not necessary, but because monsters do not respawn. Ever. If you have killed a monster, it is permanently gone. This means that there is a *fixed* finite level of gold and loot in the game, and even things like the "well, it'll respawn in a few months" option in previous iterations of the series is gone.There is no party formation -- each spot in the party lineup is equal, and it doesn't matter if you get flanked or attacked from behind. Everything does the same damage with the same random odds of it hitting someone as anything else.Like some later M&M games, you get food (called 'supplies' in this one) to camp, and can only camp so many times before having to resupply. Camping cannot be interrupted.Areas are 'gated' by progress -- did you put points into 'shield' to get it to expert level (the first tier past the starting one) so you can have that extra edge on the boss you're fighting in the beginning? Well, too bad, because that's in the second town, and you can't get there no matter what because some NPC is standing around saying the bridge is off limits, or the gates are shut, or what-have-you. Everything is limited in this fashion -- you may be given a region to explore in that's open (and consequently, may have monsters too hard for you -- which, again, you can't run from, you simply have to reload), but anything outside of that region is always gated. Don't know what trainers are available in the area and don't want to read spoilers? Sucks to be you, because if you opted to put things into your skills and got to a skill tier that's in the next 'zone', you don't get to use it.You have one single inventory, and it's on a grid that does not get larger. Later you will find yourself needing to stop your dungeon delve to go back to town to sell everything, which is mildly obnoxious. I don't yet know if the Lloyd's Beacon spells have made it into this game, however, because...Faithfulness to source material:None. This isn't Might & Magic, this is Heroes of Might and Magic: the RPG, which is a *distinctly different game*. The original Might & Magic games were a kind of silly but fun hybrid of extreme sci-fi with high fantasy. There were spaceships and computers and people and races from other planets, and later your samurai would be dodging ray guns from robots. There is and will be none of that here (one early NPC, in fact, says he was exiled because he thought that stars might be other planets), because this is all set in Ashan, the world from the Heroes of Might and Magic games. This is actually *incredibly irritating*, much moreso than I thought it would be or than it sounds on the surface, but I think it has something to do with the fact that this was touted as a long-awaited return of a game for the fans, and then (presumably Ubisoft) proceeded to crap all over everything that would've actually done that.Conclusion:The game basically feels like Grimrock, except there aren't any secrets you can spy (you just cast the detect secrets spell, and if you don't have it up, the secrets don't show up, period) and the plot is less interesting. Yes, the plot is *less interesting* than "yo we put you doods in a hole gl hf." I've dutifully been reading everything that I've come across, including all the lore books, and I really just don't care at all about it. It's extremely low-tier regional politics (that will, I'm sure, eventually involve demons or angels or both), and I'm 20 hours in (the amount of time sunk being telling, given that everything is gated and linear). I'm really not happy with it. The entire game plays like a demo game that's a lead-in for user content. Sad.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												I did like some of the ideas in this game.  I found the combat good and engaging.  But I found the story-line kinda meh, as well as the world itself and the character advancement system.  As for the world, it just felt small and constrained.  The maps weren't huge ans sprawling, and there didn't seem to be many varied areas, and only 3 real towns.  Characters were far more constrained, with limited viable builds for each one.  Characters also didn't go up to 100+ levels like they did in the old games with vast piles of skills to invest your points (with the freedom to add points past the mastery to partially compensate for the limitations of that character).  The game felt small and pedestrian.  One might argue that the grid-based system constrained it, but I remember World of Xeen still seeming far more epic (probably because of a larger step-size for outdoors and a lot more dungeons).  And of course M&M VI-IX was more free-roaming, with huge maps, and used a world map to split the gameworld into far-flung areas (but I found the combat in those games as very basic, without the epic close-up heavily animated sprites of the Xeen games)..  So yeah, this is a pale shadow of previous Might and Magic games.  I hope Ubisoft goes back to the roots of the series and builds a word more true to the New World/3D0 franchise of old.

												Final verdict: Great game, but not a Might and Magic game at all.PROSYes they had some M&M lore and a really nice NWC type dungeon in the DLC.The music was good but not M&M greatThe graphic were spectacular for a grid based RPGThe voice acting was great and your avatars side comments were often excellent although they needed more (in particular, the male orc voice actor was spectacular)The city sounds were also great but there were far too few and  and you had the same ones in all the cites and it was totally ridiculous to have Georgian chants coming out of a Orc healing center (chapel)And finally the game story was surprisingly coherent and had far deeper elements than a typical Might and Magic game.And there were bunch of puzzles. Most were fair, but they did have a couple really bad ones. There are riddle chests and puzzle dungeons ( fortunatly no monsters to battle in there)Hireable NPC was handled better in this verionsCONSCharacter upgrades are pre defined A battle simulator (just like Lords of Xulima)I think the developers wanted a cap on levels (prior M&M didnt give a lick about this)Some battle last well over 20 minutesNo retreating from battles (either win it or reload)No honorary promotions (although you can do the missions)No experience points for avatars disabled at battles end Many times the battle music would not stop after battles end (long time unfixed bug-you have to save and reload)Audio did not work on my rig until i plugged in some headphoneSpell book sucked. Good spells but too many of the mage schools had little or no offensive capabilities spells.Still, it was a good game to play and I would recommend it. But only as a good game, not as a Might and Magic sequel.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												A caveat: it was a close call whether to recommend this game or warn people off it. Keep that in mind when reading the rest of the review. Might and Magic X is basically a turn-based hack-and-slash game, and it's strength lies in providing a slightly more cerebral version of the Diablo-like experience: kill waves of monsters with sword and spell, loot the corpses (considerately done automatically in this case), level up and get new powers with which to kill monsters, rinse, repeat. There are people who give you quests, but they're not especially memorable in terms of personality or backstory. Your own characters are flat generic PCs. There a main plot involving insurrection and hidden puppetmasters, and as best I can discern it doesn't have any gaping holes, but it doesn't reach the level of the Dragon Age franchise, much less something like Fallout or Bloodlines. It does, however, provide plenty of turn-and-grid-based combats against enemies with somewhat varied abilities, plus plenty of PCs to customize and difficult, meaningful choices about how to allocate skill points (the source of many of my own considerable play hours.)In general, MM X delivers the turn-based tactical-RPG goods. In particular, however, there are a number of annoyances that detract from the experience: -OCD is mandatory. you need spells of Clairvoyance, Light, Whispering Shadows, a way to repair damaged gear (difficult when in the middle of the wilderness), antidotes and/or Cure Poison, one character with Might primary, one with Magic, one with Perception, etcetera, etcetera. Neglecting any particular little thing will at the very least cost you some opportunities and at most court a Total Party Kill-Hard fights aren't smart fights. Especially hard fights don't require that much tactical sophistication- once you've got a schtick your party can reliably resort to, for instance focusing fire on one enemy while Dark Magic users neutralize the other ones with Sleep, you just have to go through the motions. That means doing the same thing turn after turn, occasionally guzzling potions (of which you will need many). Most of the thinking goes into allocating your characters' skill points when leveling them up, before combat begins. -Take a wrong turn and die. Non-linear game worlds with difficult areas available early can be good things. The problems here are that a) there's relatively little indication of what you're getting yourself into, and b) you can't retreat from a fight (barring, maybe, one or two high-level spells that let you), which means saving and reloading. Think Skyrim, if you didn't have the option of running away from the big ugly like your pants were on fire and instead had to stand next to him trading blows until you drop, or just reload. The game has somewhat more good points than bad, enough to hope that the studio will correct these faults to produce a more enjoyable Might and Magic XI

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This game is modeled after Might and Magic 1-5, in the sense that it takes place on a grid and is entirely turn-based.  It has a lot of what made the old might and magic games good to great, but you'll definitely notice some streamlining and trimming of features.  All character skills have shifted towards combat, and you won't reach a point where you get a forester or mountaineer perk that lets you pass through impassible terrain.  Regardless, fans of the series will enjoy a bit tighter of a Might and Magic experience.. and those unfamiliar with the series will be in for some new challenges and possible frustration.  Playing on Warrior difficulty, there were some definitely challenging moments, but I managed to make it through despite picking sub-optimal character classes.  At the end of the day, it was a good solid dungeon crawl with an old-school feel.  Recommended for someone who wants a dungeon crawl with the occasional puzzle.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This game is modeled after Might and Magic 1-5, in the sense that it takes place on a grid and is entirely turn-based.  It has a lot of what made the old might and magic games good to great, but you'll definitely notice some streamlining and trimming of features.  All character skills have shifted towards combat, and you won't reach a point where you get a forester or mountaineer perk that lets you pass through impassible terrain.  Regardless, fans of the series will enjoy a bit tighter of a Might and Magic experience.. and those unfamiliar with the series will be in for some new challenges and possible frustration.  Playing on Warrior difficulty, there were some definitely challenging moments, but I managed to make it through despite picking sub-optimal character classes.  At the end of the day, it was a good solid dungeon crawl with an old-school feel.  Recommended for someone who wants a dungeon crawl with the occasional puzzle.

												I really enjoyed this one. I had the first two when they came out about 20 years ago. I felt it really kept the spirit of those old games while taking some steps into current technology. The graphics are nice but not neccessarily over the top but thats not what this game is about. It's about story and exploration. It's really a throw back to the original dungeon crawlers. Don't expect the massive scale of TES but there are some similarities. Its also refreshing to play a game at max settings that doesn't need a $1-2k system to run. The season pass added some extra missions DLC also.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												TL:DR - This is not a faithful recreation at all. The clostest thing you get is the freedom to make your own party of characters and even this is very limited. Besides that, you are moving along with a grid-based world, permentally stuck in turn-based combat. In a world that punishes exploration. ===Combat===Combat is all turn-based. If you and an enemy are right next to each other, you cannot move. This means that once you engage in combat, You're stuck. No leaving. No retreating. And this becomes a serious problem when you start to explore. You will go to areas that you are not prepared for. And You will get into combat with things you cannot fight. And You can't run. You will die... For exploring... In an open world RPG that encourages you to explore. The previous might and magic games have made it possible. But the problem is the addition of this grid based combat/exploration. In previous games, you could go to an impossible difficulty area, and the first attack kills a party member. You turn, and run away. Maybe lose another party member to a stray shot. But you can still run away and escape. Nothing bound you, like a grid does here. If an enemy engages you in melee combat, you're stuck exchanging blows. No smart manuvering or tactical fighting like in previous games or in legend of grimmock.... No, make your attacks, take your blows, repeat until you or the enemy is dead.===Exploration===As mentioned previously, you are punished for exploring if you happen to end up in an area you cannot fight in. You have to use that quick save... Alot. Its not even fun to explore. Everything is grid based. So you will find boundaries, and areas that look like you can go through but you can't because the grid says you can't go here. It's a massive step down from the previous games where you could scale mountions, fly above and look at the whole world, or jump into the water and risk drowning to discover cool treasures. Heck, it was rewarding to go exploring in areas, that your party wasn't prepared for, to grab some of the loot there. None of that in this game.

It has all the trappings of an RP, but it feels very uninspired. Perhaps it improves, but after 76 minutes, I couldn't force myself to continue on. I killed as many spiders as I could stomach, and I was ready to stab my myself in the eye with my Magic Mouse. I was hoping it would be in the vein of Dragons Age, but I was sadly mistaken. At least I only wasted $10. Now it's time to delete this from my Mac.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												Well, I read all the bad reviews, and came to the conclusion that everyone was crazy and they were all rating the early access version of this game.  Wrong.  Honestly, I love and hate this game.  I've played every M&M game before this, (6 being my absolute fave) and am a devoted fan of the series.  But people, this game is EXCEPTIONALLY buggy.  I'm a pretty patient person.  I overlook a lot.  But I have had to start over *3* times because of various bugs.  Once there was supposed to be a rusty key dropped by a couple of guards.  NO key, NO progress.  I killed the guards, the guards did not drop it.  No way to move forward.  Start over.  Once the game "lost" my saves.  Star over.  Once the game decided not to let me back into a castle I needed to get into.  Start over.  Then I decided to write this review.  This game will be super fun after a few patches.  It needs work on almost everything. Textures are awful, pop ups appear and disappear, NPCs and followers do not behave as they are supposed to, save games disappear and if you save and reload you may lose things from your inventory, IMPORTANT things  Go read the Ubisoft forums before you pay 25 bucks for this game.  Wait 6 months for the next 3 or 4 patches to go online.  I feel cheated and it's not fun.  If they fix this stuff, I would recommend it wholeheartedly.  If you have the time and patience to restart 3 or 4 times in the HOPES that you might be able to complete, go for it.  But don't say I didn't warn you.

												Positives:    If you are feeling nostalgic for old school Might and Magic, this is a great game for you!   The game is very pretty, which is one of the jarring things about trying to play the old games for me.   At low levels, I had a lot of fun.Negatives:  Still some annoying bugs.  Has the most outdated, annoying, frustrating, enraging and overall pisser of a game mechanic in the form of artificial limitations on your characters skillsets. Why can't I have a Freemage with Fire Magic at grandmaster? When I finally noticed I would not be able to achieve my planned skill and spell build I was a bit ticked. It made me nostalgic, indeed.... for the modern games that give me the freedom to build my character the way I want it.

												This game was lots of fun, it is no balanced well at all, and was not similar to M&M 6,7,8 but it was fun.The last boss was NOT fun, I spent 90 hours improving my party with exp and gear and then the game tells me some pirate NPC "was such a bad♥♥♥♥♥only through his effort could you ever hope to hurt this boss"...... sure take all the credit game.After the game tells you that only by this pirate wounding the boss could you possibly hope to win, another new NPC kills the boss............ Yes the boss "encounter" is a "puzzle" if you consider walking to 4 corners of a room a "puzzle"....... but why did I spend 90 hours making a group able kill anything that walks, so that I could NOT fight the FINAL boss and watch him get melted by npc's.The final kick in the teeth was when the expansion starts off by taking away ALL your equipment, all my shiny relics and gear I hunted all over the world, gone.I did enjoy the first 90 hours but the last 1 hour ruined it all.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												I have been a fan of the series since the fifth game, but this one feels like Ubi just felt like throwing sand in the eyes of fans. The graphics are decent, but the game is buggy, the combat is cumbersome and very unfair (the enemies can move when in melee, but you can't), and the characters aren't interesting at all. I'm not just talking about the NPCs, but the ones in your party are also very dull cardboard cutouts and incredibly repetitive in what they say (they also announce warnings for no reason whatsoever). If you choose to play this game, save really, really often – you're going to find yourself constantly reloading.If you want a much more enjoyable experience, I would recommend the Grimrock series instead.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												I agree with those who struggle to give this game a "thumbs up". It really makes you hard to rate, especially given the  Steam's yes/no system.Of course, the graphics is great, the soundtrack is great, the gameplay is not so bad - BUT.Why it is so small in all aspects? Even M&M6 was more widescale and it was made 15 years ago! Seriously, why hadn't developers reflected upon that? M&M6 had respawning enemies, several locations per zone and in this "legacy" remake everything is not present. Like, WTF?And, yeah, the "yo dawg" style of DRM in DRM - having to play through UPlay from Steam - is just stupid, softly speaking.Well, maybe some youngsters from current generation can find this game fun, but I cannot.If you really want to feel nostalgia and experience old school hack'n'slash RPG - try Legend of Grimrock 1 and 2. Those are indeed promising titles.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												I have been quite a fan of the Might & Magic series from the 6th game on.Finished 6 once (took a bit long for my taste), but 7, 8 and 9 I finished at least 3-4 times.This game however......Well it is clearly a M&M game judging by the poor'ish graphics and the turn based combat style.I don’t care about none critical mechanics like in M&M 8 getting your crew from taverns or special buildings, thisa gave the game some extra flavor and was interesting to play around with…However so far have not discovered anything new’ish.There is however 1 total game breaker for me with this game M&M X…Being in a constant turn based environment, every step you make is as if you hop like a bunny from place to place… Also the whole world seems to be 1 big huge chess board in which you walk and if your travels brings you not aligned with a door (which will happen like always), but be prepared to make several 90 degree turns to get to that door instead of doing the logical thing of going diagonal...From 6 up to 9 M&M you could walk or jump to every place you wanted like a normal FPS (the walking part), then when enemies were in melee range the game went turn based.This is what I love, this is what I want in my M&M games…Because I love the series in general I will still try to finish it regardless of its flaw, but I will never recommend this game. Simply because I don’t like this game.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Well what to say, this game is great a good old dungeon crawler with a freaking point to it. There is no grinding passage from what I know you just go explore this nicely made world and its wonders. The game mechanics are refreshing since most games nowdays are only about fastpaced action. And I enjoy it the most because i have enough time to go get me more coffee while in combat. Puzzles combinet with game world with keeping in mind logic that human brain should use are nice. On account of bugs mentioned well I did not see any so far at all. Only con is that compared to past MM series this  one is simplified with harder and more tactical combat so zyou dont miss out on fun. Even when I would welcome more things added I'm glad that ubisoft made a game like this and I would like them to continue in making games like this since i enjoy it. Go and enjoy if you catch it on sale buy it for sure.

												I'm a fan of old-school RPGs, and I really wanted to like this one, but there are just too many frustrating things about this game. The movement speed on the map is laggy and slow, which becomes incredibly annoying when you're forced to backtrack constantly. There are extremely long load times even on my SSD, and guess what, you're constantly loading save games after bumping into a creature way more powerful than you're capable of dealing with, without warning. These two issues ruined this game for me.You're much better off spending your money on the excellent Legend of Grimrock, which is slightly similar.

												I loved mm,6,7 so much and I dont feel like im in an open world at all. I dont feel like i can really explore areas and dungeons because its all blockmovement and every ankle is squared. 												Playing this for about 25 hours in so far. I like to roam once more in the lands of M&M as i played my last game of this series severel years past when i bought the Limited Edition of M&M VI.I wanted some similar experience with MMX and straight went into the Digital Deluxe Edition.So far so good, but STEAM wrote you get also the Digital Audio CD when paying for that. No it seems not.Thats why:(German) http://might-and-magic.ubi.com/mightandmagicx-legacy/de-DE/shop/index.aspx(English) http://might-and-magic.ubi.com/mightandmagicx-legacy/en-GB/shop/index.aspxOnly boxed Editions get Audio CD. So STEAM just did made a big error to get more Digital Deluxe Editions sold. Very dissapointing. At least the extra Dungeon (Didnt found it yet, wonder where Dreamshard Dungeon is) and 1st DLC for free is a plus.Well the game itself is ok'ish, you got to be a fan of good old Dungeon Crawlers. If you where in for Legends of Grimrock, then prepare for a much bigger World here in MMX, but with simpler riddles. Battles can be tough and i did almost got stuck in the storyline where theres a contentblock where u get to fight an Earth Elemental NPC to get the story rolling. If you arent able to get past it it gets a bit tricky to level up more to get it done. But theres allway a way to squeeze some XP along the walk. Over all its a time consuming Game for those who love such RPGs and therefore you should get it and play it. But dont try to make the 24/7 Achievement. Not recomandable if you not want to get feebleminded.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												It's a spiritual successor to the previous Might and Magic games - you know, before they tried going 3D (MM6), then went 3D (MM9) and generally went the way most old-school RPGs at the time did and tried to modernize their worlds when 3D was a bit too new, and screwing everything up. Looking at you, Wizardry 8, Ultima 9 and Might and Magic 9.As a turn-based grid-based dungeon crawler, it's pretty good if a bit simplistic. It follows the lore established by other Might and Magic games, with maximums for skills based on class and only having a handful of those. It's also a bit easy to bone yourself early on, so go read an FAQ or two before tackling. You know, like the old days (where it was on BBSes, or picking up the game guide).Definitely recommended for its quality, and doing a ton with a little and for keeping the flame alive. Would buy MM11 in a heartbeat.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												It is not hard core enough to be the greatest chapter of Might&Magic, yet too hard core to be a master piece.Why? A game requires players do their home works...all kind of it...put notes on map, scheduel carefully on their finance, spells, party organizing... etc.. And we haven't touched combat yet.Non-escaping, D&D encounter, Geez! Im both thrilled and damned.Look, I don't want to save before each combat, but I put so much effert into my party, I can't just let them die and reroll the whole game again!strategic wise, there are too many ambushes. Players are pretty much conered most of time.Though it reminds me the old school M&M... we have to move forward around the inconvinient part...If designers expect players plan their own adventure, then make the game more open and allow more mistakes.The game is not hard, it is just unfriendly. But it was done so as intended. Therefore developer is to be blamed.It has the potential to be as great as Skyrim with such a completed resourceful world and mechanism.However, the playing through in an Open world with a Linear and steep learning curse is just sad.The execution just won't do.However,I still recommend this game because it isn't easy to find this style anymore, it is as rare as you can get.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Pretty much just a stright up dungeon crawl RPG. You get to design 4 characters and customize them, which is in tradition with the old school Might and Magic games. However, now you have different races to choose from each with 3 unique classes. I never much cared for the other MM games, but I like this one a lot. It's really addicting. I also like how its played turn-based on a grid. Some people may not like it but I love it, it reminds me of tabletop D&D. There isn't much to do the second time around, so it is really only good for one playthrough. You get 40+ hours out of one go of it, though, so it isn't a big deal.
