content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												I can't say anything bad about this game. I absolutely loved it. Played it completely through once, and recently reinstalled to play through again. Took me a couple tries to get a group i was happy with. It's turn based old school game. It's hard. you can wander into areas you aren't ready for. Some of the puzzles are easy, some are challenging and some so obscure i had to look up the solution online.I loved the length of the game. There was a couple times i wished there was more. I did pick up a few of the dlc's. But would love to see a whole new campaign with the same engine.Don't expect AAA quality of a game. There aren't many voice overs. and little to no FMV. But be prepared to read, and enjoy the depth of the game.Highly recomend this game. I bought this when it first came out. Just decided to write a review now as i seen the low review score.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8
												Even though I had fun with this game, overall I can't really recommend it.If you are a huge fan of the Might and Magic series, you might give it a try, because it will tickle your nostalgia with countless references to the old games and will at some points even feel like them too. But sadly it's nowhere near the level of the old Might and Magic games. This game feels more like a below average RPG trying to be a Might & Magic game instead of a genuine Might & Magic successor.I don't wanna throw around "bad game design" as a buzzword, but a lot of moments in this game certainly feel like that. Overall the game lacks a lot of polish. There are a lot of moment which make you question what the developers were thinking and it really needs several patches imo. But sadly the development for this game stopped, so it kinda has to stay in this current state. Let's not even talk about all the bugs this game still has.Contrary to most RPGs I played, the battle system in this game just feels really frustrating and not fun at all. Especially if you don't have a proper party setup the fights can get ridiculously punishing and force a lot of restarts (which take pretty long in this game and are always annoying on principle). On that note, I think the recommended default party is utterly ill-equipped to deal with what the game throws at you in the last third of the game and the DLC. Which is already a really questionable design decision in itself. Before you attempt to play this game, definitely look up a decent party build or the game can actually become extremely frustrating (on normal difficulty) and even impossible to beat (on hard difficulty).The DLC was the final straw for me and the reason I decided to write this review. I have never seen such a badly designed mess. Or well, unfun and frustrating. It was certainly the worst way for me to end this game and left a bad, disappointed and frustrated taste in my mouth.If you wanna get into Might and Magic, play one of the older games (Might & Magic VI: Mandate of Heaven is a good starting point imo), this is certainly not the game to get into the series.If you are already a Might & Magic fan, maybe give it a try. But even then, you would do better just replaying one of the older games instead of wasting your time with this one.And if you don't care about the Might & Magic series and just want a good RPG to play, then avoid this game, because it's just a mediocre RPG which lacks polish

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												I strongly recommend this title to players who remember the golden age of cRPGs. This may not be everyone's cup of tea but if you like a good old-fashioned dungeon crawl, no other modern titles can touch this.Graphics: The graphics are good but the performance is a bit spotty. Still, if you ever wanted to try an old school dungeon crawler but were put off by the graphics, this will help you get into them.Sound: The sound is wonderful. The music, the voices, the effects, etc all work well.Story: These are not the kinds of games you play for story purposes. Still, if you bother to read all the text, there is a decent story there. There are even texts you can find to figure out the back story of the world or characters.Gameplay: This is where the game scores the highest marks. There are 4 races with 3 classes per race. You assemble a team of 4 from those choices. This makes the game immensely replayable. I have just finished the second act and am already planning my Hard mode playthrough.Also, the game has many nice touches. It has mechanics to limit rest abuse. Potion overuse is limited by hefty potion costs. Over-levelling is slightly limited by the lack of respawns.Overally, I love this game. It was a great surprise.

Posted: February 21, 2015
												Might and Magic X is an ok game that falls short of pretty much all its successors (the word is correct, as technically, MMX is supposed to be something like MM 5.5, hence why you get MM6 to complement it), even the mediocre Might and Magic 9. As if to add insult to injury, UbiSoft gives us the extremely good MM6 as a part of the deal as if to tell you - here, this is what Might and Magic 6 represented - tons of spells, water walking, flight, exploration, the ability to look under every nook and cranny and actually be rewarded for it. Might and Magic 6-8 were the golden years of the franchise, and every game brought the lineage to new hights. Then came MM9 which pretty much destroyed all the exploration, but added new 3D engine and interesting locales with roughly as much freedom as its forefathers.And now, as a slap in the face comes MMX Legacy with its MM6 bonus. Let's compare the two:1. Movement.1.1. MM6 has free movement, turning, water walking, flight, strategic positioning even while entering combat AND during combat.1.2. MMX is rigid as hell. You are forced into a square grid which not only makes the whole movement experince choppy and unpleasant, but also forces you to turn around just as choppily just to see if you haven't missed anything. Why were can't I enter water squares without having a certain god's blessing? Did people simply forget what a Water Walk spell is?2. Combat.2.1. MM6 has the best of both systems - turn based combat and real time combat. Turn based combat works like MMX, while in real time you could fly, play to the enemies' disadvantages (like use Water Walk and escpe on water while range attacking the enemies). It was liberating as hell and actually encouraged strategic thinking.2.2. MMX combat is rigid and there is little need for strategy. Battles are best won if you can put yourself in a corner or a corridor so that only a few enemies at a time have the opportunity to attack you, while you pick them off easily as the others simply wait dumbly for their turns to enter your killzone. And people said that flying and water walking in MM6-8 was exploiting the system...3. Exploration.3.1. MM6 encouraged exploration on any level and at any time and actually rewarded you for it. And to prove that, the devs actually put a flight scroll in your starting city, so that you can go and explore. Opening every inch of a map in MM6 is exciting and rewards you with secret islands off the coast that have money or chests lying around, craters in mountains with obelisks, chests, and other rewards. I even found extremely rare items like artifacts and relics in such chests! Even if you encounter difficullt enemies (like even dragons or titans), you have a chance to fly or teleport away to escape and come back later.3.2. MMX offers little in terms of exploration, mainly because everything is a corridor - and even if you get adventurous and press on, you get punished by it, because you encounter very difficult enemies and have little or no chance against them, which results in death. Artifacts and Relics are found in specific location, and up until now with 2 running play-throughs with 2 different groups, I found the same artifacts in the very same spots in the very sam dungeons. YAY!4. Equipment.4.1. MM6 has tons of gear diversity. You would just bite your nails before opening a chest or looting a body, looking at that hotbar right above your characters. Ding... You find 24 gold and an item (Axe)! - hell yeah, my guy needs a new one, is it better? Ding... You found 1096 gold and an item (Relic)! OH YEAH!!! What does it do? Can I even identify it? Can any of guys use it? OH it's a ring, all of my guys can use rings, but I don't know what it does! Screw that, I am porting to town to find out! This nailbiting, mouthwatering experience is very much gone in MMX.4.2. MMX has a very rigid gear system. 90% of the time I have been finding better stuff in shops than in chests or the bodies of slain enemies. If you want to make a specific character build, you have to rely on the shops in the various cities. And yeah, just go to that same dungeon to get your artifact at the end. YAY...5. Characters and classes.MMX does have more diversity in Race/Class creation than MM6 (12 vs 9), but one can't escape the feeling that many of those race/class combos play and feel the same. They also reuse the MM6 system of making specialized fighters & casters, and then add hybrids of both classes. So in essense, you have 4 warrior classes, 4 Hybrid classes and 4 Caster classes. One nukes more, another heals more. One gets an extra attack, the other is better protected. Hybrids can really accomplish a lot and supplement your party well. A touch and go system, really...In MM6 you had limitations - you Cleric was a poor fighter, but could heal and learn Light/Dark Magic and become an even better healer, buffer, or nuker. Your Knight could wear the best armor and hit like a ten ton truck, and get more attacks per turn. Your Paladin (the Knight/Cleric combo) could hit and heal, but had no access to the best healing & buffing spells from the light tree.Here, you get a Crusader with Lay on Hands for max heals at any given time at the cost of all your mana who can learn Grandmaster Light Magic (cool heals/buffs), Grandmaster Sword (good fighter), Grandmaster Heavy (well protected), Grandmaster Arcane (Lots of magic resistance). Why not have a few of those in your party, then? IMO, Crusaders very much break the game.6. To conclude: please don't get me started on the UDONTPLAY 3rd party DRM...EDIT: As I put it in the comment: That being said, I am a completionist and I will still finish the game. I, however, cannot shake the feeling that it is inferior to all others though. It is like returning to the dark times before your golden age just for the sake of nostalgia.In short, I would recommend that you buy an MM6-8 bundle and immerse yourself in the 3D-ish world of those games. Explore, fly, walk on water, steal stuff and have fun. Don't be swayed by this Grimrock-style Might and Magic game just because of the Might and Magic in it like I was...

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												Wow what a horrible game... The graphics are extremely dated, and not in a charming way (this game came out in 2014? srsly? Oblivion came out in 2006 and its graphics blow this away!). I have seen indy titles with better graphics and effects, I expect more from an AAA studio. The interface is clunky, wtf is up with the weird "tile based" movement system? You are stuck on a grid?!? What is this? Might and Magic II? MM6, 7, 8 and 9 had no problem letting the party freely move and look around, you toggled "turn based mode" on and off when needed. This game locks it on runs the world every time you step into the next grid tile (you know the way the old DOS 1-Xeen Might and Magic games did...). The character races, classes and skills are pretty basic and lack the options and depth of the games predicessors. It's like they decided to try to capture the look and feel of old titles but managed to capture all the negative things about them with none of the positive.I haven't played much but I already noticed several assets are recycled from previous games... Mostly sound effects that are from MM6, 7, 8. Several of the jingles, the sound of the quest log opening and closing, the sound of drinking potions are all from the old games. It is laughable and only makes me wish I was replaying one of the old titles.I mean... Might and Magic VIII Day of the Destroyer, a game that came out in the year 2000 had 7 base classes, plus 7 promotion classes, plus the dragons. MMX basically has 3... a "warrior" a "hybrid" or a "caster" and the class is a bit different depending on race. VIII had 35 unique skills, X has 25 and they aren't very creative. Your wizard can't even grand master all of the magic spells. VIII had very distinct magic skills, the 4 elemental magics were for wizards, the three "self" magics were for healers and the light\dark were shared (there was also class specific magic...) This game, I am not sure exactly how to distinguish between a healer and a caster, you don't seem to start with any healing spells. The previous few games were cool because you could explore the world freely in real time and then press "enter" to go into turn based mode when needed; you didn't feel like you were locked to a rigid grid.Also, dare I say, the graphics are almost better in 6\7\8. I mean sure they are low res pixelated sprite based images mostly but at least the characters wander around in real time, with a walk cycle. Your characters move their lips when they talk (yeah, no one moves their lips at all in X... it is sometimes hard to tell who is talking). It was a bit primative but at least it was easy on the eyes. Even MM3 through Xeen looked good, in a cartoony oldschool DOS way (and in Xeen the characters moved their lips when they spoke.) MM1 and MM2 had crap graphics, grid based game play and you had to draw your own maps (sort of) but they came on 5 1\4 floppies so they get a pass.Plus, no game since 6\7\8 has had the awesome inventory and equipment equip screens that 6\7\8 had. You could actually see what the thing in your inventory looked like and when you put it on your character they actually looked like they were wearing or using that item. MM9 and X went back to the oldschool "list of items" method and little squares to put the items in to equip them.6\7\8 had a few animated cutscenes, and they were animated well for their time. This game has an extremely long intro, plus another 10 minutes of naration as soon as the game starts and it is all told with still images and voice overs with characters that can't move their lips.The only thing that X seems to have taken from 6\7\8 is some ripped off audio assets.Add to all of this the "wonderful" experience of having to use UPlay... F-ck UPlay. It took quite an effort just to get this game to launch on my PC (among other things I had to sign up for a 3rd UPlay account because for some reason they can't find my old credentials) and - it wasn't worth it.The Might and Magic series peaked with 6, 7 and 8. 9 was OK. X is pretty bad.Go back to remaking "Heroes" clones Ubisoft! If this was an Indy title I would cut it some slack but... come on, this is Ubisoft, the guys who brought us Assasins Creed and Far Cry. Ubisoft and Limbic Entertainment are way above "Indy" level developers. I haven't been this disapointed with a game with the title Might and Magic since Dark Messiah. These guys are making me start to consider MM9 as one of the "good" Might and Magic games... (and I used to hate that game! Well, hate is a strong word. Strongly dislike is more like it.) I miss 3DO and New World Computing. They would have never let this happen.Damn, writing this review has made me want to go back and replay the good Might and Magic games.

												I really wanted to like this game.I saw alot of negative reviews on this and went to write a positive review because I was enjoying it.The thing is the more I played it and looked for good things to say the more I find reasons why you shouldn't buy it.Its a dungeon crawler with no random encounters; just scripted battles.The world is displayed as open but plays as if it is on rails.The writing so far is boiler -plate and bland.The production values are terrible, graphics and sounds far below expections, yet despite the low quality of these the loading time are many and long.The quests are handly orginal, the race and class choices are lets face is laughable.As much and I keenly want to recommend this game you are far better off spending your money on legend of grimrock or paper sorcerer.I wanted to enjoy this game and played it far long than I should hoping I would but the fact is it's a waste of your money when there are far worthier games out there.And that is ignoring the plague on humanity that is ubisoft's DRM which just terrible.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I was not expecting this many bugs for a released game. I find that the "open world" that was advertised in the store page to be deceitful. Infact, the game is quite linear. There isn't much room for customization of the party because if you do not have a star squad, boss fights are impossible and you will have to restart the whole game with a better party configuration. Because the game has a linear progression you cannot prepare your party to mitigate the boss fights. The difficulty wasn't what was most appalling, it was the bugs. I would have to restart or reload saves killing a good hour or two of progress to fix a bug. The most annoying of the bugs that occurs the most is the combat music overriding all other sounds. This ends up with multiple combat musics playing at varying times in their tracks and without the sounds from actual combat this results in a sound similar to that of a heavy metal band practicing in a garage.I believe that only die hard fans of the Might and Magic series would enjoy this game. For the price of 29.99 this game was not worth the punishment of playing it.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Pros:- Lots of spells, weapons, armor, and items to satisfy your cravings for treasure.- Engaging and clever puzzles.- Tactical combat that is easy to pick up, but still provides a challenge.- Solid story with characters Might & Magic fans may find familiar.- Simplified level system from previous games.Cons:- uPlay required (They do give you some extras when you use uPlay units though. I don't like it, but at least they give you some nice extras for it).- Slow to load, some objects don't appear properly (several shrubs appeared in the middle of a fight where there were no shrubs/foliage at first a couple times. Not a deal breaker, just a little weird).- There is a glitch that corrupts your save file (If this happens, don't erase your old game! Start a new one and enter the first dungeon. Then, when the game autosaves when you've entered, load your old game!)- Grid movement system isn't for everybody (though the old free movement system from 6,7, & 8 was a little wonky, so do what you like).All in all, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Initially I had high hopes for MMX as I've been a long time fan of the series since the early 90s, but MMX makes me question the developers ideas because they simply do not work period.  Some of the worst aspects are combat related, such as being locked into combat and no monsters are in the local area, a bug that STILL has not been fixed, this particular bug occurs because of the ridiculously decision to make the combat turn based, where as the previous games was all psedo-turn based meaning you could move your party/pause the game and attack.   MMx locks you into a fight to the death once monsters reach a certain distance from your character, unfortunately I've had this bug out far too many times forcing a reload to a previous point to fix - not to mention this particular type of combat also punishes the players rather harshly against ranged monsters, because you sometimes can't move into melee range!! Absurd but true!!  Honestly - the person who thought up this mechanic should be fired because its one of the serious gamebreaking issues MMx has.If your a veteran of the MM series, you'll know that skill points are valuable but in previous games you had somewhat leeway into making some mistakes with your builds, MMx forces you into very specific builds and characters classes otherwise you could literally become stuck in game without the ability to progress either because of bosses being too difficult or some encounters completely overpowering your characters, so creating your party requires very careful planning and even more careful skill point allocation.  Another major problem MMx is balance, or lack off it.  The balance problems are so bad that I don't think the game was ever playtested properly.   Overall game difficulty is another issue as it wildly increases/decreases, for instance you don't know the level of any monsters and since they cut corners with monsters design (they just re-color) the difference in color of a monster could mean that you have your entire party one-shotted or you one-shot the monster.  But for the most part, you'll die ALOT when exploring, so save literally before every encounter.  Because a typical scenerio when exploring is...kill basic monsters...no problems...oh new monster!! Game Over...reload, avoid area until higher level, it happens far too often which makes me wonder if this development team ever played any of the original might and magic games...I could write on and on about all the complaints and issues I have with this game, but this is one of those games you're either going to love it, or hate it.  I just don't recommend this game to anyone who easily gets frustrated.  It is also especially time consuming because MMx also suffers from excessive loading, with entering buildings/inns...loading...enter/leaving areas...more loading...entering dungeons/new floors...more loading.Basically, This game needs to have the movement lock removed as that would solve many of the issues.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Yes I did play many hours, but most of these hours were played with a trainer on the side to help compensate for the insane difficulty imbalance of the game, I really wanted to see if it would get better but it did not really...I've played this type of game for quite a while, that includes Dungeons Master, Eye of the Beholder, the original M&M series (including World of Xeen and then the "3d" versions), and more recently Grimrock 1 and 2.It's obvious that the team who worked on the game did not have a huge budget, but they managed to have decent graphics and style all over. My issue is more that they got all the small details wrong:- Hit animations and sounds play *before* the attack dice have been rolled, so basically you see characters die, explosion happen, ...BEFORE the main attack animation has even started. That makes the combat frustrating to say the least.- The characters are talking, which is nice, except it was done very badly: When my warrior is stunned, when my magician is dead, I don't want to hear them complain about whatever happen next or point out that they are tired and that we should sleep.- The design involves a lot of instant death, so basically you have to quick save a lot because your next step may just be the last one, and there was no way to know that. People who call that "oldskool" don't know what they are talking about. The olsdkool variant is as deadly, but in general designers left you some hints that you were going to have your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you :p- The loot distribution is abysmal, there's no link between the difficulty of a fight, the fact that the objects are well hidden in a super remote place,... it may still be a pointless non magic item.- The whole RPG system is broken. Skills almost don't matter, all that matters is that you can resist whatever is thrown into your face, which means magic shields and armors, resistance buffs, and protections against stunning, weakness, sleep, etc... the rest does not really matter.- Linking the progression of skills with the story events is so unfair... if you picked up some classes or weapons, you will not be able to level them up until way later in the game because you can't access the trainer you need for the skill.- The inventory system is bad (no auto sorting, no auto selling of the trash loot, you can't throw away stuff if you are looting (you have to close the chest, open the inventory, throw away whatever you wanted, then go back to the chest and finish looting)In conclusion I would say that it was a good attempt tech wise, but that the game design was bad, even the story was just generic fantasy with M&M typical characters while totally missing on the less traditional canon (that involves robots and spaceships.)Try at your own risk.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												It looks nice. Although no where as good as the original games ( 1 - 6 were the best in my opinion).Where this titles falls short is having the gameplay plopped on a grid world. The detail in graphics beg for free roaming, like in MM6. But instead, you're forced on this grid like in MM2/3/4/5. The two styles clash against each other, rather than compliment. And then there's the combat. It's turn-based meets World of Warcraft inspired hotbar mashing. You wouldn't even know that's how it's played, unless you read a walkthrough. The game never tells you you can click on the ability more than once in a combat turn .It's just an odd mesh of things that really don't jell together well, unfortunately. I'm sure if you are reall dedicated, you could probably find some enjoyment out of this title. I just couldn't, sadly. Perhaps one day I'll give it another go. Until, I'll play Wizardry 8.

WHAT?), not to mention same attitude towards releasing a product that will reach EoL while still having missing/incomplete features as with Heroes 6 make this game really unattractive.Even if you are new to M&M, and/or liked Heroes 6 despite plaguing issues, I would not recommend paying more than 20% of the release price (~5 EUR) for the deluxe (or complete, when it releases) edition of this game.To long-time M&M fans: you will not find any M&M in this game. 'Legacy' is just a marketing ploy, but Ubisoft is known for officially confirming claims even when they know they are wrong at the time of issuing a public 'official' confirmation.Don't buy it. You don't want to personally become familiar with how Ubisoft treats you and M&M.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												This game was a complete letdown. The grid based movement is reminiscent of the previous M&M games of yesteryear, but that is where it pretty much ends.There is very little content.. what is there is generally boring. There is not a large skillset and the story is rather bland. The textures and gameworld look like they were from the MM 3-4 era, which was intentional by the developers. However, that seems like a bad decision. The gameplay elements of the older games was great, the graphics not so much.. updating the graphics and providing some rich looking worlds would have went a long way to improve the overall immersion in the game. There are three towns and only 20 dungeons - that's a very small area to explore and overall, the content is around 20-30 hours of gameplay. That seems weak for any game in the M&M series.Modding support for the game is almost non-existent unless you are an indie developer with a Unity3D Pro license ($1500 - if you want one..) So, don't expect alot of community mods. The only good side is that it has a reduced price tag.. But even at $25, its still over priced for what you get. You are better of picking up a dos box and one of the older games in the series - atleast they have less bugs and a solid story.

												Very fun game and I'd recommend it, especially on sale where it's a steal.  One of those few games that I played obsessively to completion (I usually flit around between games as I own so many and have tons installed, and it's rare that something grips me enough to cause me to focus).The visuals never looked as good for me as they do in the screenshots here and I have a beastly computer - so maybe I was missing something (and usually the first thing I do in any game is check settings/options).The game for all its glory has some of the longest and load times and most pitiful performance of any game I've ever experienced.  It's a testament to how good the game itself is that one can put up with the horrid technical implementation of this game.  I mean, it's a turn based RPG with decent for the style graphics, and there's no execuse for how crappy the game performs when you're out and about in the world, or the insanely long loading times.  You would almost have to intentionally code something intentionally poorly to reach these lows and the fact that zero attempt was ever made to patch in optimization is pretty sad.

												I am not usually a fan of these type of games, but this one is done very well. I am playing it on the hardest mode, and love how, although the world is pretty linear, it makes it feel a lot bigger when you have to search for your next combat, slowly progressing stronger and stronger. There are no massive stat items that make the game boring shortly after acquiring them, and overall, it's worth the price and will give you a many many hours of play.Unfortunately, some characters are a little unbalanced, such as rangers are nearly worthless as almost all enemies stay in melee range, and tanks don't do a good job of focusing damage on them. I would give the game a 8/10, but unfortunately on steam its like or dislike.

												I tried very hard to like this game. Some of my favorite gaming memories are playing early M&M games. I love the retro feel and tile based movement. content:
Posted: November 26, 2013



YouTube™ Video: Might & Magic X Legacy Hands on video Preview 

			Views: 1,753		

			http://cramgaming.com - A look at the early access version of Ubisoft's 80s throwback role playing game Might & Magic X Legacy on PC.		

Might & Magic X Legacy in its current state offers some excellent music, solid adventure and some fine character customization making for a worthy game to invest many hours in. Whilst the tile based gameplay might be a little dated, if you can look past this and enjoy the game for what it is, there's an large dose of adventure to be had here for any Might & Magic enthusiast and anyone else who wants in on something slightly off the beaten track. Might & Magic X Legacy is available via Early Access on Uplay and Steam for £19.99 and includes the full game when released, a ton of extra features including the option for the community to make their own content. If early access isn't your thing, then be sure to keep an eye out for the full game when it releases.

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												As a fan of the later Might and Magic (basically 7 and 8) this game is an utter disappointment.This game is built around die and retrying to a scary level. You basically go to any area possible, get killed by the first mob or barely survive, then have to find the next area where you might possibly be able to advance.Difficulty spikes evenly at moments, for example you get a few solitary mobs for a while and then a pack of 2 and an elite with them which makes the fight annoyingly hard early on.Boss fights are also unbalanced. You might be able to complete their dungeon without pain, and still have to keep away from them,  go somewhere else leveling and getting better equipment, then come back for a hard fight.The mix of multiple mob levels in a single dungeon is also a pain as you are always saving before taking a step in another direction (level 10 in a area and level 15+ not far from it depending on another quest).I don't like the map designs, with at times just annoying path blockers, put there for no apparent reason, and towns are too big (while it makes for a real town for a grid based game it makes it a labor to travel the streets).Overall design quality isn't really good and game is unoptimized. Running into the forest and jungle kills FPS to a stop.Story wise you get a common story which is neither good nor bad per se.Classes are limited and some are apparently almost useless, like the defender which sacrifices damage for a shield but can't use his tanking skills on any boss and a number of mobsBug wise I only had a inconvenience with sound, after 8 hours of game time the combat music wouldn't stop but would be piled upon the last one after each new fight. Reloading or changing map restores the usual sound until the next fight (which isn't hard as you always reload anyway).

number of helpful: 8 of 20 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game very effectively captures the 'old school' vibe of the M&M games of the days of yore, but also effectively moves the gameplay into a modern context.  The Xeen series is clearly the main inspiration for this title and the various RPG systems in the game interact effectively to create a compelling and addictive experience.  Exploring the world and discovering new locales is really enjoyable although the graphics are relatively cut-rate compared to similar titles.  Some locations look more impressive than others.  The dungeons in particular are quite well-designed, but the overworld and towns lack visual cohesion and suffer from occasional performance hiccups.  The combat is the meat of the game and  is purely tactical.  Enemies have a variety of abilities to keep you on your toes.  Don't settle into any one tactic or rely on key-spamming, you constantly have to adapt your abilities to the foes at hand.  The lore and world building gets the job done, although exposition is occasionally heavy-handed and long-winded. The grid movement system may feel constrained at first, but if you think of the game more like a series of large chess-like game boards, it makes more sense.  Simplifying the spacialization of enemies and move options to a grid forces you to make specific choices over what you can do spatially in combat - a good thing for a game of relatively modest scope.The main point I want to get about this game is that, as much as the game wants you to, you don't have to look at it through a nostalgia lens.  The RPG systems and tactical combat that hold this game together transcend both the weight of history that hangs over the series and expectations from fans of the genre.  Come in with the right amount of expectations and you'll find that the developers acheived what they set out to do: bring the essense of what made the old Might games such a joy to play and put it in a modern context.  Given the modest resources they had at their disposal and the weight of history they had to stare down, I believe Limbic Entertainment succeeded admirably.

number of helpful: 26 of 59 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Yeah, I’ve played this game for 100+ hours, finished it 5 times, get almost all achievements… Yet I disregard it. Why?Well, all blame goes to Ubisoft, and two major points for I don’t recommend that game are:-	a wrong key feature policy (bad plan), and-	Insultingly high price, considering how low-tech, and limited in capacity that volume is.What is wrong key feature policy, you may ask? Well, that game proposes itself as HardCore and Oldschool. That’s the point for that I want to crush skulls and jaws. You see, using the old mechanic is not making the game oldschool. Forfeiting base common tricks, like adjustable map or in-game notepad, does not making it hardcore.The main reason for what people love old games is not about any type of mechanics. It is about passion! Guys who made those old games on their knees, in the dusty garages, but with full care a parent can give to its child – where every piece in every place is literally hand-made – that’s for people getting old-school. When Finnish Almost Human studio hit the shelves in the 2012 with the Legend of Grimrock, their game was praised not for using sluggish square-based movement. No, please! It was all about good combination of long-known tricks with the creativity and that famous “from gamers to gamers” drive.Might and Magic X Legacy in fact is just a tribute to old 3DO hits, snatchingly made by a small amateur game studio Limbic for a paycheck, and then sold as a full-scale hit by Ubisoft.Now, I don’t think that subsidiarity is a bad idea. It is one of the basic principles of the European Union, for example. But sometimes subsidiarity is not a good option. So rich is the fan-base of the old Might & Magic series! It is certainly have no less admirers than Deus Ex. Were Might and Magic X Legacy a stand-alone project, with some different name (Legend of Eryn, why not?) – I’d only recommend it. But as an inheritor of the whole serial… it is not even a basttard, it is an impostor.  When I’m hearing its name, it sounds to me like, “Leo Romanoff, the right heir to the Russian throne”.That’s all about two major aspects, for which I’m turning it down. Now, the base routine: normal review for a game without such big name.What we have is a first-person view RPG with tile-based movement (like in the M&M 1-5 or the Legend of Grimrock). There go some fans of M&M 6-8… I know some of them, and they don’t happy about that turn. What I didn’t like about that style of movement is that I constantly losing the track. Especially if the background is not flat, like in the Crag town. When you climbing up there, it is cool. But when you have to descend… you can’t look down! So you move, but don’t see where, because you don’t see ground! Un-natural, that concept is.The battle system is turn-based, of course: you have four of your characters, you make a move for every of them, then comes enemies, and so on, one for one. While challenge in those turn-based combats is quite high sometimes, the bad thing is that it is very clumsy in any case where you are not strong enough just to click enemy to death with single attack. It goes about applying your characters skills via game interface. Yeah, you have 10 buttons, 5 already binded (1-melee, 2-shot, 3-block, and 2 buttons for red and blue potions). Another 5 buttons are yours to bind, but boy, that’s so far from enough!After you get about 10-15 level, you’ll be constantly using sub-subdirectories to make every move for every character. I always thought that western PC RPG stands above JRPG like Final Fantasy, when we speaking about normalcy, convenience of combat performing. Alas, the turn-based fight in the M&M X is worse than in your normal JRPG. In the most of the battles it feels like romp in the mud.The story? Nothing spectacular. Go from A to B, then to C, return to A, to B, another round with new mail quest, and another. Wait! Twist! (bonfires) And go for another 3 rounds between A, B and C!There are too little place for decent amount of adventuring. Some locations are blowing my mind, but in the bad way. You go through a tomb full of ghouls and ghosts, managing through some part of it, and then – whoa! – you’re meet humans. Not necromancers. You think, well, I finished the tomb part; there is a Rubicon, now it is a human dungeon. You reconfiguring your skills to fit the fencing with humans, then hop! Another ghost attack! No logical explanation, what people and undead doing jointly, but they’re performing some cohabitation. Why? Well, not because it is a great plan of some kind. There are simply not enough place for two dungeons and variety of enemies for every maze you’ll have to see on your way through.Game falls low shortly after start. It is unnatural, bleak, and the only good point in it is the retro battle system, which gives you some trial to see if you’re fit to old standards. Oh, wait, I’ve already said that that system is clumsy and broken there! So – generally – there are no point to start it, at all!If only to cherish your curiosity… Save your time, don’t bother. My mark is 6/10.PS: I've almost forgot, but this is important piece: the sound in the game is its worst part. After about two hours of playing I was urged to shut down the voices, then, after I've got to Seahaven, I switched off the ambient, and it was not long until I totally mute the game and played only with my own soundtrack on background. What's so bad? Buzzing sounds. That's a total disaster, believe me. Limbic should shot their sound engineer, or at least, stop feeding him.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												Crunchiness rating: 2/10The crunchy bits:- Character creation- RPG level progression- Inentory managementThe not crunchy bits:- The character creation is very limited, only two heads per race (4 races only) and only one body per class (3 per race) - Only 3 classes per race, which is very limited compared to the MM titles of yore where you were much more open in your progressions. - Graphics while not normally conisdered in crunchiness leave much to be desired- Inventory management reminds me of MMOs like WoW rather than the more awesome inveotries of modern single player RPGs. - No more equipping armors and seeing them on the character paper doll like the old MM titlesI would say you should give this game a pass unless you ae looking for a simple game to pass the time with. If you liked the old MM games, you will be sorely dissapointed. There are many other better MM type games out there like Legend of Grimrock 1 & 2 on steam or better yet go get the old MM titles for GoG.Personally, I will go get my money back for this if I can.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Might & Magic X - LegacyConcept:A Dungeon crawling old school hack-and-slash RPG set in the Heroes of Might and Magic World. Graphics: ★★★☆☆Not Skyrim, but for  a 3D grid-base dungeon crawler it looks pleasing. Sound: ★★★☆☆The music is reminiscent of some of the classic Might & Magic titles as well as the Heroes of Might and Magic series. Sound effects are simple and repetitive.Playability: ★★★★☆Easy controls and interface like its predecessors. Entertainment: ★★★☆☆If your familiar with games of the past like the Wizardry series or the Might & Magic games, you will love this title as it takes you down memory lane but for those who are new to these type of games may get bored as the gameplay may get repetitive.Replay Value: ★★★★☆I feel the game has a High replay value especially since your party consists of 4 members and there are a total of 12 possible Classes to mix and match with the 4 races.Overall Rating: ★★★½☆☆ MY PERSONAL REVIEWThe Game takes place a few years after the events of Might & Magic: Heroes VI. Might & Magic X - Legacy takes place on the Agyn Peninsula. It's a throwback to the hack-and-slash RPGs of old and no knowledge of the past series is required to play it. You can create a Four person party consisting of 4 Races and 12 Classes to select from. While the party size is locked at four, players can pick up additional hirelings to fill specialized needs that give certain buffs or the pack horse that adds a considerable amount of inventory space which I found a must. The classes offer lots of skills and spells to choose from. The individual skills can be ranked up starting at novice and going up to Grandmaster. Some of the spells you get at Grandmaster are devastating but the road to get there is a long one. If you liked the Diablo style loot drops than you’ll like this game as there is a ton of different types of loot. The game adds some puzzle and riddle solving to take away from the constant combat grind.  Players can roam towns to find various power ups, coins, and quests that send them out into the wilderness. The game offers about 60+ Hours of play time if you explore every nook and cranny and take the time to read all the Lore it offers. This game is nothing like the Heroes of might & Magic series but if you liked games of the past like the Wizardry or Eye of the Beholder series or even the new Legend of Grimrock than this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												I can say, will do a bit of a quick review. So won't get too much into detail, but will cover the basics.It is a overall quite neat game. Taking the classic dungeoncrawl approach and spicing it up a little. While the graphic are notably ripped from heroes 6, I don't mind at all. After all, why waste assets when they have them? And they work well within the world so.That said, the game has some MASSIVE flaws, and some small annoyances.Can start with the small ones: For starters, there are too few lines of spoken dialog in this. Even with a diverse group, basically 70 % of all lines are identitcal between characters. Not that many, but heck, it's not far from it. They seriously cheaped out on that. The dialog that exist is pretty well done. But yeah, it incredibly fast gets repetitive  the 482'th time. Sometimes you can hear the same line 12+ times per minute. Depending on the situation.Secondly it's that, while more of a "read up on it, scrub" thing, your "talent tree" is something you heavily need to invest in, and plan ahead. You're not allowed to just pick it as you go, it became clear to me a bit in that I would have needed to plan my build from the start. As some skills are just far too vital not to have. Like how you literally can't complete certain dungeons without having certain spells and/or immunities.And while mostly a aestetic thing. It feels a bit dumb how you start as this "kinda pro adventuring party" with basically 0 equipment or skills. I get that you have to build your way up, but it's kinda derp how you're these supposedly bad♥♥♥♥♥"Raiders", and you have some rusty, duct taped gear and barely know how to slap someone xP Not to mention: The game ocassionally forgets your UI, and resests some buttons to the "default" potion combination. Not a big annoyance, but can be a nuisance. Atop that, it seems some of the DLC content is bugged. I cashed in a reward for the deluxe edition package, but the item for it was never delivered, yet it claimed it had been cashed in.Now, for the massive flaws of this game in no particular order: (I was debating a bit wheter or not I would recommend this game, but in the end, it is a nice game. Yes, it will frustrate you a lot. But it has enough enjoyable moments to mostly weigh it up)1: The loading times are far too long.  It's not to bad in the start. But later in the game, these become a massive bother. ESPECIALLY as the game refuse to load if you are tabbed out. So you can't enter a dungeon or the like, then tab out, check a few things and tab back in during the up to 30+ second long loadingscreens. This becomes ESPECIALLY annoying due to the next in this list, which will force you to repeatedly re-load over and over and over and over and over. It's just a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way to pad on extra hours of gameplay.2: The RNG creep. I could be that I had a bad party combo. But some enemies just get plain stupid with this. Most of the undead are a great example of this. With one lucky hit, and many enemies seem to have 20-40 % crit chance, they can, and will 1-shot any non-tank party member. Just like that. Poof. And there's nothing you can do about it aside from spam protective spells. Which, makes you unable to attack. While they normally hit for like, 41 damage, when they crit, it can be anywhere from 180-260 damage if they feel like it. And when a ex: magic hero at that level has around 100 hp, they're just toast. So at many places, you just have to save, enter combat, hope RNG doesn't screw you over, if so, load and rinse and repeat. You're not being challanged the least, your patience is just being tested. 3: Broken skills and events. Some abilities don't work on enemies, or are outright broken. Like how if you stun an enemy, they can still retaliate, block and all that. While you aren't allowed to do so if stunned as a character. And there's dozens of design flaws like that around. And some events break when you save at a particular palce or time. Like, one event in a crow temple, an entire encouter crashes and vanishes if you save after you talk to a spirit. Which mind you, is a place with the issue in 2 mentioned. So you have to save before you talk to them. Talk to them, enter fight and hope each turn you don't have the ~5-10 % chance of getting instantly killed and be force to load, while you try to take down 6 enemies  at both sides of you with like, 1500 hp each. Each one of these capable to 1 shot your non-tanks. Currently at that fight as I am writing this, and have been for around 2 hours, 1 of which has just been pure loading time. For a game so heavily reliant on QS and QL, this type of droll padding just isn't acceptable. I'd at most expet 5-10 second loading time, at most. Many parts of this game is pure trial and error via RNG. Atop that, you only get experience for enemies if a hero is alive, and without and negative condition on them. Like what? My mage didn't learn anything at all from figthing a dragon, just becuase she got backhanded by said dragon and stunned, and her magical boots managed to kill the dragon? She had to be fully aware and witness as the dragon died, or else the entire fight was just some dull pasttime she couldn't learn anything from?4: No ability to flee. For a game that places it's level 20 monsters next to it's level 1 obligatory giant rats. This is such a huge design flaw I don't even know what to say... It's like removing/not including a dodge or block manouver in a fighting game... like, the actual murloc? This ties heavily in with the save/load issue. As, every time you find something new or a new area, you are forced to save to know if you even are allowed to be there, before you head on in. Your entire party got 1-shotted by a magically farting spider? Welp, you better load then, possinly after being forced through a game over screen, to then be made to wait a total of 1 minute before you are allowed back in. It's just not acceptable as said with the massive amounts of lazy padding this game has. It's like... it's a great game in here, why was so much bad descisions stuffed into it? Despite this being a late, patched version of the game. I really fear how terrible it must have been at launch.  There's seriusly a good game in here. It's just brutally hampered by multiple poor choices and design errors.I think this wraps up most of it... but yeah. I'd perhaps give a 6.5 out of ten? Nice game, but far too often just plain frustrating. Just knowing that "Oh, I see my tactic and team was irrelevant here, I just wans't lucky enough with the dice rolls to progress... better spend a mintute reloading the... not saying RNG is always bad. But when it becomes a major part of the game itself... it's just frustarting. Adding numbers or making the AI cheat just to upp the difficulty is just poor design. Yes, I know it's sort of "needed"sometimes, but it's very tacky regardless. There's just far too many areas where you're simply not allowed to do anything to affect the outcome of things. Or would have had to play the game prior to know which things to bring where.

												This is a work in progress as of 2013-08-22 and an "early access" game.  Even so I expected a LOT more out of this but it falls sadly very, very short.  It's painful to play.  The older games are better.  The "grid" walking system is painful.  The combat is "meh".  The characters are flat and boring. The interface works but is sadly lacking.  The graphics - well, I think the older games looked better in their time than this does today.  The writing is so-so, the sound effects are re-used from older games (mostly) so there's some nostalgic value there but otherwise they're very bland.  Combat, the key activity in the game, is boring so far.  Again, the older games were more fun.  Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm not the gamer I used to be... but hopefully they'll fix this up and do it right.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												First off, the bad stuff. This game has a few frustrating elements put there by the developers. Poison will kill you, and quite quickly, and you get no warning that you need to get earth magic's cure poison or buy antidotes before you get poisoned the first time, although hopefully you will have picked up enough antifotes to be okay. Secondly, while both the team and monsters are locked in space when they enter a melee fight (which is fine), there is one boss that doesn't, and who is going to push the team to their death if the I guess random number generator wills it. Lastly, a couple of things are very difficult to find, and there's no abundance of hints to where to go and the voice acting isn't that great.Apart from that, Might and magic X is a truly brilliant game. You start off choosing a team of four characters whose skills will complement each other on their Quest through the Agyn peninsula. From there on, everything is grid and turn based. You will move square by square through an astonishing world with a lot, really a lot, of cool secrets you may have to go out of your way to find. The game is really well made for people who like to explore places, as the world is big, and the only thing keeping you from going places are monsters. You will need to save often, as you may be ambushed by too difficult monsters in the early game, but even really difficult monsters can often be overcome if you employ the right strategy. Mages are given powerful but costly control options, and there are lots of different strategies to employ to get past the bad guys. Being turn based, you can even change your equipment during your turn in combat, yielding very interesting options if you stack up on cool equipment. This results in a lot of digressions from the tasks at hand; the party will find a new nook or cave they want to explore while on their way to the next location. Except for interdependent quests, you can mosttimes do any quest you have in any order you'd like.While difficult monsters can often be overcome with the right tactics (or a couple of levels, there are always other things you want to do in the mean time), easy monsters can often kill the party if you don't pay attention. The simplest monsters give 5 xp, the toughest give you around 50, so you will never feel that you are too strong for an area, you simply spend less turns during each combat.One of the aspects that really got me in this game was all the puzzles. All the way through the land they have put mysterious crypts, where you need to solve a puzzle to get to the treasure, with no dangerous monsters to distract you. There are a lot of chests which requires you to answer a riddle correctly, and they are very fun to ponder about, especially if you're playing together with someone. I already said there are a lot of treasure in this game, and it is sometimes hidden due to the movement in the game. If there's a chest to your side, you won't notice it unless you face that direction, and as you can't face every wall all the time, you need to keep looking for small boxes or camuflaged chests you need to face.For the level system, I think it's good. every level gives you 4 attribute points, to be spread over strength, perception, destiny, magic, etc. with very clear effects. This makes sure your character gets better at what he/she does at every level. The character also gets 3 skill points, which can be spent on increasing skills. All the skills a character chan choose between, he/she can master to different degrees, expert (at 7 skill points), master (at 15) and grand master (at 25). At these scores, advancement needs to be bought from a skill specific trainer, which will give an extra boost and let the character advance further. There are 12 classes to choose between, and each has a different set of skill mastery possibilities, but each class needs to get promoted through a special quest to access gm training (range -> warden can gm bow, barbarian -> warmonger can gm two handed), so the game really makes you work to become better. I already mentioned that mages have interesting battle control options; the fighters also do. There's a skill called warfare, which grants spell like abilities (two more at each new level of mastery) like reducing armor or taunting enemies to attack that particular character. This makes any kind of team viable, and gives the game a lot of replay value. When I say any kind of team is viable, I mean it, character creation is not something you need to ponder a lot on, there will be ways to destroy every enemy with what you want to play. Also, at gm level, you will be insanely good, and your party will feel like living gods. This feels great.I had a lot of fun all the way through this game. They have managed to scare me through sending enemies on me that I didn't think I could handle, they have given me riddles and puzzles I didn't feel like I could handle, but I did, and it was great. If anything is too hard or obscure, you can always google it, you will still enjoy the world of asha. Turn based and grid based games aren't for everyone, and it's difficult to do it well. I hated legend of grimlock, as the movement was annoying, and you could kick difficult bosses asses by figuring out their movement patterns. What they did badly, MMX has done in a very smooth way. Id you liked the stroy part of Heroes VI, then you'll love this game, as they expand upon it with great pieces of lore scattered around (and a story that follows in the footstep of Heroes VI). If you played the old games, you will definitely love this one, as they have included lord Kilburn and Crag Hack, as well as lore about "Lord Caneghem".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												I was unable to play the game once I entered the lighthouse due to what appeared to be a bug in the game, resulting in a downvote. I submitted a helpdesk ticket to ubisoft (I'm on mac, but they apparently don't admit to have a mac version, so I submitted it to the windows help desk) and got a useless response. They basically had me install every OS X update and some flash installers, none of which really helped. I felt like I had just called comcast and the script the "helpful" individual on the other end had them read the same thing, even if it was totally innappropriate. However, I changed my recommendation after following the directions in one of the steam forums. Apparently, this is a 32 bit game and, for mac users, you must find the actual program and mark it as such in order to get decent playability. Once you do, it is fine (though, not a stellar experience). I'm pretty sure Macs have been 64 bit for over 10 years now. But, maybe the code they are using is still 32 bit and they can't afford to have someone actually update it? Even the PC version isn't 10 years old...The game plays more or less like the old M&M games that came before it, but with better graphics. Having grown up with games like this, I prefer the turn based combat. There are some real problems, such as situations where the enemy you are fighting doesn't actually appear on your screen. However, you can still blow them away with fireballs, even if you have no clue where they are. I've seen pirates walk through walls to fight you, and combat turns for the opponent can take several minutes as the animations dig through to find you. All in all, this is a decent remake of those old school dungeon grinders that were king back in the 90s but modernized for semi modern hardware. If they put some work tuning the engine itself, it would probably be a great iPad or android game. Hopefully, it will get some attention and they'll fix some of the more annoying bugs (and maybe bring it into the 21rst centry of 64 bit hardware?). But, even now, it's a fun game that can be enjoyed for hours.

YAY SO MUCH FUN. No. It's also grid based, and the texture quality in some notable places is just horri-bad. CHECK OUT THE TOWN NAME ON THE SIGN AS YOU LEAVE THE FIRST TOWN.lol.

Posted: May 9, 2014
												I don't write reviews, ever.  But being long-time M&M/Wizardry fan, I felt I needed to dispel some of the myths about this game.  I'm playing the game on a macbook 2011, with no problems running in 32-bit mode.  Gorgeous game, great interface, challenging battles, great puzzles, and funny references.  I've put some time in this game, and I'm on my first playthrough.  I have ignored butt-aches to play for another thirty minutes.  I am definitely playing this again once I complete it.  First let me say that reviewers that say you should min/max your skills, or you have to play a certain race/class combination are so so wrong.  I get a chuckle out of thinking of players not using rangers.  Now that I'm in the later stages of the game, monsters should feel privelaged to be able to survive long enough to get into melee range.  I love the turn-based combat and strategy.  Everything about this game makes sense.  If you liked the good ole days of Xeen, you will love this adventure.  Get it.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												I can say, will do a bit of a quick review. So won't get too much into detail, but will cover the basics.It is a overall quite neat game. Taking the classic dungeoncrawl approach and spicing it up a little. While the graphic are notably ripped from heroes 6, I don't mind at all. After all, why waste assets when they have them? And they work well within the world so.That said, the game has some MASSIVE flaws, and some small annoyances.Can start with the small ones: For starters, there are too few lines of spoken dialog in this. Even with a diverse group, basically 70 % of all lines are identitcal between characters. Not that many, but heck, it's not far from it. They seriously cheaped out on that. The dialog that exist is pretty well done. But yeah, it incredibly fast gets repetitive  the 482'th time. Sometimes you can hear the same line 12+ times per minute. Depending on the situation.Secondly it's that, while more of a "read up on it, scrub" thing, your "talent tree" is something you heavily need to invest in, and plan ahead. You're not allowed to just pick it as you go, it became clear to me a bit in that I would have needed to plan my build from the start. As some skills are just far too vital not to have. Like how you literally can't complete certain dungeons without having certain spells and/or immunities.And while mostly a aestetic thing. It feels a bit dumb how you start as this "kinda pro adventuring party" with basically 0 equipment or skills. I get that you have to build your way up, but it's kinda derp how you're these supposedly bad♥♥♥♥♥"Raiders", and you have some rusty, duct taped gear and barely know how to slap someone xP Not to mention: The game ocassionally forgets your UI, and resests some buttons to the "default" potion combination. Not a big annoyance, but can be a nuisance. Atop that, it seems some of the DLC content is bugged. I cashed in a reward for the deluxe edition package, but the item for it was never delivered, yet it claimed it had been cashed in.Now, for the massive flaws of this game in no particular order: (I was debating a bit wheter or not I would recommend this game, but in the end, it is a nice game. Yes, it will frustrate you a lot. But it has enough enjoyable moments to mostly weigh it up)1: The loading times are far too long.  It's not to bad in the start. But later in the game, these become a massive bother. ESPECIALLY as the game refuse to load if you are tabbed out. So you can't enter a dungeon or the like, then tab out, check a few things and tab back in during the up to 30+ second long loadingscreens. This becomes ESPECIALLY annoying due to the next in this list, which will force you to repeatedly re-load over and over and over and over and over. It's just a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way to pad on extra hours of gameplay.2: The RNG creep. I could be that I had a bad party combo. But some enemies just get plain stupid with this. Most of the undead are a great example of this. With one lucky hit, and many enemies seem to have 20-40 % crit chance, they can, and will 1-shot any non-tank party member. Just like that. Poof. And there's nothing you can do about it aside from spam protective spells. Which, makes you unable to attack. While they normally hit for like, 41 damage, when they crit, it can be anywhere from 180-260 damage if they feel like it. And when a ex: magic hero at that level has around 100 hp, they're just toast. So at many places, you just have to save, enter combat, hope RNG doesn't screw you over, if so, load and rinse and repeat. You're not being challanged the least, your patience is just being tested. 3: Broken skills and events. Some abilities don't work on enemies, or are outright broken. Like how if you stun an enemy, they can still retaliate, block and all that. While you aren't allowed to do so if stunned as a character. And there's dozens of design flaws like that around. And some events break when you save at a particular palce or time. Like, one event in a crow temple, an entire encouter crashes and vanishes if you save after you talk to a spirit. Which mind you, is a place with the issue in 2 mentioned. So you have to save before you talk to them. Talk to them, enter fight and hope each turn you don't have the ~5-10 % chance of getting instantly killed and be force to load, while you try to take down 6 enemies  at both sides of you with like, 1500 hp each. Each one of these capable to 1 shot your non-tanks. Currently at that fight as I am writing this, and have been for around 2 hours, 1 of which has just been pure loading time. For a game so heavily reliant on QS and QL, this type of droll padding just isn't acceptable. I'd at most expet 5-10 second loading time, at most. Many parts of this game is pure trial and error via RNG. Atop that, you only get experience for enemies if a hero is alive, and without and negative condition on them. Like what? My mage didn't learn anything at all from figthing a dragon, just becuase she got backhanded by said dragon and stunned, and her magical boots managed to kill the dragon? She had to be fully aware and witness as the dragon died, or else the entire fight was just some dull pasttime she couldn't learn anything from?4: No ability to flee. For a game that places it's level 20 monsters next to it's level 1 obligatory giant rats. This is such a huge design flaw I don't even know what to say... It's like removing/not including a dodge or block manouver in a fighting game... like, the actual murloc? This ties heavily in with the save/load issue. As, every time you find something new or a new area, you are forced to save to know if you even are allowed to be there, before you head on in. Your entire party got 1-shotted by a magically farting spider? Welp, you better load then, possinly after being forced through a game over screen, to then be made to wait a total of 1 minute before you are allowed back in. It's just not acceptable as said with the massive amounts of lazy padding this game has. It's like... it's a great game in here, why was so much bad descisions stuffed into it? Despite this being a late, patched version of the game. I really fear how terrible it must have been at launch.  There's seriusly a good game in here. It's just brutally hampered by multiple poor choices and design errors.I think this wraps up most of it... but yeah. I'd perhaps give a 6.5 out of ten? Nice game, but far too often just plain frustrating. Just knowing that "Oh, I see my tactic and team was irrelevant here, I just wans't lucky enough with the dice rolls to progress... better spend a mintute reloading the... not saying RNG is always bad. But when it becomes a major part of the game itself... it's just frustarting. Adding numbers or making the AI cheat just to upp the difficulty is just poor design. Yes, I know it's sort of "needed"sometimes, but it's very tacky regardless. There's just far too many areas where you're simply not allowed to do anything to affect the outcome of things. Or would have had to play the game prior to know which things to bring where.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												First, I loved playing all the old Might and Magic games.  When you can put a dragon in your party, that makes for some good times!  So nostalgia is the biggest element in recommending this title.Sure, there are many more games far greater and more compelling than this, but MMX is like rewatching an old movie that was your favorite years ago, before you knew better.  I'm not a button masher, and the old school "take all the time you want making decisions during a fight" interface is something, I'm embarrassed to admit, I enjoy.Look, "Legacy" is right there in the title.  This is an old school RPG that's mildly entertaining, and just the right speed for ageing, casual RPG gamers too intimidated to jump into the contemporary open world games of today.  Like me.

												I got this game as a part of a bundle and thought "well, this will be one game I'll nevel install".But I ended up trying the game, and liked it so much I completed it.Despite being released in 2014, Might and Magic X has a very strong back to 90' feeling looming over it. It mostly feels like a weird mixture of roguelike and older Might and Magic games. Turn based game where you run in a grid. Certainly not something you would expect from such a new game.I, however, find this pleasant and nostalgic.If you like older Might and Magic titles and are fan of roguelikes, then this game will be good for you, try it out if it's on sale. If you aren't fan of either, better stay away. You will probably not like this.There are two major downsides for this game I disliked.-Damn much running around in same places.-No real game notes. Too often you keep wondering "where on earth I saw that earth magic master teacher. Gotta go to google again, I'm not checking the whole world again to find him."They certainly didn't stop me from playing, but I must admid both were annoying for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Best RPG I've played in years, and has quickly become my single favorite game. After playing this I just HAD to play the rest of the M&M series, and I played from 3 to 9 and loved every second of it. This is how RPGs are supposed to be!Pros: - awesomely fun RPG game in pretty much every way.Cons: - support was unfortunately pulled by Ubisoft before a host of audio problems could be patched out, so we're stuck with them forever now. Battle music gets stuck on all the time, sounds constantly don't play or have wrong volumes. With a long enough play session you can end up with 3+ battle songs all playing at the same time all out of synch, which is pretty irritating to hear. these problems are extremely disappointing since the game itself is otherwise so amazing. exiting and running the game again does fix it though (temporarily). - After having played the rest of the series, there are a few things in comparison that I miss, but these are not strictly good or bad:    - most M&M games have an accelerating levelling scale. progression is slow in the beginning, but by the end you're gaining like 10 levels per trainer visit. in this one, progression does start slow, and does accelerate at first, but at the end it slows to a crawl, and you end up basically frozen and will never be good at everything you could have been good at. this is pretty strongly different than the other M&Ms where you could master everything about your class and still have tons of points left over. depending on your point of view this could be a good or bad thing.    - this game actually has *better* tactical combat than any of the other M&M games, and depending on which classes you choose, you can still become very powerful. though the classes are actually very imbalanced as well, some being extremely powerful and some being very weak. again, this may or may not be a bad thing.

												Such a fun game. If you like the old might & magic games, you'll love this one. It is buggy and I couldn't play it with the highest graphics because some effects will crash the game. I set all to medium or low and I enjoyed the game nontheless.Some cool riddles, cool but simple puzzles. great intense battles, cool unique items that level up. Really loved this game.I think that, if they step away from Unity and get an engine that doesn't make your life a living hell, and do more of  the cool things they made for this game, M&M XI should be a return to the old days when M&M was the best turn-based rpg out there.Would recommend? To a M&M fan sure, buy it now! To a regular rpg gamer, I'd say buy it on sale or look for something else.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Old school turn based RPG. Move as a party, grid based. Quest, fight, loot, level and repeat. A bit rough around the edges but recent patches have fixed the most glaring issues. I enjoyed it, it is just hard enough to keep you on your toes and there is enough vareity in characters, quests and spells to keep it interesting. There are some annoying bits like teleport and pressure plate puzzles, if you lack patience for these kinds of things you'll be reaching for a walkthrough to get past these. It is a long game, I spent ~60 hours on a play through. A bit of a slog toward the end but I remained hooked enough to finish it.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I waited for the final release, having a blast so far.  Really fun game - highly recommend for anyone that enjoyed the old time RPGs of yesteryear.  If you ever enjoyed tile-based RPGs (MM, Wizardry, Eye of the Beholder, Dungeon Master etc.) I think your money is well spent on this game.  I'm just a few hours in and already know I will complete this game with pleasure.  Good stuff!EDIT - 24 hours in and loving it - it really ramps up in difficulty.  Playing on 'normal adventure mode' but still offers up a helluva challenge.  Word to the wise, be very careful in party creation. As far as I can tell duel-wielding trumps two handed quite easily.  I recommend two blade dancers and two magic users, freemages work well as they can learn any school.  But what do I know?  I'm having a helluva time!EDIT - Completed the game tonight.  Awesome value, and a crazy challenge at the end.  The game surprised me a lot and there is a lot of depth here.  If you enjoy a turn-based, well thought out and designed RPG then you can't go wrong with this game.  If you have reservations because of the 'old-school' vibe, give it a try, you'll be rewarded with a great game.

												If you like turn-based grid-style RPG games, this is a great one to pick up on the cheap.  Yes, you do hit a wall around Act 2, but if you power through it, you will be rewarded with fun.  This game is very buggy, and I was fortunate to have game-breaking bugs at the very end, but I was able to get through them.  The game itself is right up my alley in the kind of RPGs I miss from my younger years.  I was able to beat this with a Blademaster, Rune Priest, Druid, and Freemage, and I have watched quite a few win with other combinations, leading me to beieve that you can beat the game with any makeup, provided you spec into their strengths and figure a combat strategy that will keep you alive.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Might & Magic X was a very positive surprise. The reviews were somewhat average, but I was looking for an old-style dungeon crawl and went ahead buying MMX shortly after it went out of early access. If you know what to expect (a tile and turned based game system), you might end up having a lot of fun with it.Graphics aren't the best, but look quite decent within dungeons (where you'll spent most of your time). I like the combat system, especially that you get the feeling of being in control and making good decisions without having to spent ages learning stats of weapons and spells. Almost 10 hours in, combat is still fun and I haven't encountered any frustrating difficulty spikes yet (although I faced some challenges).The story is rather weak, but then again, you're here for the dungeon crawl.I'm not a veteran MM player, but after MMX I'll definitely look into some of the classic parts of the series.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												+ Nice combination of old school turn-based RPG and modern comfort features (annotatable automap, easy comparison between different items via mouse-over, rest anywhere instead of only in safe zones etc).+ Turn-based battles require a lot of micro-management of your character's spells and skills. For me, it was a great part of the fun of MMX - for other players this might be a turn-off.+ Thoughtful management of your character's attributes and new skill points is a must - but it's also very rewarding when you reach a new weapon proficiency or finally master a new, powerful spell.+ Decent variety of enemies, though there are only about two to three different types per dungeon / overworld area. Each type of enemy has different resistances and skills - you have to adapt your attacks / buffs / debuffs accordingly.+/- Loads and loads of loot, but too often enemies drop only useless stuff (weak weapons and armour for the most part). On the other hand, a decent number of powerful "relics" (weapons, armour) can be found in the most remote and dangerous areas of the game. These relics make a real difference in battle, especially as you can level them up (4 levels each) by simply having them equipped in battle. Levelled up to max, these relics are the most powerful items in the game.+/- You will often run into enemies who are simply too strong for your characters, requiring you to level up and get some better gear before you return. A classic feature, yes, but this can be annoying if you haven't yes found an area / dungeon where your characters can level up without the constant threat of getting killed by strong mobs.- Story is okay, delivered mostly by NPC "talking heads" (text only, speech in very rare cases) and books containing background information about the world and its history. Almost no dialogue choices for your characters. All in all, the story of main quest and side quests is serviceable, but not very engaging.- Quality of character models and textures ranges from "serviceable" to "eyesore".- No crafting. Would have been nice because too many of the weapons in shops or dropped by enemies are useless.- As of mid February 2014, annoying bugs still remain (parts of the environment turn invisible, quest rewards not given etc). Your mileage may vary; I did not encounter any quest-breaking bugs.All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this games to all fans of classic, turn-based RPGs. It's not perfect and still needs some patching - but there are simply tons of fun to be had while fighting and exploring.
