content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												short summary / Kurzzusammenfassung: game concept is quite nice, but too many bugs + flaws. / Spielkonzept ist ganz nett (habe auch einige andere M&M-Teile gespielt, es gibt aber zu viele Bugs und sonstige Mängellong versionafter playing several other rpg-style games from the M&M, the dark eye, D&D, gothic and alike series i was looking forward to play another nice game. After a quite nice start ( just a bit annoying expert/master/grandmaster-skillsystem ) the waiting on loads more and more angered me (takes 20s-1min per load). later on you will find out that it really sucks to come to an area which might be relevant for quests without picking those quests before. On some game-important occasions like promotion missions you will end up with an open quest unable to complete it, if you've been to the quest-relevant area before. other bugs will add up, you will have problems to become grandmaster on some skills before it stops to matter if you are, and so on and on. Some things can be fixed when using boards to understand the game scripts, but honestly: this shouldnt be a player's deal at all. Especially annoying are the relics. Of about 30 relics in the game about 2-5 might be of good use for your team, the rest is weaker than equipment that you can buy (granted you have the time to rest and reload often enough to reset shops), or you simply cannot use it with the party you chose. on late stages (about level 25-30), depending on your chosen skills and equipment, you either wont have any mentionable enemies (i killed the last boss of the main quest with 3 hits once), or you'll have quite some problems to win it. For example: there is equipment adding +6 of a certain skill. depending on the skill you can achieve 25 (grandmaster) + 48 (2x6 foki, 3x6 jewelry, and 3x6 other equipment) for magic skills, which is damn much OP. you also could try to become invulnurable, wich is no hard task with some of the characters (about 100 defense, about 100 resistences). but besides all that, at the end of the game you'll have to flee from a prison, having no equipment at start, being able to do lots of mistakes while fleeing. combined with the waiting time for reload, that was too much of frustration for me. even though i played that game quite some time, i cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												First off, the bad stuff. This game has a few frustrating elements put there by the developers. Poison will kill you, and quite quickly, and you get no warning that you need to get earth magic's cure poison or buy antidotes before you get poisoned the first time, although hopefully you will have picked up enough antifotes to be okay. Secondly, while both the team and monsters are locked in space when they enter a melee fight (which is fine), there is one boss that doesn't, and who is going to push the team to their death if the I guess random number generator wills it. Lastly, a couple of things are very difficult to find, and there's no abundance of hints to where to go and the voice acting isn't that great.Apart from that, Might and magic X is a truly brilliant game. You start off choosing a team of four characters whose skills will complement each other on their Quest through the Agyn peninsula. From there on, everything is grid and turn based. You will move square by square through an astonishing world with a lot, really a lot, of cool secrets you may have to go out of your way to find. The game is really well made for people who like to explore places, as the world is big, and the only thing keeping you from going places are monsters. You will need to save often, as you may be ambushed by too difficult monsters in the early game, but even really difficult monsters can often be overcome if you employ the right strategy. Mages are given powerful but costly control options, and there are lots of different strategies to employ to get past the bad guys. Being turn based, you can even change your equipment during your turn in combat, yielding very interesting options if you stack up on cool equipment. This results in a lot of digressions from the tasks at hand; the party will find a new nook or cave they want to explore while on their way to the next location. Except for interdependent quests, you can mosttimes do any quest you have in any order you'd like.While difficult monsters can often be overcome with the right tactics (or a couple of levels, there are always other things you want to do in the mean time), easy monsters can often kill the party if you don't pay attention. The simplest monsters give 5 xp, the toughest give you around 50, so you will never feel that you are too strong for an area, you simply spend less turns during each combat.One of the aspects that really got me in this game was all the puzzles. All the way through the land they have put mysterious crypts, where you need to solve a puzzle to get to the treasure, with no dangerous monsters to distract you. There are a lot of chests which requires you to answer a riddle correctly, and they are very fun to ponder about, especially if you're playing together with someone. I already said there are a lot of treasure in this game, and it is sometimes hidden due to the movement in the game. If there's a chest to your side, you won't notice it unless you face that direction, and as you can't face every wall all the time, you need to keep looking for small boxes or camuflaged chests you need to face.For the level system, I think it's good. every level gives you 4 attribute points, to be spread over strength, perception, destiny, magic, etc. with very clear effects. This makes sure your character gets better at what he/she does at every level. The character also gets 3 skill points, which can be spent on increasing skills. All the skills a character chan choose between, he/she can master to different degrees, expert (at 7 skill points), master (at 15) and grand master (at 25). At these scores, advancement needs to be bought from a skill specific trainer, which will give an extra boost and let the character advance further. There are 12 classes to choose between, and each has a different set of skill mastery possibilities, but each class needs to get promoted through a special quest to access gm training (range -> warden can gm bow, barbarian -> warmonger can gm two handed), so the game really makes you work to become better. I already mentioned that mages have interesting battle control options; the fighters also do. There's a skill called warfare, which grants spell like abilities (two more at each new level of mastery) like reducing armor or taunting enemies to attack that particular character. This makes any kind of team viable, and gives the game a lot of replay value. When I say any kind of team is viable, I mean it, character creation is not something you need to ponder a lot on, there will be ways to destroy every enemy with what you want to play. Also, at gm level, you will be insanely good, and your party will feel like living gods. This feels great.I had a lot of fun all the way through this game. They have managed to scare me through sending enemies on me that I didn't think I could handle, they have given me riddles and puzzles I didn't feel like I could handle, but I did, and it was great. If anything is too hard or obscure, you can always google it, you will still enjoy the world of asha. Turn based and grid based games aren't for everyone, and it's difficult to do it well. I hated legend of grimlock, as the movement was annoying, and you could kick difficult bosses asses by figuring out their movement patterns. What they did badly, MMX has done in a very smooth way. Id you liked the stroy part of Heroes VI, then you'll love this game, as they expand upon it with great pieces of lore scattered around (and a story that follows in the footstep of Heroes VI). If you played the old games, you will definitely love this one, as they have included lord Kilburn and Crag Hack, as well as lore about "Lord Caneghem".

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												I was unable to play the game once I entered the lighthouse due to what appeared to be a bug in the game, resulting in a downvote. I submitted a helpdesk ticket to ubisoft (I'm on mac, but they apparently don't admit to have a mac version, so I submitted it to the windows help desk) and got a useless response. They basically had me install every OS X update and some flash installers, none of which really helped. I felt like I had just called comcast and the script the "helpful" individual on the other end had them read the same thing, even if it was totally innappropriate. However, I changed my recommendation after following the directions in one of the steam forums. Apparently, this is a 32 bit game and, for mac users, you must find the actual program and mark it as such in order to get decent playability. Once you do, it is fine (though, not a stellar experience). I'm pretty sure Macs have been 64 bit for over 10 years now. But, maybe the code they are using is still 32 bit and they can't afford to have someone actually update it? Even the PC version isn't 10 years old...The game plays more or less like the old M&M games that came before it, but with better graphics. Having grown up with games like this, I prefer the turn based combat. There are some real problems, such as situations where the enemy you are fighting doesn't actually appear on your screen. However, you can still blow them away with fireballs, even if you have no clue where they are. I've seen pirates walk through walls to fight you, and combat turns for the opponent can take several minutes as the animations dig through to find you. All in all, this is a decent remake of those old school dungeon grinders that were king back in the 90s but modernized for semi modern hardware. If they put some work tuning the engine itself, it would probably be a great iPad or android game. Hopefully, it will get some attention and they'll fix some of the more annoying bugs (and maybe bring it into the 21rst centry of 64 bit hardware?). But, even now, it's a fun game that can be enjoyed for hours.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Yikes. Be sure you know what you are buying even if it is only $25. This is not just retro, it’s a trip back to the computer seventies. Movement is a square at a time. You are limited to the checkerboard regardless of what the picture looks like. Want your team to run off in a diagonal direction? Then get ready for a steady stream of left turn, forward, right turn, forward, left turn, forward, right turn, forward, etc. The enviroment is simply a desktop background. You can interact with very little that you see. There are no in-game physics. I don’t find this an immersive game play experience. There is some voice but mostly you will be reading lines. Team comments are limited, my team said “I think they smelled us, who hasn’t taken a bath?” at least 8 times in the 5 hours I've played. I’m not sure how much more of that I can take.Once an enemy is in sight you are most likely to become “engaged in combat.”   When you are in combat you cannot move, except to spin in place; and you cannot run away, a tactic that would be handy to use when you bump into an enemy too far advanced to handle early in the game. Not a deal breaker but another irritating thing about the new release is that you can't position your characters where you want in a formation. You can move them in the lineup but there is no overhead view or choice of formation. As far as I can tell, they are standing in a line. I loved the M&M series and looked forward to playing this with friends but I soon realized this is not the way I remember M&M.  With games like Skyrim, FarCry 3, Dead Island Riptide, M&MX is just too ancient to enjoy. I would have much preferred to see an M & M updated to accommodate free movement, an interactive environment and game physics like Skyrim et al. Such a game would have been interesting and I would have stood in line to plunk down $60 to play it.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Might & Magic X was a very positive surprise. The reviews were somewhat average, but I was looking for an old-style dungeon crawl and went ahead buying MMX shortly after it went out of early access. If you know what to expect (a tile and turned based game system), you might end up having a lot of fun with it.Graphics aren't the best, but look quite decent within dungeons (where you'll spent most of your time). I like the combat system, especially that you get the feeling of being in control and making good decisions without having to spent ages learning stats of weapons and spells. Almost 10 hours in, combat is still fun and I haven't encountered any frustrating difficulty spikes yet (although I faced some challenges).The story is rather weak, but then again, you're here for the dungeon crawl.I'm not a veteran MM player, but after MMX I'll definitely look into some of the classic parts of the series.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Highly recommend Might and Magic X - LegacyThe game is a perfect throwback to games I loved in the 80s and 90s.  It requires lots of thought to balance survivability and damage.  Putting a lot of thought into character development helps create an engrossing game experience.It's turn based, so it may appeal more to laidback gamers.  Success depends on planning, rather than mashing the keys at the right time.There is a great variety of spells and fighting styles, so for me there is replayability to try different spell schools and weapon types.I hope the developers make expansions based on this game, and look forward to the next edition.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												Fun game, lots of variety in party builds, good old school RPG gameplay (even has a retro-pixel mode!) but without the confusing sheets of numbers--everything is laid out for you to see and nothing is really hidden. Good puzzles with clever variety, challenging fights especially with some of the bosses, and an intriguing story as well. Having said this, the game does suffer from a lack of polish in terms of graphics and animations. It also uses Uplay which some people hate with a vengeance but I haven't had any problems with. But if you like Grimrock, baldur's gate, wizardry, or the older Might and Magic games (even 6, despite the lack of real-time mode in X), you'll find MMX quite satisfying.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												GREAT GAME.It's got the "soul" of the past Might and Magic games; lots of exploration, loot, character upgrades.  I had a great time.  It uses a lot of the same animation as the Heroes series, but the enemies are a little different in difficulty, to scale with the quests.The good: It's great fun if you loved the old M&M games or are new to the tile-based RPGs (Legend of Grimrock).  It will draw you in and you'll think about playing it and the next thing to do when away from it.The bad: It's Ubisoft, so it uses Uplay.The ugly: It didn't sell well enough early on so UBI is not planning a sequel.Update. Do NOT buy the DLC (Deluxe Version) "The Falcon and the Unicorn" if you have the chance. It's broken. It was clearly cobbled together and was not play tested before release.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2013
												This is a work in progress as of 2013-08-22 and an "early access" game.  Even so I expected a LOT more out of this but it falls sadly very, very short.  It's painful to play.  The older games are better.  The "grid" walking system is painful.  The combat is "meh".  The characters are flat and boring. The interface works but is sadly lacking.  The graphics - well, I think the older games looked better in their time than this does today.  The writing is so-so, the sound effects are re-used from older games (mostly) so there's some nostalgic value there but otherwise they're very bland.  Combat, the key activity in the game, is boring so far.  Again, the older games were more fun.  Maybe it's just me, maybe I'm not the gamer I used to be... but hopefully they'll fix this up and do it right.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2015
												I can say, will do a bit of a quick review. So won't get too much into detail, but will cover the basics.It is a overall quite neat game. Taking the classic dungeoncrawl approach and spicing it up a little. While the graphic are notably ripped from heroes 6, I don't mind at all. After all, why waste assets when they have them? And they work well within the world so.That said, the game has some MASSIVE flaws, and some small annoyances.Can start with the small ones: For starters, there are too few lines of spoken dialog in this. Even with a diverse group, basically 70 % of all lines are identitcal between characters. Not that many, but heck, it's not far from it. They seriously cheaped out on that. The dialog that exist is pretty well done. But yeah, it incredibly fast gets repetitive  the 482'th time. Sometimes you can hear the same line 12+ times per minute. Depending on the situation.Secondly it's that, while more of a "read up on it, scrub" thing, your "talent tree" is something you heavily need to invest in, and plan ahead. You're not allowed to just pick it as you go, it became clear to me a bit in that I would have needed to plan my build from the start. As some skills are just far too vital not to have. Like how you literally can't complete certain dungeons without having certain spells and/or immunities.And while mostly a aestetic thing. It feels a bit dumb how you start as this "kinda pro adventuring party" with basically 0 equipment or skills. I get that you have to build your way up, but it's kinda derp how you're these supposedly bad♥♥♥♥♥"Raiders", and you have some rusty, duct taped gear and barely know how to slap someone xP Not to mention: The game ocassionally forgets your UI, and resests some buttons to the "default" potion combination. Not a big annoyance, but can be a nuisance. Atop that, it seems some of the DLC content is bugged. I cashed in a reward for the deluxe edition package, but the item for it was never delivered, yet it claimed it had been cashed in.Now, for the massive flaws of this game in no particular order: (I was debating a bit wheter or not I would recommend this game, but in the end, it is a nice game. Yes, it will frustrate you a lot. But it has enough enjoyable moments to mostly weigh it up)1: The loading times are far too long.  It's not to bad in the start. But later in the game, these become a massive bother. ESPECIALLY as the game refuse to load if you are tabbed out. So you can't enter a dungeon or the like, then tab out, check a few things and tab back in during the up to 30+ second long loadingscreens. This becomes ESPECIALLY annoying due to the next in this list, which will force you to repeatedly re-load over and over and over and over and over. It's just a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way to pad on extra hours of gameplay.2: The RNG creep. I could be that I had a bad party combo. But some enemies just get plain stupid with this. Most of the undead are a great example of this. With one lucky hit, and many enemies seem to have 20-40 % crit chance, they can, and will 1-shot any non-tank party member. Just like that. Poof. And there's nothing you can do about it aside from spam protective spells. Which, makes you unable to attack. While they normally hit for like, 41 damage, when they crit, it can be anywhere from 180-260 damage if they feel like it. And when a ex: magic hero at that level has around 100 hp, they're just toast. So at many places, you just have to save, enter combat, hope RNG doesn't screw you over, if so, load and rinse and repeat. You're not being challanged the least, your patience is just being tested. 3: Broken skills and events. Some abilities don't work on enemies, or are outright broken. Like how if you stun an enemy, they can still retaliate, block and all that. While you aren't allowed to do so if stunned as a character. And there's dozens of design flaws like that around. And some events break when you save at a particular palce or time. Like, one event in a crow temple, an entire encouter crashes and vanishes if you save after you talk to a spirit. Which mind you, is a place with the issue in 2 mentioned. So you have to save before you talk to them. Talk to them, enter fight and hope each turn you don't have the ~5-10 % chance of getting instantly killed and be force to load, while you try to take down 6 enemies  at both sides of you with like, 1500 hp each. Each one of these capable to 1 shot your non-tanks. Currently at that fight as I am writing this, and have been for around 2 hours, 1 of which has just been pure loading time. For a game so heavily reliant on QS and QL, this type of droll padding just isn't acceptable. I'd at most expet 5-10 second loading time, at most. Many parts of this game is pure trial and error via RNG. Atop that, you only get experience for enemies if a hero is alive, and without and negative condition on them. Like what? My mage didn't learn anything at all from figthing a dragon, just becuase she got backhanded by said dragon and stunned, and her magical boots managed to kill the dragon? She had to be fully aware and witness as the dragon died, or else the entire fight was just some dull pasttime she couldn't learn anything from?4: No ability to flee. For a game that places it's level 20 monsters next to it's level 1 obligatory giant rats. This is such a huge design flaw I don't even know what to say... It's like removing/not including a dodge or block manouver in a fighting game... like, the actual murloc? This ties heavily in with the save/load issue. As, every time you find something new or a new area, you are forced to save to know if you even are allowed to be there, before you head on in. Your entire party got 1-shotted by a magically farting spider? Welp, you better load then, possinly after being forced through a game over screen, to then be made to wait a total of 1 minute before you are allowed back in. It's just not acceptable as said with the massive amounts of lazy padding this game has. It's like... it's a great game in here, why was so much bad descisions stuffed into it? Despite this being a late, patched version of the game. I really fear how terrible it must have been at launch.  There's seriusly a good game in here. It's just brutally hampered by multiple poor choices and design errors.I think this wraps up most of it... but yeah. I'd perhaps give a 6.5 out of ten? Nice game, but far too often just plain frustrating. Just knowing that "Oh, I see my tactic and team was irrelevant here, I just wans't lucky enough with the dice rolls to progress... better spend a mintute reloading the... not saying RNG is always bad. But when it becomes a major part of the game itself... it's just frustarting. Adding numbers or making the AI cheat just to upp the difficulty is just poor design. Yes, I know it's sort of "needed"sometimes, but it's very tacky regardless. There's just far too many areas where you're simply not allowed to do anything to affect the outcome of things. Or would have had to play the game prior to know which things to bring where.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Fantastic turn-based, grid-based fantasy RPG.  Similar to Legend of Grimrock, but bigger and better in most respects.  Play on the warrior difficulty for a serious, but fair challenge.  There's not a lot of hand-holding -- with riddles, puzzles, and high-level mobs strewn about the continent.  It's an interesting, loot-filled, and occasionally unforgiving dungeon crawler, and I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												As a hardcore M&M series gamer and have finished this game. What this game lacks can be described in one word and that word is grandness. Start with music department. It is relatively weak and as I am writing this, I can't remember any of its melody. Whereas if I am asked to play music from M&M 6 on a piano now. I can do it in a heartbeat and it was more than 16 years ago since I first played M&M 6. Next thing is items. In Legacy, items are represented by small icons inside inventory window. How lame is that. A two-handed axe has the same dimension and takes up the same amount of spaces as an one-handed dagger. It just feels cheap and low quality. Another thing M&M 6 outshines Legacy is  critters. Where are titans, medusas and dragons? You even get to kill angels in previous games. In Legacy, minotaurs are pretty much the only epic monster left. And it is introduced early in the game (Act 2). By the time you reache the end, most of the monsters you are fighting are human like. If I want to kill human, I might as well be playing Battlefield 4.However, this game has shown some improvements. Improvements like spells. In Legacy, they have removed many useless spells. But dark school magic is still a waste of time once you reach expert level. Battles are not as grand but require more tactic. Map and towns are not huge, if you like sightseeing you may get disapointed. But the good part is that you don't waste too much time travelling around. Overall, this is a good game. If you are looking for an old school RPG. This is it. If you are a M&M fan looking for something that would blow every M&M game out of water. You may get disappointed. But Legacy is certainly worth a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												7.5/10. As a MM fan having played all MM games, this game actually succeeds in capturing the MM charme and spirit! It is nice to level up, train with trainers, and get to Expert, Master and GM status. The game is well balanced, quite difficult at the beginning, so that you will need to come back later for some bosses, and even in late game, remains challenging. The size of the game is nice, also that there are some riddles and puzzles in the dungeons.Negative: Graphics outdated, bad decisions in the beginning (many experts, Masters are not accessible until later acts, as they are located in cities you cant access!), a lot of walking around due to lack of decent teleport system; weak presentation of the "story". Last, UPLAY does not work properly if game is bought through Steam... you need to contact Support to be able to get UPlay points and unlock Rewards (worked with al other UPlay gmaes I have).All in all, a nice and addicting RPG similar to older MM titles, which could have been grand with a higher budget and a better engine, but delivers on what it tries to be. Too bad it was no success, and likely there will be no future games like this.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												The game is ok-ish at best. I am a huge Might & Magic fan and I always go back to mm6, mm7 and mm8.The game kinda stays in the same category and it can be a pleasant experience.There are a few things which put me off :1. Grid based movement. I mean 3DO build a world where you could move freely and so many years later Ubisoft can't do the same ? Really bad.2. The game is very small and the story lacking compared to any previous game.3. No flying !4. The biggest turn off for me was the complete lack of gear display. In any M&M game you could see the appearance of your character changing with every piece of gear equipped. You could what an armour looks like, on your character. This is actually very important for an RPG game. M&M X - no, sorry, w can't allow you to see that.5. skill advancement is blocked so you can't invest points as you could before. Once you hit the max level in a skill that's it, rogression stopped.All these things aside, the game is fun and worth playing. It can be challenging especially on warrior difficulty. If you liked the previous M&M games you will learn to love this one as well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												+ Nice combination of old school turn-based RPG and modern comfort features (annotatable automap, easy comparison between different items via mouse-over, rest anywhere instead of only in safe zones etc).+ Turn-based battles require a lot of micro-management of your character's spells and skills. For me, it was a great part of the fun of MMX - for other players this might be a turn-off.+ Thoughtful management of your character's attributes and new skill points is a must - but it's also very rewarding when you reach a new weapon proficiency or finally master a new, powerful spell.+ Decent variety of enemies, though there are only about two to three different types per dungeon / overworld area. Each type of enemy has different resistances and skills - you have to adapt your attacks / buffs / debuffs accordingly.+/- Loads and loads of loot, but too often enemies drop only useless stuff (weak weapons and armour for the most part). On the other hand, a decent number of powerful "relics" (weapons, armour) can be found in the most remote and dangerous areas of the game. These relics make a real difference in battle, especially as you can level them up (4 levels each) by simply having them equipped in battle. Levelled up to max, these relics are the most powerful items in the game.+/- You will often run into enemies who are simply too strong for your characters, requiring you to level up and get some better gear before you return. A classic feature, yes, but this can be annoying if you haven't yes found an area / dungeon where your characters can level up without the constant threat of getting killed by strong mobs.- Story is okay, delivered mostly by NPC "talking heads" (text only, speech in very rare cases) and books containing background information about the world and its history. Almost no dialogue choices for your characters. All in all, the story of main quest and side quests is serviceable, but not very engaging.- Quality of character models and textures ranges from "serviceable" to "eyesore".- No crafting. Would have been nice because too many of the weapons in shops or dropped by enemies are useless.- As of mid February 2014, annoying bugs still remain (parts of the environment turn invisible, quest rewards not given etc). Your mileage may vary; I did not encounter any quest-breaking bugs.All in all, I wholeheartedly recommend this games to all fans of classic, turn-based RPGs. It's not perfect and still needs some patching - but there are simply tons of fun to be had while fighting and exploring.

												If you enjoyed the old Might & Magic games, this is OK for a couple of hours, but once the nostalgia wears off, there's not much reason to keep playing.  The format is very dated compared to modern role-playing games, and other than updated graphics, this is backwards step compared to the older games - it's much smaller and simpler, and missing many of the features that made the series interesting (e.g. potion mixing, arcomage card game).  Movement is constrained to a fixed grid and real-time play has been completely removed.  Combat locks you in place, and you can get a wide range of difficulty of monsters in a small area, so it's easy to find yourself up against something you can't beat with no means of running away.I bought the version that comes with a copy of M&M VI, and it says a lot that I've spent far more time playing that!

												Old-school rpg in a new coat. Skins and models are ripped of Heroes 5 and 6, sounds are rather nice (albeit there could be more variations), ingame art is OK. Game is more action-based, but there are passages for storytelling and side questlines with some memorable/funny moments. Game is oriented towards might and magic fans, who will be able to "get" some  hidden puns and jokes. Combat can be tough sometimes (on warrior difficulty), but it promotes synergy between characters and once you understand how things work, you should not have any significant problems. As far as I can tell, there many working "builds" for characters, so you do not need to rely on certain auto-include skills/spells, but basic party structure still applies here - someone to soak dmg, someone to heal and someone to do dmg.All in all I can recommend this game as solid and enjoyable RPG, for those who like to spend some time thinking how to make a party work and then apply it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												A Welcome Return To Old School RPG GamingFor the tl;dr crowd:Pros:* Really truly does recapture the feeling of old school Might & Magic games, particularly the World of Xeen games (which was what this was patterned after)* Tough but fair* Strategic combatCons:* Optimization issues* Requires UPlay (It's Ubisoft, no way around UPlay, unfortunately)Now for the long winded review:When I first heard about this game I was first of all shocked, as it had been so long since a core Might & Magic game had been released (I bet there is a contingent of people that prior to the release of this game though Heroes of Might & Magic was the core series, rather than the spinoff it is) that I just assumed the series was dead and buried.  I was both excited and a bit scared.  Excited because holy smokes a new core Might & Magic game!  Scared because it was being made by a developer I didn't really know and that had, to the best of my knowledge, no prior experience making an old school RPG like this.  Would they be able to recapture the Might & Magic feeling?  Would they get the mechanics right?  Would they try to modernize it too much?After reading up on the team and following their blog for a bit, it became apparent that these people were a fan of the games and genuinely passionate about making an old school RPG.  They also revealed that they were patterning this game after World of Xeen (M&M 4 & 5), going with turn-based and grid-based, rather than free movement and real-time, like M&M 6-9.  While I enjoyed M&M 6-8 quite a bit, 9 not so much, I was also a huge fan of the World of Xeen games and was happy with this decision, so I decided to pull the trigger and get this.I can now happily say that I chose wisely.  This game has exceeded my expectations.  While the game isn't exactly pushing graphical boundaries and there are some jarringly low res models and textures mixed in, the game is plenty pretty enough for my tastes and it has a certain charm to it.  I suspect Ubisoft didn't exactly give Limbic a massive budget to work with, so I wasn't expecting The Witcher 2 levels of eye candy.  Much more importantly, this is an honest to goodness old school Might & Magic game.  The setting and story follow the Heroes of Might & Magic games timeline rather than M&M 9, but mechanically they really did a great job of recreating the World of Xeen gameplay.There are 12 classes among 4 races to choose from (3 per race) filling the roles of fighters, casters, and various hybrids in between.  The game doesn't hold your hand and you learn on the job, which may be a turn off for some gamers, but is very welcome in my book.  Certain class combinations will work better than other, and it's certainly possible to build a party that's going to get stomped in the game, but there is room for a variety of different viable combination.  Balanced parties (a mix of warrior and mage types) will naturally work the best, as they usually do in RPGs, but it's possible to go mage-heavy (though you will burn through a lot of mana potions) or warrior-heavy and still succeed.The game is quite challenging, but not cheap.  There are 2 difficulty settings:  Adventurer and Warrior, corresponding to Normal and Hard respectively, though, compared to the average game of these days, they're more like Hard and Very Hard.  This game will kick your behind and you will die.  There is no sleepwalking through fights except for the most basic of weak enemies.  If you try to sleepwalk on simply brute force your way (even with a warrior-heavy party) through battles you will get destroyed.  You have to use your head to survive.  The game constantly puts you into confrontations where you are surviving by your wits and the skin of your teeth, and that's on Adventurer difficulty.  Warrior difficulty is straight up punishing, and I love it!There is a good bit of strategy in using your various spells and abilities to protect yourself, buff your allies, debuff enemies, debilitate them, and deal damage.  Plus the grid-based movement adds another layer of tactics, making for a chess-like game of maneuvering where you try to lure ranged enemies into melee without getting pelted by arrows and spells while advancing on them, or getting as many "free" volleys of arrows on melee enemies before they close to melee, all while being mindful of the terrain to position yourself in a spot to prevent being flanked or surrounded.  It's a well thought out system that forces you to use all the skills at your disposal.  It can seem overwhelming when you're caught off guard and a group of enemies creeps up behind you while other enemies close in from the front and you're caught in a vice in a seemingly hopeless battle, frantically trying to keep your party members alive while trying to take out key enemies before they can demolish you.  But when you survive a battle like that, it's that much more satisfying, so much better than mindlessly steamrolling through trash mobs like in so many RPGs.  In conclusion, Might & Magic is a throwback to the RPGs of the 80s and the 90s, with much of the good and the bad that comes with that.  It's a wonderful nostalgia ride and Limbic did a terrific job of delivering an authentic old school RPG experience.  It's thoroughly challenging and quite satisfying.  If you're looking for an old-school turn-based RPG romp, look no further.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game has some potential, but the irritating design choices overwhelm that potential in my mind.First off, "open world" this game is not.  You have exactly one direction you can go through the first town, you can't even leave town without finishing a railroad quest, unless I missed something.  And even after leaving your world is made up of "you can go to X different dungeons, but X-1 of them will kill you instantly" so you really just have the illusion of choice.  Maybe it opens up past the first region, but if you have to get that far in to a game for it to be open world, it isn't.This railroading leads to the biggest issue I have compared to the old games, party composition.  I'm sure some dedicated players will be able to prove me wrong but I honestly don't feel like most party combinations will be viable in this game because of the mission you have to do before leaving town.  In the old games you could run a full ranged party and soften things up enough before they get to you if you were willing to accept that sometimes you don't soften them up enough and you get stomped.  This game doesn't seem to make that an option since there is no way to skip the first dungeon and it railroads you in to melees without the chance for an opening volley.  And that's not even considering the spells you have to run if you want to be able to explore everything.  Don't have a good coverage of the spell schools?  Prepare to miss a lot or use a guide.Even with these issues aside the mechanics just don't feel like they're there.  Outside of your weapons skills skill increases just don't seem to do much. For instance, armor skills reduce your penalty to wear armor, so if you've already negated the penalty it's just a waste of a point to put them there until you find the trainer or better armor. Unlike the old games you can't increase skills past a certain point without finding a trainer, so you end up maxing out your barbarian's mace and two-hander skills and then just throwing points into other things at random, or saving them until you can find the trainers, making your progression slam in to a wall.  Battles are just slug fests with both sides having what feels like high chances to block or dodge, which makes poison especially irritating since there's no, apparent, way to resist it and you can go three turns without anybody hitting someone if you're unlucky.  Any sort of incapacitation keeps that character from gaining XP, yes, even stun, so you find yourself stalling a battle so your tank will wake up and gain XP from the kill, only for the mage to get stunned and you to have to wait again.Overall there are just too many little issues that build up to make this game not fun, and there are too many games out there to waste time on one that's frustrating and not fun.  I feel bad for Limbic but hopefully this game got enough attention that Ubisoft will get someone that knows what they're doing, and has at least played a Might and Magic game before, for another attempt, because this could have been good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												I loved it and had a great time playing it, but you may not.  So, let's discuss it's progency, for a moment.The game owes it's existence to the joyful Legend of Grimrock, which did a great job updating the games of my youth.  MMX is an even more direct throwback to the original Bard's Tale in 1985.  The Bard's Tale took Wizardry and added outdoor areas.  Sure, they weren't that different -- they were basically dungeons with sky blue tiles as opposed to underground grey and brown tiles, but the effect worked on me.  If you have some nostalgia for the early days of RPG gaming, this will likely hit a home run.  It reminds me of playing games on my Apple II, even including watching the graphics render.  What I really enjoyed most was developing my characters and watching them become increasingly powerful.  I wanted them well prepared for the final battle, and there are many opportunities to improve their skills and their loot.Pros:- RPG nostalgia- Good skills and character development options- Good magic system- The individual quests and dungeon were mostly fun- Combat is well done- To me, at least, the game is almost perfectly balanced (with the stock party).  Only toward the end did I begin to feel overpowered.  Most of the game, the battles were close and tense, but rarely did my entire party die.- Great opportunities for exploration -- there is always something new to find- No monster respawns!!  Once you clear an area, it stays clear.  I like that.Cons:- Graphics look good, but take a long time to render.  At one point, the landscape renders well before the castle sitting on the landscape renders.  That's just weird.- Members have your party have comments about everything going on around them.  I love that.  Except that they repeat the same things over and over and over again.  We get it... human cities are as dangerous as the jungle.  Let's move on.  When characters finish a major battle, they cheer an entirely disingenuous "Yay!"  It sounds exactly like a bunch of poorly paid actors sitting around their home microphones trying to appear enthusiastic.-  With some exceptions, most of the battles use pretty much the same tactics.  I had the same criticism of Dragon Age.  So this game is not unique, in this regard.I've invested about 55 hours into this game.  And I had a lot of fun doing it.  If you have  a soft spot in your heart for the RPG dungeon-crawling heyday of the 80s, I think you'll really enjoy this.  I sure did.

												First of all: ♥♥♥♥ uplay.I seriously hate this godawful ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t excuse of a software as much I hate "origin". And that says much.I guess cloud synchronizing save-game files is just too much of a feature to ask these days, huh? Just delete that♥♥♥♥♥♥and do it properly in Steam along with everything else instead of trying to push your useless subpar piece of software.Now, to the game:It's incredible. I love it to pieces, 24 hours in I am nowhere near final stages of the game it seems. If you liked Classic M&M - you will like this most likely. It does stray from some of the canons of 6-8, sometimes back to the roots, sometimes just keeping in tune with current-gen design practices. But the main - the feel of M&M is there, and it's gorgeous. I wouldn't try to compare it to Legend of Grimrock (though the comparisons really jumps to mind), because essentially the things that are great about this game are non-existent in LoG (Lore, colorful world, variety of characters, skills and systems) and vise a versa the things that made LoG great are a bit on the sidelines here (secrets are a plainer system, puzzles are not that convoluted, combat system not dynamic at all (it's actually Turn-based here), I would even say the graphics were a bit more spot on in LoG.Nevertheless, If you have waited for this game: buy it now, you will not regret it.If you haven't waited for this game: check out the videos to see if it's something that you might enjoy and probably give MM 6/8 a whirl first before picking this up, because that's an immortal cllassic. I cannot fully say this one is too, because I do see some problems with it. I guess 50 hours later I'll see! =)

content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												So you want to play a retro game? Remember a few things about the past games first. The difficulty level will be ramped up, there will be no hand holding, you will have to think not click past fights. No NPC with explanation points, its trial and error and dialog trees to get quests. Long time burns to go from place to place with unfair fights that you have to avoid for a while then come back to when you level up. This is the core of the original games and its a fresh breeze of awesomeness. So many new games are click fests, afraid to make the game too difficult for people. Not here, its not Dark Souls but it is very much Might and Magic. It will be a bit too hard for the average ADD click kid but if you have a level head and are willing to learn and grow with a game this will be your ticket. It has flaws still but forgivable flaws. My guess is in just a few months this should be a well polished game that will no doubt make me happy for quite a while.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I love this game, it has surpassed all my expectations.Yes, it's low budget, but what do you expect from such a niche title being released by a big publisher? Yes, it's turn-based and you move your party around on a grid. This makes the combat fairly tactical (especially since it's pretty well balanced) and a ton of fun, but if you don't like that kind of thing then stay away.It's also a difficult game at times, and there are places you won't be able to go at first because the monsters are too tough. But it rewards planning ahead in tough fights, and if you still can't win you can usually come back later when you're more powerful and have a satisfying time wiping the floor with your enemies.I'm seriously surprised that this game turned out as good as it did, I hope it sells well enough for expansions and sequels because I'd love to play more of this game on a new quest.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												Old-school rpg in a new coat. Skins and models are ripped of Heroes 5 and 6, sounds are rather nice (albeit there could be more variations), ingame art is OK. Game is more action-based, but there are passages for storytelling and side questlines with some memorable/funny moments. Game is oriented towards might and magic fans, who will be able to "get" some  hidden puns and jokes. Combat can be tough sometimes (on warrior difficulty), but it promotes synergy between characters and once you understand how things work, you should not have any significant problems. As far as I can tell, there many working "builds" for characters, so you do not need to rely on certain auto-include skills/spells, but basic party structure still applies here - someone to soak dmg, someone to heal and someone to do dmg.All in all I can recommend this game as solid and enjoyable RPG, for those who like to spend some time thinking how to make a party work and then apply it.

Posted: January 31, 2014
												First and foremost this game is RETRO!!! Which means all you noob gamers weened on skyrim and all the fancy flashy graphics and refined systems of modern day gaming...get over yourself and pay homage to history. I played World of Xeen back in the 90s when it first came out, and since then have played every Might and magic game I could, including the heroes games and every spin off etc. I mention Xeen specifically because this game is basically the great gand child of that game and all the games to come between then and now were just pretenders to the throne. I do my homework, I read every publication of every review for every game I buy without fail, I start with meta critic and work my way down the list via thier links. And every mouth breathing tard wanting to put down a few black and white pixels about the shortcomings of this game obviously missed the point of RETRO!!! Forget the reviews dont listen to the nay sayers every single part of this game was made intentionally, the grid system the combat, the OP enemies early on. Its all about the ambiance, and the history and the very concept of a game of this ilk. Its funny too cause you read reviews on games that scream RETRO!!!! fromt he start and they are considered masterpieces of old school gaming and should be admired for thier edgy psuedo-historical content. Most of the are garbage to be honest and just some lazy indie developer trying to get recognized or paid. Its a great game, well crafted and rich in content and ideas. Go in with a retro mindset and dont try to compare it to every modern game out there, appreciate it for its commitment to history, and wallow in its "hardcore" difficulty and most of all be proud of yourself for playing a true masterpiece of gaming, because to be honest, in this day and age we all eat enough garbage in our entertainment media, gems like this should never be overlooked.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Disclaimer: This review is influenced by nostalgia.I grew up on Might & Magic and Wizardry games, and my favorite was the combined package of M&M 4/5 that was World of Xeen. It's to them that Legacy's core gameplay pays homage. You move your party of four on a grid in the first person. Everything functions in a turn based manner, and your party fights small groups, not armies. I'll admit that when Might and Magic 6 came out, I was a bit disappointed in that changes in the game mechanics. That's not to say I didn't enjoy the game, but I didn't care for the, admittedly optional, real time mode. With that in mind, I'm very happy with how Legacy draws many of its movement mechanics from my preferred games in the series. Legacy does use M&M6+'s (in my opinion) superior skill point distribution levelling system, allowing for a bit more hands-on customization of your character's progression. Unfortunately, your options for race/class combinations are a bit limited compared to previous games. There are four races to choose from, and each race has its own warrior/scout/magic classes that are not available between races. In other words, you choose the PC's race, and then each race has three class options. Want a dwarven tank based fighter? Great, they have that. Want a dwarf who specializes two handed damage dealing? No option for that, sorry. There are still plenty of very good options to choose from, and each class feels useful in its own right. In a game that can be difficult if you don't have the right combination of classes, I'm guessing this is a way to more clearly define the player's options, but I admit I miss the extra bit of customization that the previous games allowed.Speaking of character customization, it's one place I feel the game dropped the ball. For each race, there are 4 portraits, two male and two female, to choose from. Decide your fighter should be an orc female? Your portrait options are A or B, regardless of class. Same with voices. Each race has a male heroic or cynical and a female heroic or cynical option, which sound to me like they're voiced by the same person, but saying different things. While it's a somewhat minor complaint, it makes it harder to feel like some of the characters are mine with the limited options. Still, for the caveats and minor gripes I have, I can't forget to emphasize that the game is fun. It's a classic system in a more modern wrapper, but it's a classic system that I did, and still do, love. The dungeons are fun, the monsters are well done, bosses are appropriately tougher than the fodder you cut through to get to them, and while the world feels a little small compared to some of the old Might and Magic games, it's been an engaging and entertaining ride so far. If you really didn't like the grid based system and smaller fights of the earlier entries in the series, this might not be the game for you. However, if you do enjoy those older entries of the series, then you'll likely find Might and Magic X an enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												A Welcome Return To Old School RPG GamingFor the tl;dr crowd:Pros:* Really truly does recapture the feeling of old school Might & Magic games, particularly the World of Xeen games (which was what this was patterned after)* Tough but fair* Strategic combatCons:* Optimization issues* Requires UPlay (It's Ubisoft, no way around UPlay, unfortunately)Now for the long winded review:When I first heard about this game I was first of all shocked, as it had been so long since a core Might & Magic game had been released (I bet there is a contingent of people that prior to the release of this game though Heroes of Might & Magic was the core series, rather than the spinoff it is) that I just assumed the series was dead and buried.  I was both excited and a bit scared.  Excited because holy smokes a new core Might & Magic game!  Scared because it was being made by a developer I didn't really know and that had, to the best of my knowledge, no prior experience making an old school RPG like this.  Would they be able to recapture the Might & Magic feeling?  Would they get the mechanics right?  Would they try to modernize it too much?After reading up on the team and following their blog for a bit, it became apparent that these people were a fan of the games and genuinely passionate about making an old school RPG.  They also revealed that they were patterning this game after World of Xeen (M&M 4 & 5), going with turn-based and grid-based, rather than free movement and real-time, like M&M 6-9.  While I enjoyed M&M 6-8 quite a bit, 9 not so much, I was also a huge fan of the World of Xeen games and was happy with this decision, so I decided to pull the trigger and get this.I can now happily say that I chose wisely.  This game has exceeded my expectations.  While the game isn't exactly pushing graphical boundaries and there are some jarringly low res models and textures mixed in, the game is plenty pretty enough for my tastes and it has a certain charm to it.  I suspect Ubisoft didn't exactly give Limbic a massive budget to work with, so I wasn't expecting The Witcher 2 levels of eye candy.  Much more importantly, this is an honest to goodness old school Might & Magic game.  The setting and story follow the Heroes of Might & Magic games timeline rather than M&M 9, but mechanically they really did a great job of recreating the World of Xeen gameplay.There are 12 classes among 4 races to choose from (3 per race) filling the roles of fighters, casters, and various hybrids in between.  The game doesn't hold your hand and you learn on the job, which may be a turn off for some gamers, but is very welcome in my book.  Certain class combinations will work better than other, and it's certainly possible to build a party that's going to get stomped in the game, but there is room for a variety of different viable combination.  Balanced parties (a mix of warrior and mage types) will naturally work the best, as they usually do in RPGs, but it's possible to go mage-heavy (though you will burn through a lot of mana potions) or warrior-heavy and still succeed.The game is quite challenging, but not cheap.  There are 2 difficulty settings:  Adventurer and Warrior, corresponding to Normal and Hard respectively, though, compared to the average game of these days, they're more like Hard and Very Hard.  This game will kick your behind and you will die.  There is no sleepwalking through fights except for the most basic of weak enemies.  If you try to sleepwalk on simply brute force your way (even with a warrior-heavy party) through battles you will get destroyed.  You have to use your head to survive.  The game constantly puts you into confrontations where you are surviving by your wits and the skin of your teeth, and that's on Adventurer difficulty.  Warrior difficulty is straight up punishing, and I love it!There is a good bit of strategy in using your various spells and abilities to protect yourself, buff your allies, debuff enemies, debilitate them, and deal damage.  Plus the grid-based movement adds another layer of tactics, making for a chess-like game of maneuvering where you try to lure ranged enemies into melee without getting pelted by arrows and spells while advancing on them, or getting as many "free" volleys of arrows on melee enemies before they close to melee, all while being mindful of the terrain to position yourself in a spot to prevent being flanked or surrounded.  It's a well thought out system that forces you to use all the skills at your disposal.  It can seem overwhelming when you're caught off guard and a group of enemies creeps up behind you while other enemies close in from the front and you're caught in a vice in a seemingly hopeless battle, frantically trying to keep your party members alive while trying to take out key enemies before they can demolish you.  But when you survive a battle like that, it's that much more satisfying, so much better than mindlessly steamrolling through trash mobs like in so many RPGs.  In conclusion, Might & Magic is a throwback to the RPGs of the 80s and the 90s, with much of the good and the bad that comes with that.  It's a wonderful nostalgia ride and Limbic did a terrific job of delivering an authentic old school RPG experience.  It's thoroughly challenging and quite satisfying.  If you're looking for an old-school turn-based RPG romp, look no further.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												This game has some potential, but the irritating design choices overwhelm that potential in my mind.First off, "open world" this game is not.  You have exactly one direction you can go through the first town, you can't even leave town without finishing a railroad quest, unless I missed something.  And even after leaving your world is made up of "you can go to X different dungeons, but X-1 of them will kill you instantly" so you really just have the illusion of choice.  Maybe it opens up past the first region, but if you have to get that far in to a game for it to be open world, it isn't.This railroading leads to the biggest issue I have compared to the old games, party composition.  I'm sure some dedicated players will be able to prove me wrong but I honestly don't feel like most party combinations will be viable in this game because of the mission you have to do before leaving town.  In the old games you could run a full ranged party and soften things up enough before they get to you if you were willing to accept that sometimes you don't soften them up enough and you get stomped.  This game doesn't seem to make that an option since there is no way to skip the first dungeon and it railroads you in to melees without the chance for an opening volley.  And that's not even considering the spells you have to run if you want to be able to explore everything.  Don't have a good coverage of the spell schools?  Prepare to miss a lot or use a guide.Even with these issues aside the mechanics just don't feel like they're there.  Outside of your weapons skills skill increases just don't seem to do much. For instance, armor skills reduce your penalty to wear armor, so if you've already negated the penalty it's just a waste of a point to put them there until you find the trainer or better armor. Unlike the old games you can't increase skills past a certain point without finding a trainer, so you end up maxing out your barbarian's mace and two-hander skills and then just throwing points into other things at random, or saving them until you can find the trainers, making your progression slam in to a wall.  Battles are just slug fests with both sides having what feels like high chances to block or dodge, which makes poison especially irritating since there's no, apparent, way to resist it and you can go three turns without anybody hitting someone if you're unlucky.  Any sort of incapacitation keeps that character from gaining XP, yes, even stun, so you find yourself stalling a battle so your tank will wake up and gain XP from the kill, only for the mage to get stunned and you to have to wait again.Overall there are just too many little issues that build up to make this game not fun, and there are too many games out there to waste time on one that's frustrating and not fun.  I feel bad for Limbic but hopefully this game got enough attention that Ubisoft will get someone that knows what they're doing, and has at least played a Might and Magic game before, for another attempt, because this could have been good.

												I don't write reviews, ever.  But being long-time M&M/Wizardry fan, I felt I needed to dispel some of the myths about this game.  I'm playing the game on a macbook 2011, with no problems running in 32-bit mode.  Gorgeous game, great interface, challenging battles, great puzzles, and funny references.  I've put some time in this game, and I'm on my first playthrough.  I have ignored butt-aches to play for another thirty minutes.  I am definitely playing this again once I complete it.  First let me say that reviewers that say you should min/max your skills, or you have to play a certain race/class combination are so so wrong.  I get a chuckle out of thinking of players not using rangers.  Now that I'm in the later stages of the game, monsters should feel privelaged to be able to survive long enough to get into melee range.  I love the turn-based combat and strategy.  Everything about this game makes sense.  If you liked the good ole days of Xeen, you will love this adventure.  Get it.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Yo, if you like old school RPGs in the veins of say the Might and Magic series or Lands of Lore you need to get this. It runs on a grid so it's less fluid than Escape from Grimrock (another game that harkens back to the time of old school RPGS), but that gives it an even greater retro charm, hell it even has an option for fuzzy retro graphics. It pays greatest homage to Might and Magic 1-4, it still does give refrences to six and seven (seven being my absolute favorite of the series). It even gives the synopsis of the plots for each previous game in in-game lore books while maintaining the new lore and world.Though character creation is limited to four races with three classes for each race, it's still not as bad as Might Magic XIII's character creation (IDK about you guys but that game had the worst race/class choices in the series). Combat can be a bit buggy at times, the latest patch seems to have fixed a lot of the release issues, so I can now give this game my full approval.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												short summary / Kurzzusammenfassung: game concept is quite nice, but too many bugs + flaws. / Spielkonzept ist ganz nett (habe auch einige andere M&M-Teile gespielt, es gibt aber zu viele Bugs und sonstige Mängellong versionafter playing several other rpg-style games from the M&M, the dark eye, D&D, gothic and alike series i was looking forward to play another nice game. After a quite nice start ( just a bit annoying expert/master/grandmaster-skillsystem ) the waiting on loads more and more angered me (takes 20s-1min per load). later on you will find out that it really sucks to come to an area which might be relevant for quests without picking those quests before. On some game-important occasions like promotion missions you will end up with an open quest unable to complete it, if you've been to the quest-relevant area before. other bugs will add up, you will have problems to become grandmaster on some skills before it stops to matter if you are, and so on and on. Some things can be fixed when using boards to understand the game scripts, but honestly: this shouldnt be a player's deal at all. Especially annoying are the relics. Of about 30 relics in the game about 2-5 might be of good use for your team, the rest is weaker than equipment that you can buy (granted you have the time to rest and reload often enough to reset shops), or you simply cannot use it with the party you chose. on late stages (about level 25-30), depending on your chosen skills and equipment, you either wont have any mentionable enemies (i killed the last boss of the main quest with 3 hits once), or you'll have quite some problems to win it. For example: there is equipment adding +6 of a certain skill. depending on the skill you can achieve 25 (grandmaster) + 48 (2x6 foki, 3x6 jewelry, and 3x6 other equipment) for magic skills, which is damn much OP. you also could try to become invulnurable, wich is no hard task with some of the characters (about 100 defense, about 100 resistences). but besides all that, at the end of the game you'll have to flee from a prison, having no equipment at start, being able to do lots of mistakes while fleeing. combined with the waiting time for reload, that was too much of frustration for me. even though i played that game quite some time, i cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												M&M X: Legacy - for those of us who have been playing games BEFORE Steam, and before the internet was the monster it has become, there were games played on boards, and before that, paper. Once computers entered the gaming world a few people wrote games in text only format to entertain the infant market. I even wrote a Star Trek game on the Commodore 64 that was stored on a floppy disk! M&M X is a new game which captures a little of the older, but not as old as that old C64 game I wrote. And thank heaven for that! Greatly improved graphics over past iterations of the M&M world, smoother play, old style movement and enough creatures, bad guys, and other diversions to keep the most stout-hearted adventurer in the game for many hours. This game uses an older type of interface that the younger generation might find "clunky" but this is only because they have no basis for comparison. Humor is always required in an adventure game as are challenges which increase in difficulty level as progress is made make gaming as time consuming blast! The first dragon encountered is very much a challenge worthy of the best warrior party - for this dragon is beautiful but deadly. Cyclops are always a challenge and M&M X gets it right by inserting a cave with a cyclops standing inside the entrance and it carries a club. Your party is in grave danger and there is no leaving the cave until the danger is past...er...dead. Get a horse early and let it carry the extra armor and weapons you collect along the way, leaving your arms free to hold a sword and shiled. Keep gold in your pockets though, horses can't be trusted!Easy to play, addictive style that will captivate the most jaded players due to the strangely adaptive A.I., and graphics that are old-school and yet pleasing to the eye -- Might & Magic X: Legacy is a great game! Oh, yeah, and it comes with M&M VI, a definite blast-from-the-past title that will keep you journeying and adventuring for hours on end.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Were you OK with Wizardry 8? That was one half-finished game, even more so than M&MX. That didn't stop it from being very good, though.Play M&MX if:1) You want an open-world, turn-based and grid-based dungeon crawler. 2) You are fine with thinking about class and party builds ahead of playing the game. M&MX on warrior difficulty is hard, some would say even brutal - even a very strong, metagamey party will get consistently challenged. You can't max out every skill (at most you'll max 3 skills out of 10+ available for each class) so you have to pick and choose carefully as well as making sure that your classes work well together. 3) You can appreciate the fact that it's actually very open. Recently we've been fed fake open-world games like Divinity OS and Xulima where you're actually meant to do things in a very specific order. M&MX handles this aspect very well so that going into a hard area, barely managing it through encounters and coming back some epic loot feels nice and rewarding.Don't play it if:1) You want a casual game.2) You want a faithful clone of Xeen or another M&M6. This is different - though it does borrow a lot of things from the older M&M's, at least style-wise.2) You hate turn-based, grid-based gameplay.3) Can't handle bugs, glitches and lack of polish.Have fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												So, I completely understand that my positive reaction to this game is incredibly personal, and, while I'm in no way blind to the obvious flaws in the game's design or execution, I still personally consider it my Game of the Year, 2014. I've been a fan of the Might & Magic franchise, both the RPG's and the strategy games, from childhood. When 3DO went bankrupt and dragged New World Computing down with them, I was saddened, and initially excited when Ubisoft bought the license and started working on it again. Then they released their games, and, apart from the Clash of Heroes spinoff, which became one of my favourite games ever partly due to its tongue in cheek nature, I've been sorely unimpressed by them, especially by Ubisoft's behaviour as a publisher.But then this game happened, and it is such a genuine piece of work that I couldn't help but love it despite the obvious flaws. I could go on for a feature length article about why this game is so personally important to me, but I'll limit myself to the technical aspects: this game has a great story and a great atmosphere, and it plays like a modern version of those old school, grid based, first person RPGs like Lands of Lore or, well, Might & Magic 1 through 5. Of course, this cuts both ways, in that Might & Magic X carries over some of the flaws of those old games we moved past, most noteably incosiderately placing two mobs of wildly different power levels within close proximity to each other, combined with an inability to actually escape from a fight once it's engaged. Also, like others have mentioned, it's not optimally balanced, and it's got the occasional, sometimes crippling glitch.Then again, a lot of old school RPG's weren't balanced, and had their bugs that made things annoying, and while we certainly should have moved passed this in the two decades, if you're already used to dealing with them, Legacy isn't egregious about it. And, for a Ubisoft game, the bugs and glitches are remarkably inoffensive.Like I said, great story, great atmosphere, and, you know what, some very solid puzzles that you don't see much of in modern RPGs. Like, legit puzzles, riddles, gimmick dungeon levels that are mostly intuitive, not easy enough to be insulting, or so obtuse to be frustrating. Also, if you're, like me, a huge fan of the original Might & Magic franchise, there's this moment at the end of one of these game spanning quests that made me giddy.So, yeah, recognizing that this is a flawed game, it's still incredibly important to me, and I still highly recommend it to traditional RPG lovers.
