number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Might & Magic X is an okay turn-based, retro crpg that do have some interesting ideas, but poorly executed. You play as a group of adventurers whose task is to deliver the ashes of their master in the Agyn peninsula, only to be greeted with brigands and monsters and political intrigue that plot to shatter the Empire from afar.The game start with a character creation that lets either pick pre-determined adventurers, make up your own or let everything choosed randomly. You will find 4 generic playable races being Humans, Elfs, Dwarves and Orcs, each race featuring 3 unique classes each, even though each one can be summed up as Warrior, Ranger and Mage.Each class have its own set of special abilities, along with a late game 'promotion' that will let you unlock Grand-master skills and new traits, although it's kind of blurry which one seems to be the most effective in what situations. Some classes are very late game based where others are early game efficient, so i recommend check a wiki before throwing yourself blindly into the game, especially if you want to play in Hard.Character progression will grant you attribute points and skill points to allocate in different capacity. You can raise the level of your skills up to a certain stage where you will need to find a trainer to unlock the next matery step, while granting you with additionnal traits. Each classes can only unlock certain skills up to a certain level of mastery, but every classes feature almost the same skills. Although, playing in hard, i started by allocating points in Vitality, especially for my 'tanks' so that they soak up more damage, until i realise that it was more a waste than anything since the Skill trait "endurance" end up giving a stronger health pool than what you can get from the few points the attribute will grant. So i'd recommend spending most of your points in dps or critical, eventually Spirit so that your caster can keep up firing spells.It is a fairly simple system, though one of the major complaint i'd have is that one of the skill tree that will give your melee caracter more combat skills will only grant you with more Mana, where you actually need them to control and add more strategy to your actions in combat. The main weapons traits will let you carry better weapon indeed, but never give you any actual skill to use in battle so, you end up wanting more dps rather than more mana for skills you don't have anyway.The "seek a trainer" system is also pretty sweet on paper, but they happen to be a bit randomly scattered through out the game, and so you'll find out that a lot of 'expert' trainers for early game skills you'd be tempted to spend points in will be located in later game zones you can hardly reach with a lower level. So you find youserlf specialising in skills you will be able to actually train rather than taking the ones that feels interesting for your build but can't make anything out of it because you can't properly train them.A good thing though is that the peninsula is somewhat open world with dungeon scattered around so, you rarely feel claustrophobic about your environment, compared to other dungeon crawler. You will find yourself exploring the world with care, trying to find every small cave or dungeon, hidden secrets and chests, which is probably the best part of the game. Most of the zones will be level capped so you'll know when you enter somewhere you don't have the level required for, mainly because most of the mobs will destroy you. But if you are determined and have a good team composition you can sometimes wander always a little further, which feels really rewarding to overcome enemies that gave you a beating a few hours ago. Although... you don't have that much to do in the exploration in the end. The peninsula feels really small after a few hours in, even if populated with a lot of little things and npcs all around, it always feels like once you've killed everything and clicked everywhere the zone become empty, with rarely any reason for you to come back. Unfortunatly, the game features a lot of backtracking, and an old chool fast travel system that, even if i liked it, can be a bit dull to use just to bring an early game npc a quest item you found in the other side of the map.Also, you can't interract with much of the walls or what is around you by yourself, so there would be no hidden switchs or moving objects around. It is fairly restrictive for most of the secrets will be overly obvious, highlighted 3D details you can only interract pressing [spacebar]. So in a way, it is very contextual.You'll speak to npcs and use different items like chest or barrel that will let you raise certain stats the same way, which is a shame because the game do present you with a lot of puzzle that are sometimes clever, but never escape the "mash everything and press every floor switch until you find a solution" problem.Combats are turn based, you have to take an action, either walking or attacking with your whole groupe, before the enemy move and so on. Each group will only be able to attack adjacent to their position so you will have to use the landscape and diagonales to prevent from being flanked by too many monsters at once. It's also important to know that once you're engaged with a group, aka next to their square, you can't move anymore or leave the battle. Enemies will also follow you to death once you aggro them so, once a combat start there is no turning back. Which can become really frustrating at time, especially since the devs use a lot of that fact to put you in really hard, unfair embushes you can't really prevent.The level design and placement of a lot of monster group will also be in favor of the monsters themselve rather than the player. Rarely you will have the line of sight to hit and lure monsters from afar, which makes ranged based classes or character build less powerfull than the regular melee ones. The only reason you'd max out a "perception" based character would be to detect traps and secret or eventually aggro at long distance just so you can lure enemy into a corridor, which is a shame.So is the game any good ? Well...I've never played a Might and magic before so i'm kind of unaware of its lore or what the former games were. The only one i almost got into was the 6th, but when i discovered it, Morrowind was released and so i was put off by the graphics. I approached that game thinking why not try the latest one so maybe i can get into the others, but the least i can say is that the game deliver its lore in a very unwelcome fashion for a newcomer. Most of the things that is narrated refer to a lot of details out of the peninsula, giving a sense of never really concerning you in any way except for the ancient war and a few other, quest related notes scattered here and there. Same goes for the npc that will usually tells you about themselves or about the empire but, never in an engaging way. So naturally, i left the background behind, only to realise that certain quests and puzzle needed you to answer things related to the informations you'll learn everywhere.Also, it may be because i have a Radeon but during my playthrough, i encountered a hell lot of visual glitches too like, background elements clipping and disapearing, reapiring when you face them. Some mobs were stuck in their animation making the game broken.But somehow, i liked the game. I liked the exploration and that feeling of completion you get from going back to early levels and finding solutions to encounter you couldn't beat. It's just really sad that the game feels like Ubisoft taking the oportunity and success of indy games like Grimmrock to grab some cash with a really low budget game. Because it feels rushed in many aspect.In the end, i'd recommend that game if you ran out of retro crpg or if you love Might and Magic. But if you're new to the genre i'd recommend to look for something else.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												7.5/10. As a MM fan having played all MM games, this game actually succeeds in capturing the MM charme and spirit! It is nice to level up, train with trainers, and get to Expert, Master and GM status. The game is well balanced, quite difficult at the beginning, so that you will need to come back later for some bosses, and even in late game, remains challenging. The size of the game is nice, also that there are some riddles and puzzles in the dungeons.Negative: Graphics outdated, bad decisions in the beginning (many experts, Masters are not accessible until later acts, as they are located in cities you cant access!), a lot of walking around due to lack of decent teleport system; weak presentation of the "story". Last, UPLAY does not work properly if game is bought through Steam... you need to contact Support to be able to get UPlay points and unlock Rewards (worked with al other UPlay gmaes I have).All in all, a nice and addicting RPG similar to older MM titles, which could have been grand with a higher budget and a better engine, but delivers on what it tries to be. Too bad it was no success, and likely there will be no future games like this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Were you OK with Wizardry 8? That was one half-finished game, even more so than M&MX. That didn't stop it from being very good, though.Play M&MX if:1) You want an open-world, turn-based and grid-based dungeon crawler. 2) You are fine with thinking about class and party builds ahead of playing the game. M&MX on warrior difficulty is hard, some would say even brutal - even a very strong, metagamey party will get consistently challenged. You can't max out every skill (at most you'll max 3 skills out of 10+ available for each class) so you have to pick and choose carefully as well as making sure that your classes work well together. 3) You can appreciate the fact that it's actually very open. Recently we've been fed fake open-world games like Divinity OS and Xulima where you're actually meant to do things in a very specific order. M&MX handles this aspect very well so that going into a hard area, barely managing it through encounters and coming back some epic loot feels nice and rewarding.Don't play it if:1) You want a casual game.2) You want a faithful clone of Xeen or another M&M6. This is different - though it does borrow a lot of things from the older M&M's, at least style-wise.2) You hate turn-based, grid-based gameplay.3) Can't handle bugs, glitches and lack of polish.Have fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												So, I completely understand that my positive reaction to this game is incredibly personal, and, while I'm in no way blind to the obvious flaws in the game's design or execution, I still personally consider it my Game of the Year, 2014. I've been a fan of the Might & Magic franchise, both the RPG's and the strategy games, from childhood. When 3DO went bankrupt and dragged New World Computing down with them, I was saddened, and initially excited when Ubisoft bought the license and started working on it again. Then they released their games, and, apart from the Clash of Heroes spinoff, which became one of my favourite games ever partly due to its tongue in cheek nature, I've been sorely unimpressed by them, especially by Ubisoft's behaviour as a publisher.But then this game happened, and it is such a genuine piece of work that I couldn't help but love it despite the obvious flaws. I could go on for a feature length article about why this game is so personally important to me, but I'll limit myself to the technical aspects: this game has a great story and a great atmosphere, and it plays like a modern version of those old school, grid based, first person RPGs like Lands of Lore or, well, Might & Magic 1 through 5. Of course, this cuts both ways, in that Might & Magic X carries over some of the flaws of those old games we moved past, most noteably incosiderately placing two mobs of wildly different power levels within close proximity to each other, combined with an inability to actually escape from a fight once it's engaged. Also, like others have mentioned, it's not optimally balanced, and it's got the occasional, sometimes crippling glitch.Then again, a lot of old school RPG's weren't balanced, and had their bugs that made things annoying, and while we certainly should have moved passed this in the two decades, if you're already used to dealing with them, Legacy isn't egregious about it. And, for a Ubisoft game, the bugs and glitches are remarkably inoffensive.Like I said, great story, great atmosphere, and, you know what, some very solid puzzles that you don't see much of in modern RPGs. Like, legit puzzles, riddles, gimmick dungeon levels that are mostly intuitive, not easy enough to be insulting, or so obtuse to be frustrating. Also, if you're, like me, a huge fan of the original Might & Magic franchise, there's this moment at the end of one of these game spanning quests that made me giddy.So, yeah, recognizing that this is a flawed game, it's still incredibly important to me, and I still highly recommend it to traditional RPG lovers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Might & Magic X is an okay turn-based, retro crpg that do have some interesting ideas, but poorly executed. You play as a group of adventurers whose task is to deliver the ashes of their master in the Agyn peninsula, only to be greeted with brigands and monsters and political intrigue that plot to shatter the Empire from afar.The game start with a character creation that lets either pick pre-determined adventurers, make up your own or let everything choosed randomly. You will find 4 generic playable races being Humans, Elfs, Dwarves and Orcs, each race featuring 3 unique classes each, even though each one can be summed up as Warrior, Ranger and Mage.Each class have its own set of special abilities, along with a late game 'promotion' that will let you unlock Grand-master skills and new traits, although it's kind of blurry which one seems to be the most effective in what situations. Some classes are very late game based where others are early game efficient, so i recommend check a wiki before throwing yourself blindly into the game, especially if you want to play in Hard.Character progression will grant you attribute points and skill points to allocate in different capacity. You can raise the level of your skills up to a certain stage where you will need to find a trainer to unlock the next matery step, while granting you with additionnal traits. Each classes can only unlock certain skills up to a certain level of mastery, but every classes feature almost the same skills. Although, playing in hard, i started by allocating points in Vitality, especially for my 'tanks' so that they soak up more damage, until i realise that it was more a waste than anything since the Skill trait "endurance" end up giving a stronger health pool than what you can get from the few points the attribute will grant. So i'd recommend spending most of your points in dps or critical, eventually Spirit so that your caster can keep up firing spells.It is a fairly simple system, though one of the major complaint i'd have is that one of the skill tree that will give your melee caracter more combat skills will only grant you with more Mana, where you actually need them to control and add more strategy to your actions in combat. The main weapons traits will let you carry better weapon indeed, but never give you any actual skill to use in battle so, you end up wanting more dps rather than more mana for skills you don't have anyway.The "seek a trainer" system is also pretty sweet on paper, but they happen to be a bit randomly scattered through out the game, and so you'll find out that a lot of 'expert' trainers for early game skills you'd be tempted to spend points in will be located in later game zones you can hardly reach with a lower level. So you find youserlf specialising in skills you will be able to actually train rather than taking the ones that feels interesting for your build but can't make anything out of it because you can't properly train them.A good thing though is that the peninsula is somewhat open world with dungeon scattered around so, you rarely feel claustrophobic about your environment, compared to other dungeon crawler. You will find yourself exploring the world with care, trying to find every small cave or dungeon, hidden secrets and chests, which is probably the best part of the game. Most of the zones will be level capped so you'll know when you enter somewhere you don't have the level required for, mainly because most of the mobs will destroy you. But if you are determined and have a good team composition you can sometimes wander always a little further, which feels really rewarding to overcome enemies that gave you a beating a few hours ago. Although... you don't have that much to do in the exploration in the end. The peninsula feels really small after a few hours in, even if populated with a lot of little things and npcs all around, it always feels like once you've killed everything and clicked everywhere the zone become empty, with rarely any reason for you to come back. Unfortunatly, the game features a lot of backtracking, and an old chool fast travel system that, even if i liked it, can be a bit dull to use just to bring an early game npc a quest item you found in the other side of the map.Also, you can't interract with much of the walls or what is around you by yourself, so there would be no hidden switchs or moving objects around. It is fairly restrictive for most of the secrets will be overly obvious, highlighted 3D details you can only interract pressing [spacebar]. So in a way, it is very contextual.You'll speak to npcs and use different items like chest or barrel that will let you raise certain stats the same way, which is a shame because the game do present you with a lot of puzzle that are sometimes clever, but never escape the "mash everything and press every floor switch until you find a solution" problem.Combats are turn based, you have to take an action, either walking or attacking with your whole groupe, before the enemy move and so on. Each group will only be able to attack adjacent to their position so you will have to use the landscape and diagonales to prevent from being flanked by too many monsters at once. It's also important to know that once you're engaged with a group, aka next to their square, you can't move anymore or leave the battle. Enemies will also follow you to death once you aggro them so, once a combat start there is no turning back. Which can become really frustrating at time, especially since the devs use a lot of that fact to put you in really hard, unfair embushes you can't really prevent.The level design and placement of a lot of monster group will also be in favor of the monsters themselve rather than the player. Rarely you will have the line of sight to hit and lure monsters from afar, which makes ranged based classes or character build less powerfull than the regular melee ones. The only reason you'd max out a "perception" based character would be to detect traps and secret or eventually aggro at long distance just so you can lure enemy into a corridor, which is a shame.So is the game any good ? Well...I've never played a Might and magic before so i'm kind of unaware of its lore or what the former games were. The only one i almost got into was the 6th, but when i discovered it, Morrowind was released and so i was put off by the graphics. I approached that game thinking why not try the latest one so maybe i can get into the others, but the least i can say is that the game deliver its lore in a very unwelcome fashion for a newcomer. Most of the things that is narrated refer to a lot of details out of the peninsula, giving a sense of never really concerning you in any way except for the ancient war and a few other, quest related notes scattered here and there. Same goes for the npc that will usually tells you about themselves or about the empire but, never in an engaging way. So naturally, i left the background behind, only to realise that certain quests and puzzle needed you to answer things related to the informations you'll learn everywhere.Also, it may be because i have a Radeon but during my playthrough, i encountered a hell lot of visual glitches too like, background elements clipping and disapearing, reapiring when you face them. Some mobs were stuck in their animation making the game broken.But somehow, i liked the game. I liked the exploration and that feeling of completion you get from going back to early levels and finding solutions to encounter you couldn't beat. It's just really sad that the game feels like Ubisoft taking the oportunity and success of indy games like Grimmrock to grab some cash with a really low budget game. Because it feels rushed in many aspect.In the end, i'd recommend that game if you ran out of retro crpg or if you love Might and Magic. But if you're new to the genre i'd recommend to look for something else.

												First, I loved playing all the old Might and Magic games.  When you can put a dragon in your party, that makes for some good times!  So nostalgia is the biggest element in recommending this title.Sure, there are many more games far greater and more compelling than this, but MMX is like rewatching an old movie that was your favorite years ago, before you knew better.  I'm not a button masher, and the old school "take all the time you want making decisions during a fight" interface is something, I'm embarrassed to admit, I enjoy.Look, "Legacy" is right there in the title.  This is an old school RPG that's mildly entertaining, and just the right speed for ageing, casual RPG gamers too intimidated to jump into the contemporary open world games of today.  Like me.

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Best RPG I've played in years, and has quickly become my single favorite game. After playing this I just HAD to play the rest of the M&M series, and I played from 3 to 9 and loved every second of it. This is how RPGs are supposed to be!Pros: - awesomely fun RPG game in pretty much every way.Cons: - support was unfortunately pulled by Ubisoft before a host of audio problems could be patched out, so we're stuck with them forever now. Battle music gets stuck on all the time, sounds constantly don't play or have wrong volumes. With a long enough play session you can end up with 3+ battle songs all playing at the same time all out of synch, which is pretty irritating to hear. these problems are extremely disappointing since the game itself is otherwise so amazing. exiting and running the game again does fix it though (temporarily). - After having played the rest of the series, there are a few things in comparison that I miss, but these are not strictly good or bad:    - most M&M games have an accelerating levelling scale. progression is slow in the beginning, but by the end you're gaining like 10 levels per trainer visit. in this one, progression does start slow, and does accelerate at first, but at the end it slows to a crawl, and you end up basically frozen and will never be good at everything you could have been good at. this is pretty strongly different than the other M&Ms where you could master everything about your class and still have tons of points left over. depending on your point of view this could be a good or bad thing.    - this game actually has *better* tactical combat than any of the other M&M games, and depending on which classes you choose, you can still become very powerful. though the classes are actually very imbalanced as well, some being extremely powerful and some being very weak. again, this may or may not be a bad thing.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												First, I loved playing all the old Might and Magic games.  When you can put a dragon in your party, that makes for some good times!  So nostalgia is the biggest element in recommending this title.Sure, there are many more games far greater and more compelling than this, but MMX is like rewatching an old movie that was your favorite years ago, before you knew better.  I'm not a button masher, and the old school "take all the time you want making decisions during a fight" interface is something, I'm embarrassed to admit, I enjoy.Look, "Legacy" is right there in the title.  This is an old school RPG that's mildly entertaining, and just the right speed for ageing, casual RPG gamers too intimidated to jump into the contemporary open world games of today.  Like me.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												I got this game as a part of a bundle and thought "well, this will be one game I'll nevel install".But I ended up trying the game, and liked it so much I completed it.Despite being released in 2014, Might and Magic X has a very strong back to 90' feeling looming over it. It mostly feels like a weird mixture of roguelike and older Might and Magic games. Turn based game where you run in a grid. Certainly not something you would expect from such a new game.I, however, find this pleasant and nostalgic.If you like older Might and Magic titles and are fan of roguelikes, then this game will be good for you, try it out if it's on sale. If you aren't fan of either, better stay away. You will probably not like this.There are two major downsides for this game I disliked.-Damn much running around in same places.-No real game notes. Too often you keep wondering "where on earth I saw that earth magic master teacher. Gotta go to google again, I'm not checking the whole world again to find him."They certainly didn't stop me from playing, but I must admid both were annoying for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												I loved it and had a great time playing it, but you may not.  So, let's discuss it's progency, for a moment.The game owes it's existence to the joyful Legend of Grimrock, which did a great job updating the games of my youth.  MMX is an even more direct throwback to the original Bard's Tale in 1985.  The Bard's Tale took Wizardry and added outdoor areas.  Sure, they weren't that different -- they were basically dungeons with sky blue tiles as opposed to underground grey and brown tiles, but the effect worked on me.  If you have some nostalgia for the early days of RPG gaming, this will likely hit a home run.  It reminds me of playing games on my Apple II, even including watching the graphics render.  What I really enjoyed most was developing my characters and watching them become increasingly powerful.  I wanted them well prepared for the final battle, and there are many opportunities to improve their skills and their loot.Pros:- RPG nostalgia- Good skills and character development options- Good magic system- The individual quests and dungeon were mostly fun- Combat is well done- To me, at least, the game is almost perfectly balanced (with the stock party).  Only toward the end did I begin to feel overpowered.  Most of the game, the battles were close and tense, but rarely did my entire party die.- Great opportunities for exploration -- there is always something new to find- No monster respawns!!  Once you clear an area, it stays clear.  I like that.Cons:- Graphics look good, but take a long time to render.  At one point, the landscape renders well before the castle sitting on the landscape renders.  That's just weird.- Members have your party have comments about everything going on around them.  I love that.  Except that they repeat the same things over and over and over again.  We get it... human cities are as dangerous as the jungle.  Let's move on.  When characters finish a major battle, they cheer an entirely disingenuous "Yay!"  It sounds exactly like a bunch of poorly paid actors sitting around their home microphones trying to appear enthusiastic.-  With some exceptions, most of the battles use pretty much the same tactics.  I had the same criticism of Dragon Age.  So this game is not unique, in this regard.I've invested about 55 hours into this game.  And I had a lot of fun doing it.  If you have  a soft spot in your heart for the RPG dungeon-crawling heyday of the 80s, I think you'll really enjoy this.  I sure did.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I'm not entirely sure this is a fitting homage to the series, let alone a worthy sequel to the original Might and Magic first person adventure games. This feels more like a Wizardry game than anything, only it does not have random encounters.If you're looking for an updated version of M&M 6: The Mandate of Heaven, you're going to notice immediately that combat is turn based instead of action based and that you're not able to cheese the ranged attacks quite the same way you did in the last few titles. This forces the element of difficulty into the game that used to come from having to strategize about when and where to cast spells and run from enemies. Once engaged in melee combat, you can't back away or use exits, and very often you're arbitrarily ambushed and beaten down from behind. This leaves little to no strategy available to the player to decide when and where to engage the enemy. Worse still, every skill you need to progress is gated by leveling up multiple times and collecting money, which there is a limited amount of in the game. This entire game feels like it was designed by people who did not play the original series and do not fully understand the mystique and challenge of M&M adventure games. The elements are there but different. Most of the difficulty in this game comes from needing to block or chug potions at the right time. And you can't even equip the best shields available to you in the first town. You have to complete several incredibly difficult dungeons and make it to the second town before you're even allowed to purchase the training to equip them. This makes the fights with tougher enemies frustrating if not outright unfair. Those who would focus on defense to secure the best outcome are punished while people who choose whatever deals the most damage are rewarded; All in all, this is par for the course for turn based games but not balanced the way M&M 1-6 were. Moreover, entire methods of playing the game, such as going with heavy armor and shields, goes completely unrewarded, so there's no point to that portion of the content. You do not have a front-line and a back-line since enemies can reach any of your party members to attack them at any time, so there isn't even signficant incentive to have defensive members balancing against softer damage dealers until halfway into the game when you actually get usable healing spells. By then, you'd have been better off going full barbarian or mage across the board.The only genuinely positive part of this experience is that the dungeons and quests all string together nicely like an mmo and it's easy to figure out where to go next just from exploring and poking around on the mini map, talking to people, etc. That and, somehow acknolwedging the limitations of non-respawning chests and enemies, the game apparently dumps loot on you when you find it, so that's nice.I haven't played a full team of mages like I mentioned earlier yet but I suspect they work much better than the classes I was trying before; And if that is the case, then this is the only great similarity between the original games and this one. Overall, I don't want to take the time to play it anymore after having gotten my butt kicked repeatedly. I'm already too frustrated after a few hours of trudging around in the Lighthouse. The difficulty curve is ridiculous and fights go from being winnable to being totally hopeless, from room to room even. Moreover, there's almost nothing to indicate to you when going in a room or across a bridge will be life threatening so you can never learn from your mistakes. There are even several places you're clearly meant to return to when you're stronger, but how much stronger is somewhere between vaguely incomprehensible and utterly unfathomable. It feels like a big slap in the face when you as a player go in a door that was open to you and can't even escape certain demise because you weren't genuinely going to be allowed an opportunity to succeed at what lay behind it. This kind of high stakes trial-and-error is very unrewarding and disappointing.Update: I have now played with a full team of mages and it's as I suspected. I was able to get this team to the place of progress it had taken hours to get to before within about 30 minutes. Of course once you run into the one thing that's immune to the school of magic you've been focusing on or up the difficulty from normal to hard, you can expect to be back in the boat of unplayable content and frustration. Overall, the game seems to want to force you to have to bring a specific party to accomplish the goals it sets before you. Some doors can't even be found and some passage ways can't even be opened unless a person with a high score in a specific stat is able to locate and/or open them for your team, which means teams lacking that stat may not even be able to progress in certain dungeons at all. This is very detrimental as, 1) it's impossible to know what the recommended (or required) team composition is upfront and 2) playing with any other party composition is apparently almost futile. TLDR; This is a competent and somewhat fun to play turn-based RPG but has little to nothing to offer those who are fans of M&M6. I'd still like to recommend this one because it's challenging and a classic first person dungeon crawler like Wizardry, but I can't while it's at any price over 10 dollars. The fact that Wizardry 6 is the same kind of game and was slightly better than this despite having come out 24 years ago prevents me from doing so. If you were hoping to have some fun with this one, buy Wizardry Renaissance and play it all the way through first. Then maybe pick this one up and play it out of boredom when it falls below 10 dollars standard price.
